fields.description: تقرير : فادي منصور - هيتي تاريخ بث التقرير :17\1\2010 قال رئيس وزراء هيتي إن السلطات ومنظمات الإغاثة تمكنت من انتشال جثث خمسة وعشرين ألف شخص لقوا مصرعهم حتى الآن جراء الزلزال الذي ضرب بلده. في هذه الأثناء، قالت منظمات إغاثة أمريكية إن عدد قتلى الزلزال الذي ضرب هيتي قد يصل إلى مئتيْ ألف. ورغم استمرار تدفق المساعدات فإن عدم التنسيق والتخبط يؤثران سلباً على عمليات التوزيع

fields.title: الفيضانات تشرد أكثر من خمسة ملايين باكستاني
fields.description: تتواصل معاناة ملايين من سكان إقليم السند جنوبي باكستان مع استمرار غرق قراهم وحقولهم الزراعية بمياه الأمطار. أكثر من خمسة ملايين مشرد، في مساحة مليون وثمانمائة ألف هكتار من الأراضي الزراعية، يعانون ظروفا قاسية، تنقصهم سبل الحياة الأساسية. كما فقدوا ماشيتهم وأبقارهم، التي نفقت داخل الفيضان، مما سمم المياه الراكدة الملوثة أصلاً. الأمر ينذر بانتشار عدة أمراض تقرير : عبد الرحمن مطر تاريخ البث : 17/09/2011

fields.title: معاناة ضحايا الفيضانات في اقليم بلوشستان الباكستاني
fields.description: تقرير عبد الرحمن مطر تاريخ بث التقرير : 21-8-2010

fields.title: مبادرة المواطنين للمساهمة في مواجهة كارثة التسونامي
fields.description: رغم مرور أكثر من أسبوعين على الزلزال الكبير الذي ضرب اليابان، تتواصل الهزات الزلزالية التابعة، وكان آخرها بقوة ست درجات وخمسة أعشار الدرجة على مقياس ريختر. وأدى الزلزال إلى إطلاق تحذير من التسونامي، لكنه ألغي بعد فترة قصيرة. وتعيق هذه الهزات جهود الحكومة للتعامل مع الحجم الكبير لكارثة التسونامي وأزمة محطة فوكوشيما النووية. ويدفع هذا الوضع المواطنين للمبادرة، كلٌ حسب قدرته، للمساهمة في مواجهة الكارثة. تقرير فادي سلامة

fields.title: الوضع الصحي في منطقة بدين بإقليم السند
fields.description: قال الناطق باسم الهيئة الوطنية لادارة الازمات في باكستان إن حوالي مليوني شخص يعانون في إقليم السند من الامراض الناجمة عن الفيضانات. واضاف الناطق ان كثيراً من الأط...

fields.description: تقرير:صهيب جاسم 18-9-2007

fields.title: خسائر بشرية ومادية جراء الفيضانات في باكستان
fields.description: تقرير أحمد بركات تاريخ بث التقرير : 2 - 8 - 2010

fields.title: المياه تجرف جسوراً وطرقات في إقليم السند
fields.description: تقرير :احمد بركات تاريخ البث : 17-9-2010

fields.title: المتضررين من فيضانات باكستان يشكون غياب الحكومة

fields.title: من معاناة بطش تسونامي اليابان
fields.description: ضرب زلزال قوي المناطق الشمالية الشرقية من اليابان، دفع السلطات إلى إطلاق تحذير جديد من خطر حدوث تسونامي. وقد تجاوزت قوة الزلزال سبع درجات على مقياس ريختر. ويأتي الزلزال بعد شهر من زلزال مدمر أحدث موجة تسونامي وأودى بحياة آلاف اليايانيين. تقرير: فادي سلامة بتاريخ: 11-04-2011

fields.title: تعهد بمراجعة سياسة الطاقة النووية في اليابان
fields.description: تعهد رئيس الوزراء الياباني بإجراء مراجعة دقيقة لسياسة الطاقة النووية الحكومية في البلاد والتي ثارت حولها شكوك بعد كارثة الزلزال وموجات تسونامي. ورغم مرور أكثر من شهر على هذه الكارثة مازالت إمدادات الماء والكهرباء والغاز مقطوعة عن جزء كبير من المدن الساحلية المنكوبة. ورغم ذلك تسود روح التصميم والتحدي بين اليابانيين ممن نجت منازلهم من التسونامي حيث يصرون على العيش فيها وسط الركام متحدين أكبر كارثة طبيعية تواجهها اليابان في تاريخها. تقرير : فادي سلامة تاريخ البث : 18/04/2011

fields.title: بعد عام من كارثة والتسونامي اليابان
fields.description: رغم مرور عام منذ كارثة الزلزال والتسونامي التي حلت باليابان في مارس/آذار من العام الماضي، لا تزال عمليات إزالة الدمار في خطواتها الأولى. ولا يزال مئات الآلاف من الناجين , في مآوٍ مؤقتة وسط ظروف صعبة. تقرير/ فادي سلامة 2012/3/12

fields.title: أثر كارثة الزلزال والتسونامي على اليابان
fields.description: تراجعت اليابان خلال السنوات الخمس الماضية من ثاني أكبر دولة مانحة للمساعدات الخارجية إلى خامس أكبر المانحين بسبب التباطؤ الاقتصادي الذي تشهده. وقد أضافت كارثة...

fields.title: تغيرات تشهدها اليابان بعد كارثة التسونامي
fields.description: يخشى ناشطون يابانيون من استغلال الأحزاب اليمينية في البلاد كارثة زلزال وتسونامي الحادي عشر من مارس/آذار الماضي لتوسيع نشاطاتها ونشر أفكارها المتطرفة، والاستفادة من تنامي الروح الوطنية بعد الكارثة. وقد ازدادت مخاوف الناشطين إثر دعوة مسؤول بارز من اليمينيين، لضرورة امتلاك طوكيو قوة نووية رادعة . تقرير/ فادي سلامة 24/9/2011

fields.title: معاناة عائلة شردتها الفيضانات شمالي باكستان
fields.description: تقرير عبد الرحمن مطر تاريخ البث 27/8/2010

fields.title: الركام يزعج المتضررين من زلزال اليابان
fields.description: خلفت موجة التسونامي التي ضربت السواحل اليابانية عقب الزلزال المدمر الذي ضرب البلاد مؤخرا وراءها خرابا امتد لآلاف الكيلومترات على طول الساحل الشرقي الشمالي لليابان. وباتت أطنان الركام تشكل مصدر إزعاج وتلوث لسكان المناطق المتضررة. ويسعى اليابانيون جاهدين لحل هذه المشكلة. تقرير : محمد حسن تاريخ التقرير : 27/03/2011

fields.title: زيارة اردوغان لمناطق الفيضانات في باكستان
fields.description: تقرير أحمد زيدان تاريخ البث : 14/10/2010

fields.title: سلسلة زلازل تهز سواحل جزيرة سومطرة الإندونيسية
fields.description: هزّت سلسلة زلازل سواحل جزيرة سومطرة في غربي إندونيسيا بلغت قوة ُ أشدِها نحوَ تسع ِ درجات ووصلت إلى عدة دول أخرى. وقال الرئيس الإندونيسي إن حدوث تسونامي أمر غير متوقع حاليا ولكن السلطات ستبقى في حالة تأهب تقرير : هيثم ابو صالح تاريخ البث 11/4/2012

fields.title: تجاهل وسائل الإعلام اليابانية أوضاع مفاعل فوكوشيما
fields.description: ومع توالى أخبار الوكالات العالمية عن أوضاع مفاعل فوكوشيما وتداعيات الأضرار التي لحقت به جراء الزلزال وموجة التسونامي التي ضربت اليابان في الحادي عشر من مارس الجاري، لم تكتمل الصورة تماما حول الحدث حتى الآن

fields.title: تشيلي..عمليات النهب التي تلت الزلزال
fields.description: تقرير : حجي جابر تاريخ بث التقرير : 2010/03/1 تواصل فرق الإنقاذ في تشيلي البحث عن ناجين من كارثة زلزال السبت الماضي التي أودت بحياة أكثر من سبعمئة شخص حتى الآن. من جانب آخر، أعلنت سلطات تشيلي حالة الطوارئ، وفرض حظر على التجوال في البلاد، سعياً لضبط عمليات النهب التي تلت الزلزال.

fields.title: اثاركارثة انحسار مياه الفيضانات في ولاية كوينزلاند
fields.description: تقرير : صالح السقاف تاريخ البث :18-1-2011

fields.title: The DC Embassy of Haiti reacts to massive quake
fields.description: Raymond Joseph, Haitian Ambassador to the United States, speaks to the press on Jan. 13 about the 7.0 earthquake that hit the impoverished country on the afternoon of Jan. 12. (Anna Uhls/The Washington Post)

fields.title: A Year of Coping With Tragedy in Japan
fields.description: Wall Street Journal reporters produced an ongoing series of videos documenting the aftermath of Japan's March 11, 2011 earthquake and tsunami.

fields.title: Quake Rattles Communities Around Indian Ocean
fields.description: A massive earthquake hit off the west coast of Indonesia, triggering a tsunami warning in the same region where a 2004 tsunami killed more than 200000. A second magnitude-8.2 quake triggered a fresh tsunami warning.

fields.title: Corporate Japan's Post-Quake Resilience
fields.description: Corporate Japan has proven remarkably resilient over the year since the 2011 earthquake. Earnings are expected to fall in the year through March, but rebound past predisaster levels next year, James Simms reports on Markets Hub.

fields.title: An Altered Japan Marks a Year After Quake
fields.description: Country commemorates the anniversary of the 2011 earthquake with prayers for victims, reflections on losses and protests against nuclear energy. Read more: online.wsj.com

fields.title: After Tsunami, a Sweets Shop's Effort to Make a Comeback?
fields.description: More than seven months ago, Masayuki Kimura watched from a hilltop as his sweets shop and factory in Rikuzentakata, Japan were destroyed by a massive tsunami. Now he's trying to figure out how to start over. WSJ's Linda Blake reports.

fields.title: After the Disaster, Knitting Together New Friends
fields.description: A year after a tsunami destroyed their communities, a group of elderly Japanese women have found a simple way to cope with the past and face an uncertain future - with knitting needles and balls of yarn. WSJ's Yumiko Ono reports from Shichigahama.

fields.title: Japan Town's Mayor Fights to Rebuild City Crippled by Tsunami
fields.description: Rikuzentakata, Japan wasn't rebuilt this year. But it is still alive. WSJ's Patrick Barta reports on the efforts of Mayor Futoshi Toba to bring his tsunami-devastated town - and his family - back from the brink. Photo: Hisashi Murayama.

fields.title: Japanese Tsunami Anniversary - Holding Onto Community in the Aftermath
fields.description: How do you keep a town together when it's no longer habitable? A year after a tsunami crippled the Fukushima nuclear power plant, evacuees from nearby Namie are struggling to do just that. WSJ's Yuka Hayashi reports.

fields.title: Japan Town Rikuzentakata's Will to Go On After Tsunami
fields.description: After surviving the March 11th tsunami, a lone pine tree in Rikuzentakata has become a symbol of the town's will to go on. But this emblem of life is failing. WSJ's Linda Blake reports.

fields.title: Quake Rattles Communities Around Indian Ocean
fields.description: A massive earthquake hit off the west coast of Indonesia, triggering a tsunami warning in the same region where a 2004 tsunami killed more than 200000. A second magnitude-8.2 quake triggered a fresh tsunami warning. Eric Bellman has details on Lunch Break from Jakarta.

fields.title: Japan Town's Effort to Get Back on Its Feet
fields.description: Nine months after a tsunami ravaged Japan's northeast, downtown Rikuzentakata remains an abandoned wasteland, but there are signs of progress. WSJ's Linda Blake reports.

fields.title: New Designs for Nuclear Reactors
fields.description: Innovations in nuclear design are tackling problems like the ones that contributed to the Fukushima Daiichi disaster in Japan. WSJ's Rebecca Smith reports.

fields.title: Japanese Tsunami Anniversary - New Hospital for Devastated Town
fields.description: Dr. Mikhito Ishiki has been hustling to meet the medical needs of his city after the tsunami gutted Rikuzentakata's general hospital last March. After months of lobbying, Mr. Ishiki has broken ground on a new inpatient ward. WSJ's Linda Blake reports.

fields.title: Japanese Tsunami Anniversary - Rebirth for a Sake Brewer
fields.description: After his sake factory was destroyed by Japan's March 11th tsunami, Yasuhiko Konno learned that running a business isn't always about profit. His employees matter, too, as they work tirelessly to restart the business. WSJ's Linda Blake reports.

fields.title: Japan Sake Brewer: Rebirth in Tsunami Recovery
fields.description: After his sake factory was destroyed by Japan's March 11th tsunami, Yasuhiko Konno learned that running a business isn't always about profit. His employees matter, too, as they work tirelessly to restart the business. WSJ's Linda Blake reports.

fields.title: World: The Killings at Les Cayes Prison - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: When the Haitian police stormed a prison after rioting in January, they fatally shot at least 12 detainees and wounded 40 others, a New York Times investigation found. Related Article: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: Surviving Haiti's Earthquake: Children - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: A year in the lives of two severely injured Haitian children who are flown to Boston for surgery, physical therapy and recovery. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: World: Surviving the Haiti Earthquake - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: A look back at the month following the earthquake in Haiti and how a diverse group of individuals dealt with the crisis. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: A Factory Grows in Haiti
fields.description: The showcase project for Haiti's earthquake reconstruction is being built far outside the disaster zone, in a location that could jeopardize the country's key conservation effort. Related Article: nyti.ms Please visit nyti.ms in order to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: TimesCast - December 30, 2010
fields.description: A photographer reflects on the difficult year for Haiti; how the Tea Party helped set the political agenda in 2010; and Oprah Winfrey's new cable network. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: World: The Doctor Who Would Be President - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: With the hospitals in Port-au-Prince overwhelmed with trauma patients from the earthquake, Dr. Guy Theodore is picking up the slack in a remote mountain village. Related Article: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: Haiti's Legacy of Environmental Disaster - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Even before the Jan. 12, 2010 earthquake Haiti's environment teetered on the brink of disaster. Brent and Craig Renaud traveled to report country's deforestation problems just weeks before the deadly earthquake. Produced by Brent Renaud, Craig Renaud, and Jane Bornemeier. Full Coverage of Haiti Earthquake of 2010: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Security in an Insecure Land - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Alix Sainvil, a Haitian-American United Nations police officer, worked to secure Cité Soleil. But the disaster may cause gang violence and instability to return this poor neighborhood. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Saving Lives on the USNS Comfort
fields.description: The US Navy struggles to get earthquake victims to the Comfort, a hospital ship, so they can be treated. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: For Haitian Children, a Crisis Escalates - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: After 10 Americans tried to take children out of Haiti last month, medical evacuations for critically wounded children have slowed dramatically because of paperwork requirements. Related Article: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: In Haiti, Help From Above
fields.description: As wide-scale challenges of aid distribution persist, owners of private aircraft are delivering small-scale assistance. Related Article: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: The Mother Figure of Morne Lazarre - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Rea Dol leads an effort to feed and care for the people of Morne Lazarre, a poor neighborhood in Port-au-Prince. Related Article: nyti.ms

fields.title: TimesCast - July 28, 2011
fields.description: July 28, 2011 - Thousands die in Somalia's worst drought in decades; Speaker John A. Boehner gathers support for the debt limit vote; and Dominique Strauss-Kahn's accuser continues her press campaign. Please visit nyti.ms in order to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: TimesCast - April 20, 2011
fields.description: Italy's long relationship with Libya complicates its role in NATO's mission; Japan's history with tsunamis is documented in stone; and the "Restrepo" director Tim Hetherington is killed in Libya. Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: World: Haiti's Enduring Creativity - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Though the arts were impacted by the January 12 earthquake in Haiti many artists are already responding to the disaster with music. Related Link: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: On the Ground in Port-au-Prince - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: The Times' Marc Lacey reports from the airport in Port-au-Prince shortly after flying into Haiti on Wednesday, January 13. Produced by Erik Olsen. Full Coverage of Haiti Earthquake of 2010: bit.ly

fields.title: World: A Somali-American's Improbable Return - nytimes.com
fields.description: After returning to Somalia in 2008 to aid victims of a drought, the locals asked Mohamed Aden to become their leader. In less than a year, he has transformed Adado, Somalia, into an enclave of peace. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: Opinion: Congo's Forgotten War
fields.description: The war unfolding in eastern Congo has claimed perhaps 30 times as many lives as the Haiti earthquake, but this crisis generates little international response. Related Link: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Haiti's School Problem - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: The earthquake that leveled much of Port-au-Prince left Haiti's already fragile educational system in shambles. A few schools have reopened, but class remains out of reach for most students. Related Link: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: Haiti Earthquake - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Haitian authorities and humanitarian aid organizations are struggling to respond amid devastation wreaked by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake that struck near Port-au-Prince, Haiti, late on Tuesday. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Confusion in the Haitian Countryside
fields.description: In the smaller cities and countryside outside of Port-au-Prince, major obstacles still stand in the way of getting food, water and shelter to those affected by the earthquake. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Fort National, Haiti: Choosing to Stay - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: After the devastating earthquake in Haiti on January 12, most residents of Fort National fled their homes. Todd Heisler, a staff photographer, documented the ones who stayed behind. Related Link: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: Impact of the United Nations - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: UN Bureau Chief Neil MacFarquhar reports on the impact of the devastating Jan. 12 earthquake in Haiti on United Nations facilities and personnel located there. Produced by Erik Olsen. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Haiti: Stolen Tents - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: In Port-au-Prince, tents which had been sent as relief for homeless Haitians, were subsequently stolen, leaving some without shelter. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: Haiti Quake Day 8: A Proper Burial
fields.description: Rob Harris joins a widow and her family on a pilgrimage to bury a loved one who died in last week's earthquake. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Haiti Earthquake Day 7: NY to Haiti - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: New York City police, fire and paramedic teams are working around the clock in Haiti. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: A Carnival Artist Without a Carnival - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Onel Bazelais, a Haitian mask maker from the city of Jacmel, struggles to showcase his vision and make a living now that Carnival has been canceled throughout the earthquake ravaged nation. Related Article: nyti.ms

fields.title: World: The Great Mosque of Djenné - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: The Great Mosque of Djenné, Mali, is a magnet for tourists, but it is increasingly difficult for locals to live a normal life around it. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: World: Haiti Earthquake Day 7: UN Aid Efforts - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, requested that 3500 more security officers be sent to Haiti to help ensure relief efforts can take place effectively. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Haiti Quake Day 5: Hunger Frays Nerves - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Survivors show frustration and restraint at a locked supermarket, four days after a powerful earthquake devastated Port-au-Prince. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: Haiti Quake Day 9: Hospital Ship Arrives
fields.description: The USN Comfort, a United States naval hospital ship, treats its first earthquake patients in Haiti. For Haitian-American sailors it is a particularly meaningful duty. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Haiti Quake Day 8: Haiti's First Lady - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Marc Lacey of The Times spoke with Haiti's first lady, Elizabeth Préval, in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, who said that the Haitian government was still in place despite many buildings having been destroyed. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: National: Haitians in the United States Pray for News - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: With electricity and telephone lines in Haiti cut, Haitians living in the United States do not know if their loved ones are dead or alive after the Jan. 12, 2010 earthquake, but are desperate to help. Produced by Emily B. Hager and Vijai Singh. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Haiti Quake Day 7: A Mass Exodus - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: As aid and increased security forces arrive in Haiti, thousands of earthquake refugees are leaving Port-au-Prince, fleeing to the countryside, or trying to get on planes to leave the country entirely. Related Articles: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Haiti Quake Day 7: Aid, by Sea - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: The Comfort, a United States naval hospital ship, is preparing to offer aid to Haitian patients. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Ishinomaki Journal: No Plans To Leave - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Toshiyo Fujisaki, a restaurant owner, discusses life after the tsunami in Ishinomaki City, directly north of the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant. Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: TimesCast - Fleeing the Nuclear Crisis
fields.description: March 17, 2011 - Tokyo Bureau Chief Martin Fackler reports from Yamagata on the influx of people fleeing the nuclear crisis. Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: The Neediest Cases | Jovins Lin Dorestan - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Mr. Dorestan was standing in the doorway of his home in Haiti when the earthquake struck on January 12, killing hundreds of thousands. He came uncomfortably close to being one of them. Related Article: nyti.ms Watch more videos at nytimes.com/video

fields.title: TimesCast - Aftermath in Kesennuma
fields.description: March 15, 2011 - Mac William Bishop reports on the aftermath of the tsunami and earthquake in the fishing village of Kesennuma, Japan. Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: World: Haiti Quake Day 6: Faith and Healing - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: The decimated Catholic Church in Port-au-Prince offers hope while others offer what medical help they can. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Day 2: Japan's Earthquake - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: The death toll continues to rise as the Japanese military tries to find survivors in towns that have completely vanished. Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com/​video

fields.title: World: In Haiti, Slow Relief - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Damien Cave reports on the relief efforts in Port-Au-Prince on January 15, 2010. Related Article: bit.ly

fields.title: World: Death in the Streets of Port-au-Prince - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Marc Lacey reports from Haiti on the evening of January 14, 2010. Latest News on Haiti Earthquake: bit.ly

fields.title: TimesCast - March 11, 2011
fields.description: Tokyo bureau chief Martin Fackler reports on the huge earthquake and tsunami that hit Japan. Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: March 14, 2011
fields.description: Tokyo bureau chief Martin Fackler reports on the huge earthquake and tsunami that hit Japan. Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: Opinion: Earthquakes in Japan - nytimes.com/video
fields.description: Andrew Revkin of Dot Earth on what earthquake-prone countries can learn from Japan's resilience, motivation and planning. Related Article: nyti.ms Please visit nyti.ms to embed this video. Watch more videos at nytimes.com

fields.title: Haiti six months on: Claudine Souffrante
fields.description: Claudine Souffrante was gravely injured when her school collapsed during the earthquake. The consequences have enveloped her entire family.

fields.title: Disaster and Debt: India's Dalit community fight back
fields.description: India's east coast communities suffered from the Boxing Day Tsunami of 2004. Less well covered in the news are the annual cyclones which hit this coast, when the lives and homes of the most vulnerable have to be rebuilt each year. This video is one of a series of investigative documentaries about poverty, commissioned and editorially controlled by Guardian Films, produced in association with Christian Aid. Go to www.guardian.co.uk for more details.

fields.title: Haiti six months on: Pierre-Louis Joliebois
fields.description: College Joliebois school was badly damaged in the earthquake. Pupils and teachers alike remain traumatised and the school's headmaster faces a struggle to keep the school open

fields.title: Pakistan floods: Feudals under fire in Punjab
fields.description: In the second film in our series of four, Declan Walsh travels through Punjab where the swollen waters of the Indus river have devastated the breadbasket of Pakistan and the livelihoods it supports

fields.title: Haiti six months on: Wilson Octaveus
fields.description: Wilson Octaveus lost his wife and three children in the Haitian earthquake. He takes us to the site of where his home once stood

fields.title: When the floods came: Australia and Pakistan
fields.description: Photographer and film-maker Gideon Mendel visited the Sindh province in Pakistan six weeks after the floods hit in 2010, and Queensland and Victoria in Australia during early 2011. Here he presents a unique split screen view of the disasters and the people whose lives they destroyed

fields.title: Rebuilding a business after the Japan tsunami
fields.description: Michihiro Kono watched as last month's tsunami destroyed his home and the soy sauce business handed down through generations of his family. He describes what happened on 11 March and explains why rebuilding local industry is vital for the area's recovery

fields.title: Kenyan drought threatens crops and livestock
fields.description: The nomadic pastoralists who live in the arid scrubland on the Kenya-Somalia border are being forced out of their traditional way of living by a succession of worsening droughts. Peter Beaumont travelled to the border town of Elwak to meet the desperate families abandoning the ranger lands for an equally uncertain future living by the road

fields.title: The aftermath of the earthquake in Haiti
fields.description: Guardian photographer and filmmaker David Levene spent a week in Port-au-Prince documenting the human cost of the recent earthquake

fields.title: Back in the frame: Photographs washed away by Japan's tsunami restored and returned to owners
fields.description: In an effort to save the memories of a nation, muddied photographs and albums sent from tsunami-hit areas are washed and repackaged by an army of volunteers across Japan before being returned to their owners. The disaster on 11 March 2011, described by then prime minister Naoto Kan as Japan's worst since the second world war, killed more than 15000 people and destroyed the homes and livelihoods of thousands more

fields.title: Back home in the Fukushima exclusion zone
fields.description: Residents of a town in the shadow of Japan's Fukushima Daiichi power plant visit the houses they had to abandon when nuclear disaster struck

fields.title: Pakistan floods: The new island villages of Sindh province
fields.description: In the third of our four-part series Declan Walsh travels to Sehwan, home to Pakistan's largest Sufi shrine, where the flood waters are draining slowly and illness and malnourishment are rife

fields.title: Japan's tsunami survivors gather in shelter
fields.description: The Minami Sanriku evacuation shelter is a makeshift home to nearly 1000 displaced people as they pick up the pieces following the tsunami. Supplies are finally arriving after days of waiting

fields.title: Fukushima radiation fails to deter dairy farmers
fields.description: In a radiation hotspot downwind of Japan's stricken nuclear plant, farmers explain why they can't leave their cows despite fears of contamination

fields.title: After the tsunami: Japanese survivors find reasons to sing
fields.description: Music and government assistance ease the pain as people who lost their homes in the 11 March disaster watch the demolition of their neighbourhoods in Kamaishi city

fields.title: 'We're always fresh in Haiti'
fields.description: A day in the life of a barbershop owner in Port-au-Prince since the earthquake

fields.title: Aceh five years after the tsunami
fields.description: Dan Chung revisits the Indonesian province five years after the Indian Ocean disaster

fields.title: Noriko Ogawa on her Japan disaster appeal concert in London
fields.description: Renowned pianist Noriko Ogawa will be performing a special appeal concert in aid of the British Red Cross Japan Tsunami Appeal at Kings Place on Wednesday 30 March. Here she talks about the disaster that has devastated her country and the music she has chosen to perform

fields.title: Japan tsunami: Rescue in Kesennuma
fields.description: Following shocking amateur footage filmed in Kesennuma, Jonathan Watts find hope in the rescue of an elderly couple from their home in the city

fields.title: Miyagi tsunami aftermath: 'We lost everything in a split second'
fields.description: Survivor testimony from Miyagi prefecture recounts the devastating effect of the Japanese tsunami

fields.title: Keiser Report - Global Death Spiral (E71)
fields.description: In the 71st episode, Max Keiser and co-host, Stacy Herbert, look at death spirals and vanity trades in the global financial markets. In the second half of the show, Max talks to Richard Buchanan about his attempts to form a Facebook union.

fields.title: Pirates' paradise: Inside Somalia's suffering
fields.description: Civil War and famine have been fueling Somali piracy for more than a decade, making many turn to the sea in search of the source of income. International naval forces have been stepping up patrols in the area. But here they are behind enemy lines. The place has turned into a navigators nightmare and a Pirates Paradise. The RT crew visits the gulf of Aden and dives deep in the story.

fields.title: CrossTalk on 2011: Storm Before the Storm?
fields.description: 2011: a revolutionary year? Or is it just the calm before the storm? What should the year 2011 be remembered for? Has it brought any solutions to the crises? Peter Lavelle remembers the top stories with his guests Mark Levine from CA, Jeffrey Sommers and Mark Levine from DC on Dec. 30. CT on FB: www.facebook.com

fields.title: Haiti Earthquake: Chronicles of Inferno
fields.description: The Republic of Haiti is a Caribbean country. It was the first independent nation in Latin America and the first black-led republic in the world. Despite these facts, Haiti is the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. On January 12, 2010, a 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck Haiti and devastated the capital city of Port-au-Prince. Reportedly, more than 150000 people were killed and many buildings were destroyed and damaged in the quake. RT correspondent Aleksandr Luchaninov visited Haiti after the tragedy and here is his report.

fields.title: CrossTalk on Haiti: Year of Agony
fields.description: On this edition of Peter Lavelle's CrossTalk, he asks his guests why aid efforts in Haiti have largely failed. Who is to blame? Is it the UN, the US and its NGOs or is it the fault of the Haitian people? RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: CrossTalk on Haiti: Take Care or Takeover?
fields.description: Could the aid to Haiti have been better administered? Peter Lavelle and his Crosstalk guests - William R. Hawkins from American Business & Industry Council Education and US filmmaker Danny Schechter are debating the issue.

fields.title: CrossTalk: Haiti's Hell
fields.description: This time on CrossTalk, Peter Lavelle asks what to expect as Haiti holds an already very flawed election and whether the UN is actually playing a counter-productive role in the country. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Nuclear Emergency: All eyes on Fukushima
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com RT gets some expert opinion on the situation in Japan from Christopher Simons, an Associate Professor at the International Christian University in Tokyo.

fields.title: Fukushima nuke plant out of control? RT talks to nuclear expert from Hiroshima, Japan
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com RT talks about the earthquake and it's effects to Dr. Robert Jacobs, a research associate professor of nuclear history and culture at Hiroshima Peace Institute.

fields.title: Slow rolling tsunami: 2010 flood worst disaster in Pakistan history
fields.description: International aid is flowing into Pakistan where massive floods have claimed 1600 lives and affected more than 17 million people. "We are still in the beginning. There are hundreds of thousands of people displaced, newly displaced every day, every week more and more people are impacted," UN Deputy Envoy to Pakistan Kilian Kleinschmidt told RT.

fields.title: Immortal Technique: No escape from capitalism!
fields.description: RT spoke to renowned political rapper and activist Immortal Technique, who recently spent time in Haiti. He argued that there is no long term vision in Haiti, referring to the nation as a military and police state run by the United States and the UN.

fields.title: 'EU a disaster, illegal state built on false principles'
fields.description: The European Union is a disaster and the UK should quit, says Gerard Batten, a European Parliament Member. RT met him in London.

fields.title: 'Water used to cool Fukushima flowing back to sea - effects hard to predict'
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com In an exclusive interview with RT, Sergey Shoigu, Russia's Emergencies Minister, discussed the work of emergency services and international rescue amid the growing threat of a nuclear reactor meltdown in Japan following the quake and tsunami.

fields.title: Fukushima nuclear reactor radiation exposure: How far will this go?
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan's Prime Minister has addressed the nation as fears intensify about a possible nuclear meltdown at a power-plant struck by last Friday's catastrophic earthquake and tsunami. The company running the Fukushima nuclear power plant has admitted meltdown is a possibility following 2 fresh explosions at the complex. There are also fears of radioactive leakage with reports of damage to the structure protecting the reactor. For more we talk to Christopher Simons, who's an expert on the situation in Japan, an Associate Professor at the International Christian University in Tokyo.

fields.title: Ron Paul Review: Haiti quake, Body Scanners and Yemen ops
fields.description: The issue of international aid for Haiti earthquake survivors is being debated by politicians worldwide. US congressman Ron Paul shares his thoughts about the situation along with a look at terrorism and the ongoing financial crisis.

fields.title: History Repeating? Fears Fukushima may turn into Chernobyl
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com The situation at the Fukushima plant is seeing comparisons drawn to the Chernobyl nuclear explosion - which was the world's worst atomic plant disaster. It happened 25 years ago in Ukraine, but the effects of the contamination are still felt today. Let's now talk to our correspondents Aleksey Yaroshevsky in Kiev and Peter Oliver in Moscow.

fields.title: Seismic Hotbed: 'Quake time zone, Japan not the end'
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com The magnitude-9.0 earthquake in Japan was one of the major events in the natural cycle of the planet's seismic activity, Evgeny Rogozhin, deputy director of the Institute of Physics of the Earth of the Russian Academy of Sciences told RT.

fields.title: Radioactive Kamikaze: Saving Japan from Fukushima meltdown
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com The fate of millions of Japanese now lies in the hands of just a few dozen. They're known as the 'faceless fifty' - a team of workers putting their lives on the line to stop nuclear disaster at the Fukushima plant. RT's Irina Galushko looks at how man sometimes has to sacrifice himself when technology fails. Also RT talks to Dr Kiyul Chung, he's a political scientist and Editor-in-Chief of political magazine 4th Media.

fields.title: Silent Island: Grim scenes as RT films Ishinomaki trashed by Japan tsunami
fields.description: RT presents exclusive footage from quake-tsunami devastated Ishinomaki region. The earthquake and tsunami wiped out entire communities in Japan. People who lost their homes are living in overcrowded shelters while the clean-up operation goes on. But even after that's finished, many will still have nowhere to go. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Haiti: Aid efforts hurt by lack of coordination
fields.description: The relief efforts in Haiti have demonstrated several problems endemic in international relief efforts. With all the technology available in 2010, why is it so difficult to get help into areas suffering from natural disasters. And, what can be done to help Haiti in particular overcome its many problems. Kristine Frazao talks with Lawrence Wilkerson and Lawrence Korb.

fields.title: Russia to help Japan in 'worst crisis since WW2' as nuke disaster looms
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Moscow is promising to do its best to help Tokyo with the crisis. Having dealt with the world's worst nuclear disaster - Chernobyl - Russia has vital experience in this area.

fields.title: Fukushima Fears: Nuclear disaster man-made?
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Another powerful aftershock has struck Japan. This follows last week's double hit which killed over 7000 people and crippled the Fukushima nuclear plant, raising fears of a meltdown. RT's Ivor Bennett is across developments in Japan.

fields.title: Japan Ground Zero: Latest images from Fukushima nuke plant
fields.description: Japan's TEPCO releases footage from tsunami-stricken Fukushima nuclear plant. Video was recorded during dust sampling survey at southern side of Unit 3 Fukushima reactor building, on November 5, 2011 RT on Twitter twitter.com RT on Facebook www.facebook.com

fields.title: Worst Nightmare? Nuclear meltdown threat as Fukushima fuel rods 'fully exposed'
fields.description: It's feared nuclear fuel rods may have partially melted at the 2nd reactor of the stricken Fukushima power plant. This comes after reports they were fully exposed for a short period of time. Shaun Burnie, an independent atomic energy consultant from Scotland says Japan's nuclear crisis is much worse than it seems.

fields.title: Emergency at Onagawa nuclear plant, radiation 700 times over normal
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan has declared an emergency alert at another nuclear power plant in the north-east of the country. Radiation levels of about 700 times higher than normal have reportedly been detected at the facility in Onagawa. Authorities are currently investigating their source. For more opinion on the threat of a nuclear crisis in Japan, RT talks to Harvey Wasserman, who's written on the subject of a sustainable green-powered Earth.

fields.title: RT's 10 that shaped 2011: Japan's Tsunami & Fukushima Meltdown
fields.description: RT is remembering the ten key events of 2011. Today, we turn to Japan's massive earthquake and tsunami that killed more than 10-thousand people. It also caused a series of explosions at the Fukushima nuclear plant that put the world on watch, fearing an atomic disaster. RT's Ivor Bennett was in Japan in the hours after the tragedy struck. RT on Twitter twitter.com RT on Facebook www.facebook.com

fields.title: Nuclear Alert: Fears of 3rd explosion at Japan's Fukushima as cooling fails
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com There are new threats and warnings coming from Japan with reports of a possible third explosion on the way at the Fukoshima nuclear plant. This follows Monday's second blast there which injured 11 people. Japanese officials have been reassuring locals that radiation levels at the plant are within legal limits. RT talks to Dr. Robert Jacobs from the Hiroshima Peace Institute with more on what the threat of radioactive contamination means for Japan's people and infrastructure.

fields.title: 'Fukushima reports conflicting, Japan govt not in control'
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan has declared emergency at another nuclear power plant in Onagawa, northeastern Japan. Hightened radiation levels have reportedly been detected there. Authorities are currently investigating their source. At first it was reported they could've been blown from Fukushima. Dr. Robert Jacobs from the Hiroshima Peace Institue says that if that's the case, the 20km exclusion zone around the Fukushima reactor may not be enough...

fields.title: Radiation caught on tape: RT talks to Fukushima zone stalker
fields.description: A powerful aftershock has hit northeastern Japan, exactly a month after March's devastating earthquake and tsunami killed over 13 thousand people. Meanwhile the government is extending the 20 kilometre evacuation zone around the Fukushima nuclear plant over risks of long-term radiation. Well video journalist Tetsuo Jimbo braved the area and went within 1 and a half kilometres of the facility to document the dangerous levels of radiation there. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: 'Haiti needs a relief effort that doesn't continue oppression'
fields.description: Carl Dix of the Revolutionary Communist Party says that US-Haitian relations has influenced the way the relief efforts have unfolded in Haiti. Is there any solution except a revolution?

fields.title: New radioactive leak at 2nd nuclear plant in Onagawa, Japan
fields.description: In Japan, radioactive water is reported to have leaked from fuel pools at the Onagawa nuclear power plant following a violent aftershock measuring seven point one. The plant is less than a hundred kilometres from the stricken Fukushima plant, which is still to be made safe following last month's devastating double hit of earthquake and tsunami. To discuss how events might develop RT talks to Philip White from the Citizen's Nuclear Information Center, who's in Tokyo. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: New hydrogen blast at Fukushima nuclear reactor after Japan quake-tsunami
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com To the latest developments in Japan now where there's been a second blast at the Fukushima nuclear plant. 11 people were injured in the explosion. The reactors are said to be intact at the moment. And officials claim there hasn't been a change in the radiation levels since the latest incident took place. At least 22 people have already been exposed to radiation - after an earlier explosion following Friday's devestating tremor and tsunami. Officials say the possibility of another blast is now unlikely. People within a 20km radius of the reactor have been evacuated to safety. There had been warnings of a three-metre high tsunami moving towards the northeast coast of Japan caused by a strong aftershock. We're now getting reports that the alert has been lifted. Prime Minister Naoto Kan has called it the worst crisis since World War II. RT's Ivor Bennett is in Sendai, one of the towns worst-affected by the huge wave.

fields.title: Japan earthquake: Danger of nuclear disaster after Fukushima plant failure?
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com North-east Japan has been swamped by a major tsunami - and the entire Pacific region is now on alert. It was caused by an 8.9-magnitude earthquake that struck 130 kilometres off the eastern coast - sending a reported 10-metre wall of water inland, causing widespread devastation. 32 people are confirmed dead - but that number's expected to rise. The wave has also reached Russia's Kuril islands to the north, reportedly around a metre high. In Japan, 200 people have reportedly been washed away, with several others missing in Japan's Sendai city. Tokyo's been all-but shut down - with fires and injuries widely reported there. Millions are without electricity. Norita International Airport is also closed. 20 powerful aftershocks have been recorded since the first quake, which was the strongest ever recorded in Japan - and the 6th biggest-ever. An earthquake has now been felt in Hawaii - measuring 4.5 - with tsunami waves expected within a few horus.

fields.title: Full meltdown in full swing? Japan maximum nuclear alert
fields.description: In Japan, radiation levels in the seawater near the Fukushima plant continue to rise. They're now more than 3.5 thousand times higher than normal. Radioactive material has also been detected in soil at the facility. Japan's government described the situation as serious and unpredictable. Workers have been unsuccessfully trying to restore the plant's cooling system, in what is now the worst atomic crisis since Chernobyl. There's been some debate over whether there are any similarities between the two events. RT talks to Professor Christopher Busby, of the European Committee on Radiation Risks. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: US set Haiti up for disaster
fields.description: In addition to the obvious problems Haiti faces recovering from this week's earthquake, the country suffers from a lack of civil society and a respected government. Glen Ford of the Black Agenda Report says that the effects of Haiti's history continue to play out in the recovery effort.

fields.title: Aid to Haiti is not enough?
fields.description: Many have considered the relief efforts in Haiti a success, however critics argue that the relief effort has been slow and sluggish from the start. China responded faster to the crisis much faster than the US, however people are still living in tent cities, there is no after care help and people are still dying. Even though the UN has taken charge the situation has gotten much worse.

fields.title: 'Fukushima media cover-up - PR success, public health disaster'
fields.description: Residents of the Fukushima district, and those who lived near-by have not only faced radiation exposure but also social exclusion... That's according to Dr. Robert Jacobs, Professor of nuclear history, at the Hiroshima Peace Institute. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Race to save lives continues in Haiti
fields.description: Much of the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, and surrounding towns lie in ruins - while rescuers wage a desperate race against time to save survivors trapped under the rubble.

fields.title: US grants Haitian immigrants protected status
fields.description: Haitian immigrants living in the US will get a temporary break. The US Office of Homeland Security is offering undocumented Haitians eighteen months of protected status. The decision was made following the catastrophic deadly quake last week in Port-au-Prince. RT's Lauren Lyster talked about the new developments with Amy Gottlieb. She is the Director of Immigration Rights from American Friends Service Committee.

fields.title: Losing battle for Fukushima? Radioactive material leaked out, plant abandoned
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan may be losing control at the Fukushima nuclear power plant after a rise in radiation levels meant attempts to stabilise the situation had to be halted. The government's top spokesman said one of the reactor's key containment vessels is feared to have broken and radioactive material leaked out.

fields.title: 'Fukushima nuke crisis - Chernobyl on steroids'
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan is struggling to control the reactors damaged by the disasterous earthquake as radiation levels continue to rise and a partial meltdown of nuclear fuel is feared in two facilities at the Fukushima plant. Workers were withdrawn after the danger of exposure peaked - the alert also saw plans to drop water from helicopters adandoned. Energy adviser Arnold Gundersen says the Japanese nuclear crisis could have disasterous consequences.

fields.title: Chernobyl Lesson: Japan's swift evacuation amid nuke disaster fears
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com There are new threats and warnings coming from Japan with reports of a possible third explosion on the way at the Fukoshima nuclear plant. This follows Monday's second blast there which injured 11 people. Japanese officials have been reassuring locals that radiation levels at the plant are within legal limits. Russia is sending aid and rescuers to Japan to help with the aftermath of Friday's earthquake and tsunami, as well as to prepare for a potential new disaster... RT's Peter Oliver has more on Moscow's involvement.

fields.title: 'Catastrophic' radiation exposure, more blasts at Fukushima nuclear reactor
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan's Prime Minister has addressed the nation as fears intensify about a possible nuclear meltdown at a power-plant struck by last Friday's catastrophic earthquake and tsunami. The company running the Fukushima nuclear power plant has admitted meltdown is a possibility following 2 fresh explosions at the complex. There are also fears of radioactive leakage with reports of damage to the structure protecting the reactor.

fields.title: Military takeover or humanitarian mission?
fields.description: A week after the earthquake in Haiti, rescue teams and relief groups are concerned for their safety as they try to distribute aid. The concerns are based not only on a lack of infrastructure, but also because of reports of armed gangs roaming the streets of Port au Prince. And with the US military in charge of the airport, some fear the efforts are turning into a military takeover rather than a humanitarian mission.

fields.title: Japan's Chernobyl? Radiation pressure fears at Fukushima plant
fields.description: Japan is dealing with the aftermath of a massive tsunami. The official number killed is now 375. That's a figure which even the most optimistic estimates suggest will rise dramatically. The huge wave was caused by the biggest earthquake in the country's history. Japan has now asked the UN to send rescue teams to help deal with the disaster. Another earthquake has also hit central Japan in the past hours, although there are no reports of damage from this latest aftershock. An emergency situation has been declared at the Fukushima nuclear plant in the north east, after it was damaged. The pressure inside the reactor is rising, raising fears of a radiation leak. But Japan's nuclear safety agency says to reduce the pressure, radioactive vapor may be released, posing no risk to humans or the environment. Top videos of Japan earthquake & tsunami 2011 www.youtube.com Subscribe to RT! www.youtube.com Watch RT LIVE on our website rt.com Like us on Facebook www.facebook.com Follow us on Twitter twitter.com Follow us on Google+ plus.google.com RT (Russia Today) is a global news network broadcasting from Moscow and Washington studios. RT is the first news channel to break the 500 million YouTube views benchmark.

fields.title: Haitians pray, mourn the dead
fields.description: The UN has appealed for more than 500 million US dollars to help victims of the devastating earthquake in Haiti. The organization says the funds are intended to help three million people over the next few months.

fields.title: Fukushima - Nuclear Titanic? Seawater radiation hits new high in Japan
fields.description: RT discusses Fukushima situation with John Large, an independent nuclear consultant. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Strong 6,1 magnitude aftershock rocks Haiti
fields.description: A powerful Aftershock measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale has hit Haiti some sixty kilometres away from the capital. Early reports say residents abandoned their homes and gathered on the streets for safety. This comes a week after the initial devastation, as international agencies are still struggling to get aid to those still in despeate need of help. With the situation now spiraling out of control only a small portion of the food, water and medicine has reached survivors.

fields.title: Nuclear No-go: Geiger counter key device in Japan
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com The race is on to restore electricity to Japan's stricken Fukushima nuclear facility - so that workers can then get the reactor cooling systems back online. Japan's also increased the severity of the accident to a level five out of seven - meaning the consequences reach wider than the power plant's vicinity. It's now a week since the country was rocked by its worst-ever post-war disaster that's left thousands of people dead or missing. Ivor Bennett is there for RT.

fields.title: Private companies look to Haiti for opportunities
fields.description: Private companies are looking to Haiti for upcoming job opportunities. These organizations are offering a range of services, from rapid housing construction to emergency relief shelters and even transportation. After the 7.0 earthquake struck Haiti, several companies posted websites for future clients. Private organizations in Afghanistan and Iraq are also seeing dollar signs in the catastrophe. RTs Lauren Lyster talked with investigation journalist, Wayne Madsen about this issue facing Haiti.

fields.title: Scary footage: Tsunami waves raging, buildings burn after 8.9 Japan earthquake
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com The government has confirmed 25 deaths, with the number expected to rise. It follows the 8.9-magnitude earthquake which sent a 4-metre wall of water inland across the Miyagi prefecture . There's considerable destruction - 200 people have been washed away. Buildings, cars and ships were also swept by the raging waters. Several are missing on Japan's Sendai island. The first wave has also reached Russia's Kuril islands to the north, reportedly around a metre high. There are several fires along Japan's eastern coastline, and 4 million homes are without power. The Prime Minister's ordered an emergency response team to tackle the disaster - with aircraft scrambled to the worst-affected area. Communication is crippled and Tokyo's Norita International Airport has been closed. The entire Pacific region is on tsunami alert - with Hawaii braced to be hit within the next few hours.

fields.title: Quake-shattered Haiti awaits aid as thousands feared dead
fields.description: Thousands are feared dead after Haiti's deadliest earthquake in over two centuries. The Prime Minister of Haiti said that he feared an earthquake which devastated Port-au-Prince could have killed "well over 100000" people. According to the Red Cross, more than three million people have been affected and over six hundred thousand reportedly injured. The quake measuring seven on the Richter scale destroyed the Presidential Palace Most of the island's infrastructure has been severely damaged. The island state is said to be suffering 'a catastrophe of major proportions'. With communication links on the island disrupted, people are desperately trying to contact their relatives.

fields.title: Cracked Fukushima: Radioactive steam escapes danger zone
fields.description: Workers at Japan's Fukushima plant say the ground under the facility is cracking and radioactive steam is escaping through the cracks. The cooling system at the plant failed after the devastating tsunami hit Japan in March, sparking a nuclear crisis. But new evidence suggests that Fukushima reactors were doomed to cripple even before the massive wave reached them. RT's Anissa Naouai talks to Dr. Robert Jacobs, a Professor at the Hiroshima Peace Institute. RT on Twitter: twitter.com RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com

fields.title: Home Grim Home: US gives Haitians boot back to ravaged island
fields.description: Ravaged by an earthquake that claimed over two hundred thousand lives a year ago, Haiti is still gripped by the after-effects. Widespread homelessness and a cholera outbreak have brought the island to its knees. And now, Washington has added insult to injury. Hundreds of Haitians will soon be deported from the US, to face a grim future back home. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Ten arrested after abducting 33 Haitian children
fields.description: The ten members of the Idaho-based New Life Children's Refuge (NCLR) have been arrested by Haitian authorities for attempting to abduct 33 Haitian. The NCLR says that this is just a misunderstanding; however Wayne Madsen says that the group may have wanted the children for trafficking. He also adds that three types of groups show up for children during a disaster; adoption mills, pedophiles and organ traffickers.

fields.title: Japan 7.4 Earthquake: Fueling Nuclear Fears
fields.description: A powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake has struck off the coast of Japan. A tsunami warning was issued, which was later lifted. Residents of the north-east of the country were told to evacuate to higher ground. RT talks to Dr Tim Wright, an earthquake expert from the UK's University of Leeds. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Over 1000 feared killed as megaquake strikes Japan
fields.description: Russia's Kuril islands that lie just a few kilometres north of the Japanese coast are at high risk of being hit by the tsunami. 3-metre-high waves have reportedly already reached one of the islands. RT's Egor Piskunov reports. RT also talks to James Jackson who's a professor of tectonics activity at Cambridge University. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: 'No way out of waste water dumping to keep core cool at Fukushima'
fields.description: Japanese officials say 60000 tons of radioactive water have accumulated in the basement of the stricken Fukushima plant. Workers must keep feeding water into the reactors to stop them overheating, which is leading to a build-up of radioactive fluid. Japan has asked Russia to send a waste disposal facility to the crippled nuclear station. Almost 12000 tons of low-tainted water are being released into the ocean to free storage space for more highly contaminated waste. Authorities say this poses no threat to human health or the environment. For more about the situation, RT talks to nuclear industry expert Arnold Gundersen. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Danny Schechter: US has let Haiti down
fields.description: US control of the Port au Prince airport has resulted in accusations that needed aid is not getting through. Filmmaker and blogger Danny Schechter says the US should be ashamed.

fields.title: Deserted Land: RT drives through devastation after tsunami in Sendai
fields.description: RT crew has arrived in Sendai just one day after the devastating tsunami waves almost wiped out the area. RT's reporter Ivor Bennett has been to the quake-hit regions to see, first-hand, and film the shocking aftermath of disaster. Top videos of Japan earthquake & tsunami 2011 www.youtube.com Subscribe to RT! www.youtube.com Watch RT LIVE on our website rt.com Like us on Facebook www.facebook.com Follow us on Twitter twitter.com Follow us on Google+ plus.google.com RT (Russia Today) is a global news network broadcasting from Moscow and Washington studios. RT is the first news channel to break the 500 million YouTube views benchmark.

fields.title: Fukushima Scar : 1 year since Japan's worst quake/tsunami tragedy
fields.description: Japan marks one year since a devastating earthquake and tsunami killed over nineteen thousand people, devastating an entire nation. A minute's silence has been observed at the exact moment the quake hit last March. The tsunami turned whole neighborhoods into debris leaving hundreds of thousands homeless. It also triggered the worst nuclear crisis in a quarter century after the cooling systems at the Fukushima plant were knocked out. For more on the risks of contamination the plant poses today RT talks to Dr. Robert Jacobs, who's professor of nuclear history and culture at Hiroshima Peace Institute. RT on Twitter twitter.com RT on Facebook www.facebook.com

fields.title: Christopher Busby: Chernobyl-like radiation found in Tokyo
fields.description: Workers at Japan's Fukushima plant say the ground under the facility is cracking and radioactive steam is escaping through the fissures. They also say pipes and at least one reactor were seriously damaged before the tsunami hit the area in March. RT talks to Christopher Busby of the European Committee on Radiation Risks. RT on Twitter: twitter.com RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com

fields.title: Are Haitians going to be exploited?
fields.description: Relief efforts in Haiti have been a disaster and the country remains mired in apocalyptic - to make matters worse, imperial powers and corporate vultures are circling, eyeing the profits to be made from reconstruction. Ashley Smith reports that the US is reviving what Haitians call "the plan of death", a shock Doctrine for Haiti imposed by the US in the 70s and 80s to undermine the economy, use cheap Haitian labor. Fast forward to today, the US is pushing ahead with the same kind of plan.

fields.title: Radiation up 400 times in Miyagi, new blast feared at Fukushima
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japanese police say the death toll following Friday's mega-quake and tsunami has now exceeded 1000 people. But fears remain it'll easily be 10 times that. It all comes amid warnings of new threats in the country. Officials fear there's a risk of another explosion at the Fukoshima power plant but remain confident it can withstand the blast like the first reactor did on Saturday. The government is also saying that a second reactor in Fukushima could be experiencing a partial meltdown. Meanwhile, radiation has increased 400-fold in the region of Miyagi which lies dozens of kilometres further north. It's not clear at the moment if the radiation came from the local nuclear plant or drifted up from the facility in Fukushima following Saturday's explosion. Officials claims the radioactivity released so far does not pose a threat to human health. Having said that, the number of people admitted to hospital suffering exposure is said to be rising amid a series of aftershocks that continue to rock the country. The Japanese Prime Minister has been addressing the situation and he said that 12000 people have been rescued so far. He called it was the hardest time for the country since World War II. Meanwhile the emergency services are on high alert in Russia's Far East.

fields.title: Fukushima Exclusion Zone: Inside Report
fields.description: Courtesy: Tetsuo Jimbo/videonews.com The Japanese government has issued the evacuation order on March 12 for the residents living within the 20 kilometer radius of the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant. Since then, residents have left their homes, and the "no man land" has been out of touch with the rest of the world. A Japanese journalist, Tetsuo Jimbo, ventured through the evacuation zone last Sunday, and filed the following video report. He says that, inside the evacuation zone, homes,building, roads and bridges, which were torn down by Tsunami, are left completely untouched, and the herd of cattle and pet dogs, left behind by the owners, wonders around the town while the radiation level remains far beyond legal limits. More videos on www.youtube.com

fields.title: Nuclear emergency as Fukushima cooling system fails after Japan quake
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com For more insight on Japan's earthquake, RT talks to Kevin McCue, who's the Director of the Australian Seismological Centre.

fields.title: Scientologists Rushing to Haiti
fields.description: Our Scientology sources tell us there's an interesting reason that some members of the church are swarming into Haiti. The Scientologists are taking up landing time slots, which is holding up doctors that are trying to get into the country to provide medical assistance for the citizens of Haiti. Many of the Haitians are very spiritual and are asking the Scientologists to leave them alone.

fields.title: Japan Devastated: Video of fires, landslides, stranded people
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com The extent of the damage left behind by the ferocious tsunami unleashed by Japan's biggest recorded earthquake was slowly becoming clearer by Saturday afternoon. The earthquake on Friday killed hundreds of people as it carried away ships, cars and homes, and triggered widespread fires that burned out of control. The violent wall of water swept away houses, cars and ships. Fires burned out of control.

fields.title: 'Worst-case scenario: Fukushima fuel pool with plutonium catches fire'
fields.description: Engineers at Japan's struggling Fukushima nuclear plant have resumed efforts to remove built-up radioactive water. It comes after a powerful aftershock forced crews to flee the area. On Tuesday Japan raised the nuclear alert around the facility to the maximum level of seven. This puts the crisis on a par with the Chernobyl disaster. The decision was based on new data showing more radiation had leaked from the damaged plant than previously thought. But officials say that the upgrade does not mean the situation has become more critical. Meanwhile, attempts to restore cooling systems at the reactors appear to be no closer to success. Nuclear engineer, Arnold Gundersen, believes the Japanese government has downplayed the extent of the disaster... RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: Japan closes last reactor, 'energy crisis looms'
fields.description: Japan is set to turn off its last working reactor this weekend, leaving one of the world's largest industrial nations without a source of nuclear energy for the first time in almost 50 years. The government has bowed to public pressure following last year's disaster at the Fukushima power plant after the catastrophic earthquake and tsunami. For more on the impact of the shut-down, RT talks to James Corbett, editor of The Corbett Report. RT on Twitter twitter.com RT on Facebook www.facebook.com

fields.title: RT footage of Japan Kesennuma 'ghost' port city smashed by tsunami
fields.description: RT crew has been filming in Japan's port of Kesennuma - a traditional fishing town, which was almost wiped out by tsunami. After being struck by the earthquake and the tsunami, it was then ravaged by fires that lasted days - RT's Igor Ogorodnev reports. There are at least five hundred dead in Kesennuma. Meanwhile, another strong earthquake off the coast of Japan has rocked the already devastated country. Although a Tsunami warning that was issued following the new quake has since been cancelled.

fields.title: Eyewitnesses of Japan quake talk to RT from Tokyo
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com To discuss Japan's tsunami RT talks to two eyewitnesses to the disaster. Yoshihiro Hino and Kazuyuki Sasaki are both at Meiji University in Tokyo.

fields.title: Reactor Rethink: Japan asks IAEA for help as EU eyes alt energy
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan has asked the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to help the country deal with its nuclear crisis. This comes amid concerns of similar incidents taking place around the world.

fields.title: Haiti in chaos a week after earthquake
fields.description: A week after the earthquake in Haiti, the situation on the ground grows more and more desperate. Although international governments are making additional offers of aid, not all are being accepted.

fields.title: Ruined by Tsunami: RT reporter in the middle of disaster-hit Sendai, Japan
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan is struggling to regain control over the overheated reactors at the Fukushima nuclear plant, after a series of blasts and fires. The government's most-senior spokesman said cooling reactor number 3 is now the top priority because it's posing the biggest danger. Military helicopters are currently dropping seawater onto the stricken reactors in the latest bid to avert nuclear meltdown... While other aircraft are monitoring the amount of radiation. If levels get too high for the air crews, trucks with water cannons will be deployed to try and get the temperature of troubled reactors to drop. RT's Ivor Bennett has been to the quake-hit regions to see, first-hand, how more and more people are fleeing the area - terrified by the threat of meltdown.

fields.title: First tsunami waves hit Hawaii islands, California coast after Japan quake
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Countries across the Pacific area, including Russia, South America, the US and Indonesia have been put on alert for any tsunamis heading their way. But while the first waves have now reached America's mainland any major threat appears to be fading. 95 deaths reported in Japan, but that is rising quickly. One Japanese news agency suggests there are literally tens of thousands unaccounted for. Worst hit is the north eastern city of Sendai. Police say almost every house there has been damaged or destroyed. This 8.9 earthquake was the strongest in Japan since records began 140 years ago, in fact its the 6th- largest ever recorded in the world. Experts say it's around eight thousand times bigger than the quake which devastated the New Zealand city of Christchurch last month.

fields.title: RT at Haiti quake epicenter: Humanitarian crisis looms
fields.description: Millions of dollars of aid is flowing into Haiti - following the devastating earthquake thought to have killed at least fifty-thousand people. The scale of the catastrophe poses a huge challenge to ensure that help from governments, organisations and private donors gets to those in desperate need. RT's correspondent in Haiti, Marcelo Sanchez, says people are awaiting help - among the bodies of the dead.

fields.title: Cover-Up Anger: Japanese outraged with govt keeping truth in the dark
fields.description: The Japanese government is starting radiation checkups for more than two million people living near the crippled Fukushima plant. It's part of a long-term health monitoring programme - launched over 3 months after the nuclear crisis started. And as RT's Sean Thomas reports, confusion over where's safe - and where isn't - is seeing many lose trust in the authorities.

fields.title: Video of rooftop helicopter rescue in Japan's tsunami-hit town
fields.description: Residents stranded on rooftops in the city of Kesennuma, in Japan's northeastern Miyagi prefecture, were rescued by helicopter on Saturday, after the area around their homes was inundated with water, mud and fallen trees following Friday's huge earthquake and tsunami. Top videos of Japan earthquake & tsunami 2011 www.youtube.com Subscribe to RT! www.youtube.com Watch RT LIVE on our website rt.com Like us on Facebook www.facebook.com Follow us on Twitter twitter.com Follow us on Google+ plus.google.com RT (Russia Today) is a global news network broadcasting from Moscow and Washington studios. RT is the first news channel to break the 500 million YouTube views benchmark.

fields.title: Chaos in Haiti as huge earthquake hits island
fields.description: Hundreds are feared dead in Haiti after the strongest earthquake to hit the country in over two hundred years. The island, considered the poorest country in the Western hemisphere, is said to be suffering 'a catastrophe of major proportions.' Tens of thousands of people are now homeless after 7.0 magnitude quake and the Presidential Palace and the UN headquarters are in ruins. There's been a united plea for international aid and hundreds or even thousands are estimated to have died in the tragedy.

fields.title: Faceless Fifty: 'Heroes of Japan fight to end'
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com RT talks to Alex Kerr who's an American writer and an expert on Japanese culture.

fields.title: Red Cross: Quake killed up to 50000 in Haiti
fields.description: Bodies are piling up in the streets of Haiti in the aftermath of an earthquake that has decimated the Caribbean island state. On the ground, survivors of the earthquake - measuring seven on the Richter scale - are struggling to save those still trapped under the rubble. At least a third of the population are now homeless - including the country's president. An estimated three million people will need emergency relief as aid organsations make their way to the scene. The Haitian Red Cross predicts an horrific death toll of around 50000 while the World Health Organization predicts the sheer numbers of dead may lead to an outbreak of disease.

fields.title: No Image, No News? How disasters unfold on TV
fields.description: As images of Japan's earthquake and tsunami poured in, the world watched in awe as the tragedy unfolded. But media coverage has not been as thorough in more remote regions of the world. Natural disasters in less technologically advanced areas tend to get less attention, and as a result generate less awareness. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: From tsunami to nuke plant crisis: Japanese fear invisible killer
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com Japan may be losing control at the Fukushima nuclear power plant after a rise in radiation levels meant attempts to stabilise the situation had to be halted. The government's top spokesman said one of the reactor's key containment vessels is feared to have broken and radioactive material leaked out. The authorities had earlier been using military helicopters to drop water onto the troubled reactor but later aborted the mission. RT's Ivor Bennet who's in the region, says many people are trying to flee from areas facing immediate danger...

fields.title: Japan Tsunami Havoc: Ship on roof, car graveyard, ruined homes
fields.description: Ofunato was pulverized by the blast of seawater triggered by a massive 9.0-magnitude earthquake earlier last month. The quake was one of the strongest recorded in history. Overturned cars and a boat on the rooftop of buildings could still be seen in the battered city. As many as 25-thousand people have been killed by the tsunami which also destroyed hundreds of miles of coastline. Top videos of Japan earthquake & tsunami 2011 www.youtube.com Subscribe to RT! www.youtube.com Watch RT LIVE on our website rt.com Like us on Facebook www.facebook.com Follow us on Twitter twitter.com Follow us on Google+ plus.google.com RT (Russia Today) is a global news network broadcasting from Moscow and Washington studios. RT is the first news channel to break the 500 million YouTube views benchmark.

fields.title: Haiti still suffering from aftershocks
fields.description: The earth continues to move under Haiti as the country was rocked by a 6.1 aftershock on Wednesday. Seismologist Eric Calais says that more could be done to prepare for seismic action.

fields.title: Haiti lacks food & water amid rising looting
fields.description: The UN Secretary-General has appealed to Haitians to be patient over delays in getting desperately-needed aid to the country devastated by last Tuesday's earthquake. Ban Ki-Moon made the plea from the capital Port-au-Prince on Sunday - describing the catastrophe as one of the biggest "humanitarian crises in decades.

fields.title: UN defends actions in Haiti
fields.description: As the UN mission in Haiti tries to recover from its own losses, the international organization faces criticism over its actions in the aftermath of the earthquake.

fields.title: Oil refinery ablaze after devastating Japan earthquake, tsunami
fields.description: Follow latest updates at twitter.com and www.facebook.com The government has confirmed 18 deaths, with the number expected to rise. It follows the 8.9-magnitude earthquake which sent a 4-metre wall of water inland across the Miyagi prefecture . There's considerable destruction - 200 people have been washed away. Buildings, cars and ships were also swept by the raging waters. Several are missing on Japan's Sendai island. The first wave has also reached Russia's Kuril islands to the north, reportedly around a metre high. There are several fires along Japan's eastern coastline, and 4 million homes are without power. The Prime Minister's ordered an emergency response team to tackle the disaster - with aircraft scrambled to the worst-affected area. Communication is crippled and Tokyo's Norita International Airport has been closed. The entire Pacific region is on tsunami alert - with Hawaii braced to be hit within the next few hours.

fields.title: Japan Earthquake: Helicopter aerial view video of giant tsunami waves
fields.description: A ferocious tsunami spawned by one of the largest earthquakes on record slammed Japan's eastern coast on Friday, killing hundreds of people as it swept away ships, cars and homes while widespread fires burned out of control. Police said 200 to 300 bodies were found in the northeastern coastal city of Sendai, the city in Miyagi prefecture, or state, closest to the epicentre. Another 137 were confirmed killed, with 531 people missing. Police also said 544 people were injured. Top videos of Japan earthquake & tsunami 2011 www.youtube.com Subscribe to RT! www.youtube.com Watch RT LIVE on our website rt.com Like us on Facebook www.facebook.com Follow us on Twitter twitter.com Follow us on Google+ plus.google.com RT (Russia Today) is a global news network broadcasting from Moscow and Washington studios. RT is the first news channel to break the 500 million YouTube views benchmark.

fields.title: Spy PR? Georgia arrests 20 over 'espionage for Russia'
fields.description: Twenty people have been detained in Georgia, suspected of spying for Russia, according to a Reuters report. All the suspects are Georgian citizens, a source told the news agency. The report has not yet been officially confirmed. RT's Sara Firth has the details. RT on Facebook: www.facebook.com RT on Twitter: twitter.com

fields.title: World unites in aid efforts to quake-hit Haiti
fields.description: Survivors of the Haiti earthquake - measuring seven on the richter scale - are struggling to save those still trapped under the rubble. An estimated three million people will need emergency relief as aid organisations make their way to the scene. The Haitian Red Cross predicts an horrific death toll of around 50000. The global community is doing everything possible to help the survivors.

fields.title: Video of muddy mess as tsunami waves swallow homes, villages in Japan
fields.description: Japan's NHK broadcast dramatic amateur video that captured the moment that Friday's tsunami ripped through residential areas across Miyagi prefecture. Residents of the Minami-sanriku Town took to elevated ground after a tsunami warning. They watched in horror as an enormous tidal wave swept through their town, uprooting trees, houses and carrying everything in its path.
