fields.description: www.euronews.com Tokyo is upbeat in its latest assessment of the Japanese economy In their monthly report, government economists said the recovery looks more certain due to encouraging signs in the global economy Domestic demand is also improving with companies increasing spending as areas along the earthquake-hit coast slowly rebuild. In addition spending by private individuals is holding firm, on improving consumer confidence. "The economy is still picking up slowly, while difficulties continue to prevail due to the earthquake," the Cabinet Office said in the monthly report. Progress has been frustratingly slow in rebuilding areas of the northeast coast devastated by last year's massive earthquake and tsunami. But there are signs of recovery in the area and the broader economy, albeit uneven. "Domestic demand is on an upward trend ... if both domestic and external factors improve, along with the nation's policy steps such as public spending related to reconstruction and subsidies for fuel-efficient cars, we expect a pickup in the economy will become certain," said Minoru Masujima, director of macroeconomic analysis at the Cabinet Office. However, the report also noted several risks facing the economy, including rising oil prices, Europe's prolonged debt crisis and constraints on power supply with all but two of Japan's 54 nuclear reactors shut amid public safety fears after the radiation crisis sparked by the disaster. The government report follows an assessment by the ...

fields.title: Tepco executives sued over Fukushima
fields.description: www.euronews.com Shareholders of Tokyo Electric Power are suing the company's bosses over their role in the Fukushima nuclear disaster. In the biggest claim of its kind in Japan, they are asking for the equivalent of 51 billion euros in compensation. In the law suit, 27 current and former Tepco directors are accused of failing to prepare for a severe accident and ignoring multiple warnings of a possible tsunami. The 42 shareholders want the executives to pay damages to Tepco, which would then use the money to compensate those affected by the disaster. Hiroyuki Kawai, a lawyer representing the shareholders said: "By seeking to hold individuals responsible, we want to correct the collective and systemic irresponsibility in the nuclear industry." There is deep public anger over Tepco's handling of the crisis and the perceived arrogance of top management, including underplaying the seriousness of the disaster in its early stages and delays in compensating those forced to leave their homes. The Fukushima Daiichi plant was wrecked by an earthquake and tsunami last March, triggering the world's worst nuclear crisis in a quarter of a century. The disaster swamped the firm with huge clean-up, compensation and decommissioning costs.Find us on: Youtube bit.ly Facebook www.facebook.com Twitter twitter.com

fields.title: Japan exits recession
fields.description: www.euronews.net Japan's economy has rebounded. It expanding by 1.5 percent in the third quarter and six percent year on year. It is recovering from a recession triggered by March's earthquake and tsunami as reconstruction after the disaster supports economic growth. However economists said that pace will likely slow as the strong yen and weak global growth hit exports. Some believe the economy may even shrink again as floods in Thailand -- a major production base for Japanese manufacturers -- disrupt production and as emerging economies cool.

fields.title: Accelerated earning predicted by Toyota
fields.description: www.euronews.com Toyota expects to treble its operating profit this year to the equivalent of more than 9.6 billion euros -- though that is still less than half what it made annually before the global financial crisis. Operating profit jumped more than five-fold in the first three months of the year with all production centres back up and running after last year's earthquake, tsunami and Thai floods disrupted supply chains and hit production. That cost Japan's top carmaker around 400000 vehicles in lost output - roughly nine weeks' worth of US sales. Find us on: Youtube bit.ly Facebook www.facebook.com Twitter twitter.com

fields.title: Floods and strong yen sink Toyota's profits
fields.description: www.euronews.net Toyota has more than halved its annual profit forecast. It has been cut to the equivalent of less than two billion euros because of the strong yen and flooding in Thailand that severed its supply lines. That, coupled with the Japanese earthquake and tsunami in March, meant Toyota has not been able to make enough cars. It is expected to be overtaken in sales this year by General Motors and probably Volkswagen

fields.title: 'Fission' scare hits Japan's crippled nuclear plant
fields.description: www.euronews.net A radioactive gas has been found at Japan's tsunami-hit Fukushima nuclear power plant, raising fresh fears over its safety. Xenon gas, which could be the result of nuclear fission, has been detected in the No 2 reactor. But analysts say there is unlikely to be any heightened risk of radiation.

fields.title: Flooding leaves several dead in Haiti
fields.description: Heavy rains causing mudslides and flooding have killed at least 23 people in Haiti at the very start of the Atlantic hurricane season. Most of those who died were in the capital, Port-au-Prince. Crowded slums and tent camps where thousands remain after losing their homes in last year's earthquake have been inundated.... www.euronews.net

fields.title: Japanese trade minister resigns over gaffe
fields.description: The Japanese Prime Minister's new government has suffered a blow after just eight days in office. As Yoshihiko Noda visited tsunami and quake-hit zones, news broke that his trade minister, Yoshio Hachiro, had resigned. This after Hachiro reportedly joked with a journalist about radiation from the devastated Fukushima plant.... www.euronews.net

fields.title: 'Heroes of Fukushima' win Spain's Asturias prize
fields.description: Spain's prestigious Prince of Asturias Concord prize has been awarded to Japanese workers who have been battling to stabilise the Fukushima nuclear plant, ravaged by the earthquake and tsunami in March. The jury said despite major uncertainty, the 'Heroes of Fukushima' carried on in extreme conditions, putting their lives in danger. Many workers became ill from radiation exposure but continued in their efforts to regain control of the reactors nonetheless. ... www.euronews.net

fields.title: UN to declare a famine in Somalia
fields.description: The UN is set to declare famine in parts of southern Somalia signalling donors need to provide more aid. The organisation's food agency is to host a meeting on the escalating humanitarian crisis on July 25 in Rome. More than 10 million people are affected by the devastating drought.... www.euronews.net

fields.title: Mexico takes stock after major quake
fields.description: www.euronews.com Mexico is counting the cost of a major earthquake that damaged buildings and infrastructure but did not cause any fatalities. Eleven people were injured. The 7.4 magnitude tremor rocked the capital, Mexico City, for more than one minute sending thousands panicking onto the streets. The quake hit hardest in the southwestern state of Guerrero, where around 800 houses were damaged, officials said. The tremor was one of the strongest to hit the country since the devastating 8.1-magnitude earthquake of 1985, which killed thousands in Mexico City. Mexico's interior ministry said the country would remain on high alert after 18 aftershocks to the quake were registered. Find us on: Youtube bit.ly Facebook www.facebook.com Twitter twitter.com

fields.title: Earthquake hits southern Peru
fields.description: www.euronews.net There has been little real damage and no deaths or injuries following an earthquake in Peru with a magnitude of 6.9. The epicentre was 50 kilometres off the coast of the southern city of Ica - the same area where a quake killed 500 people in 2007. This time, a few roads were blocked and mobile phone signal disrupted.

fields.title: UN asked to pay for Haitian cholera outbreak
fields.description: www.euronews.net The UN is being petitioned for compensation after being blamed for an outbreak of Cholera in the wake of the 2010 Haitian earthquake. A human rights group argues infected UN peacekeeping troops from Nepal, where cholera is endemic, were the source of the disease after dumping waste from their camp base into the local river.

fields.title: Radiation detected in Britain after Japan nuclear disaster
fields.description: As offiicals in Japan still battle around the clock to regain full control of the damaged nuclear plant in Fukushima - traces of radiation have been detected for the first time across Britain. Air samples taken in Glasgow and Oxfordshire have revealed very low levels of radioative iodine - indicating that the fall out from the nuclear disaster has spread more than 5000 miles. However health experts say there's no risk to the public, as our science correspondent Tom Clarke reports. .

fields.title: Japan tsunami sweeps car off road in Asahi - driver survives
fields.description: A Japanese man has been describing how he survived the moment the tsunami struck his car with the entire event captured on video. The man who isn't named describes in a telephone interview what happened when the enormous wave hit Asahi City in Chiba Prefecture: "When I came to the fishing port and turned the corner I could see the wall of water. At that moment I could do nothing else but keep driving. In the middle of that situation my car was taken by the wave.".

fields.title: Haitians can't 'get a break'

fields.title: 60 Minutes, 11.14.10
fields.description: While some complain about extracting natural gas from shale rock, others are getting wealthy; Also, conditions in Haiti after the earthquake helped to spread the water-borne infection cholera; Plus, the first living soldier to win the Medal of Honor since the Vietnam War.

fields.title: @katiecouric: Disaster in Haiti
fields.description: Katie Couric speaks with Mark Schneider from the International Crisis Group, and President of Partners in Health, Ophelia Dahl about the disastrous earthquake in Haiti and the relief efforts to help Haitians in need.

fields.title: Face the Nation, 03.13.11
fields.description: Bob Schieffer is joined by a team of CBS News correspondents on the ground all over Japan covering the fallout from the earthquake; Then, the chairman of the homeland security committee Sen. Joe Lieberman (D-Conn.) speaks upon what the US can learn about nuclear safety; Also, Bob Schiffer remembers Washington Post political reporter David Broder.

fields.title: Evening News Online, 03.11.11
fields.description: Friday: Japan suffered an 8.9 magnitude earthquake which caused a tsunami with up to 24-ft. waves; Then, The 8.9 magnitude earthquake off the coast of Japan triggered a tsunami which sent waves surging to Calif.; Also, New tapes have surfaced that detail the events that took place the day President Ronald Reagan was shot.

fields.title: Evening News Online, 03.12.11
fields.description: Saturday: The world is getting a closer look at the extent of the damage from the earthquake that hit Japan, as concerns mount over the possibility of a nuclear meltdown; Also, Qaddafi's forces are regaining control in key areas of Libya; And, the NFL's owners locked out its players, putting the next football season in jeopardy.

fields.title: Evening News Online, 08.15.10
fields.description: Sunday: Eight people were killed when truck plowed into race spectators at track in Calif.'s Mojave Desert; Also, authorities confirm the jailhouse death of the so-called "Craigslist killer" Philip Markoff; Plus, the UN secretary general visits Pakistan.

fields.title: Haiti: Frustration and Anger
fields.description: The earthquake made things in already-poor Haiti bad enough, but now a cholera epidemic is threatening to kill more Haitians, whose living conditions after the quake help to spread the water-borne infection. Byron Pitts reports.

fields.title: Sister cities after the tsunami
fields.description: The March tsunami destroyed the Japanese town of Otsuchi, but not its bond to the town of Fort Bragg, CA, which is determined to help save its sister. Bob Simon reports.

fields.title: Japan earthquake exceeded expectations
fields.description: Bob Schieffer spoke to a team of CBS News correspondents on the ground all over Japan covering the fallout from the earthquake, tsunami, and possible nuclear meltdown.

fields.title: May 25, 1960: Tsunami devastation in Hawaii
fields.description: From the CBS News archives: In May of 1960, the port city of Hilo, Hawaii was hit by huge tidal waves which killed many who ignored the warnings of an impending disaster. (No Audio)

fields.title: The Week In Haiti
fields.description: CBS News' Jeff Glor is in Haiti and provides a timeline of the events immediately after a devastating earthquake struck.

fields.title: How Japan's buildings differ from others
fields.description: Structural engineer Bill Faschan spoke with Lauren Wanko on how Japan's strict building codes potentially saved thousands of lives from a 9.0 magnitude earthquake and tsunami.

fields.title: Special Report: Obama on Haiti Relief
fields.description: As tens-of-thousands in Haiti wait for relief efforts to arrive, President Obama gives an update on what the United States is doing to help Haiti after the devastating earthquake.

fields.title: Haiti Recovery Effort

fields.title: Wyclef Jean Updates Haiti Relief Efforts
fields.description: Musician and philanthropist Wyclef Jean surprises Shira Lazar backstage at The Saturday Early Show to update how his Yele Haiti Earthquake Fund has been aiding relief efforts in Haiti after the devastating earthquake.

fields.title: The Early Show - Dr. Jill Biden: Fighting famine in Africa
fields.description: American educator and wife to Vice President Joe Biden, Dr. Jill Biden talks to Erica Hill about her recent visit to the Dadaab refugee complex in Kenya, and a new advertising campaign which encourages people to spread awareness of the famine and drought in the Horn of Africa.

fields.title: How To Help Haiti Quake Victims

fields.title: Trying to Keep Haiti Alive

fields.title: CBS News Looks Back at 2010
fields.description: A year ago, few people had ever heard of WikiLeaks and no one had an iPad. Gulf coast residents looked forward to a great summer and Democrats hoped to keep both houses of Congress. CBS News puts 2010 "In Focus" looking back at the some of the biggest news stories of the year.

fields.title: Clinton And Bush Join Forces For Haiti Relief
fields.description: Bob Schieffer spoke with former Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush who have joined forces in an effort to provide relief for those affected by Haiti's tragic earthquake.

fields.title: Disaster in Japan
fields.description: Cham Dallas, PhD, CBS News Nuclear Safety Consultant, discusses the latest on Japan's nuclear crisis.

fields.title: Haiti: The Long Road Back

fields.title: CBS Sunday Morning - Japan: One year after disaster
fields.description: The people of Japan today mark the first anniversary of the earthquake and tsunami that killed nearly 20000 and triggered the Fukushima nuclear meltdown. Correspondent Bill Whitaker visits some of those who continue to deal with the loss and devastation.

fields.title: Special Report: Obama on Quake Relief
fields.description: In a press conference following the devastating earthquake in Haiti, President Obama said American search teams are on their way to aid in rescue efforts.

fields.title: General In Haiti Says Worst Disaster He's Seen

fields.title: The Early Show - Top five world news stories of 2011

fields.title: Haiti: 'No Coordinated Efforts'

fields.title: Haiti: One Year Later

fields.title: Clinton Speaks in Haiti
fields.description: In Haiti, Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton discusses relief efforts for victims of the massive earthquake and stresses that America is here to help.

fields.title: How to Rebuild Haiti
fields.description: As the efforts to rebuild Haiti after a massive earthquake are barely underway, CBS News' Erica Hill speaks with crisis management expert Mark Ghilarducci about the best means for restoration.

fields.title: Surviving Haiti's Earthquake
fields.description: For five days, Jens Kristensen lived underneath the rubble of the United Nations headquarters in Haiti before he was rescued. CBS News anchor Michelle Gielan talked with Kristensen, Senior Humanitarian Officer with the UN Stabilization Mission in Haiti, about his experience via phone.

fields.title: Haiti, Three Months Later
fields.description: Three months after a devastating earthquake ravaged much of Haiti, Katie Couric returns to this island nation and reports on the ongoing progress of the prolonged restoration efforts there.

fields.title: Horn of Africa famine

fields.title: Race Against Time in Haiti
fields.description: A crammed airport in Haiti has led the FAA to temporarily stop American planes from entering Haiti. Katie Couric reports that coordinating the relief effort has become a monumental challenge.

fields.title: US Students Survive Quake

fields.title: Sean Penn on Haiti Since Quake
fields.description: Harry Smith spoke with actor Sean Penn about the relief organization he has helped build in Haiti over the last six months since the devastating earthquake.

fields.title: Somalia: Refugee crisis grows
fields.description: A massive drought in Somalia has sent hundreds of thousands of people across the border into Kenya. Erica Hill talks to Christopher Tidey, UNICEF spokesperson, about what it's like in the refugee camps.

fields.title: Japanese radiation reports "Not that bad"
fields.description: Michael Kloran, an American teacher living in Japan, spoke with Chris Wragge and Erica Hill on how the Japanese media and government are disseminating information about possible radiation exposure to the public.

fields.title: How close is Japan to a nuclear meltdown?
fields.description: CBS News Washington bureau chief Christopher Isham spoke Monday with Sharon Squassoni, a nuclear expert and fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, on how serious the threat of a nuclear meltdown is in Japan and if the disaster at Chernobyl could be repeated.

fields.title: Pakistan Oxfam Aid Worker: 'Very Desperate Situation'
fields.description: Jeff Glor talks to Oxfam aid worker, Ben Pickering, about the floods that are devastating Pakistan's Swat Valley.

fields.title: Japan copes with losses
fields.description: For more than a week, an anxious world has been watching as Japan struggled to get the upper hand first, against a natural disaster, then over a nuclear plant teetering on the brink of catastrophe. Bill Whitaker reports on Japan's efforts to cool the reactors at the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant and coping with the losses from the tsunami.

fields.title: Haiti's Medical Crisis
fields.description: More than three months after Haiti's earthquake, the country remains in a desperate medical crisis. Dr. Jon LaPook reports on the life-or-death dilemmas facing doctors there.

fields.title: Can radiation from Japan reach the West Coast?
fields.description: Chris Wragge talks to nuclear energy expert Cham Dallas and Dr. Jennifer Ashton about radiation fears spreading to the US West Coast.

fields.title: The Early Show - Tsunami debris washing up in US?
fields.description: Nearly 10 months after Japan's devastating tsunami, scientists say what may be some debris is starting to wash up on the US West Coast. Lee Cowan reports. Also, Oceanographer Dr. Curtis Ebbesmeyer joins to discuss.

fields.title: How to talk to your kids about Japan
fields.description: Erica Hill talks with psychologist and "Early Show" contributor Dr. Jennifer Hartstein about the ways that parents can address the events in Japan with their children.

fields.title: Third explosion at Fukushima; high radiation levels
fields.description: In Japan, fears of a nuclear disaster grew following a third explosion and fire at the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power plant. CBS News correspondent Harry Smith reports.

fields.title: Nuclear radiation found in Japan's food
fields.description: Bob Schieffer spoke with Rep. Ed Markey (D-Mass.) of the Energy and Commerce Committee on the viability of nuclear power in the United States after safety concerns arose from the meltdown at Japan's Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant.

fields.title: Haiti Ambassador on Disaster
fields.description: Katie Couric speaks with Raymond Alcide Joseph, the Haitian Ambassador to the US, about a recent earthquake which has caused severe damage and a potential disaster on the island nation.

fields.title: Hillary Clinton on Haiti Relief Effort
fields.description: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton described US relief efforts sent to Haiti by air and sea to provide aid for the thousands of homeless and injured victims of the 7.0 earthquake.

fields.title: Fukushima: How dangerous is it?
fields.description: Russ Mitchell interviews Ian Hore-Lacy, the director of public communications for the World Nuclear Association, an international organization that promotes nuclear power, about the dangers at the Fukushima power plant.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - School tragedy from tsunami
fields.description: Sunday marks the first anniversary of the devastating tsunami and earthquake in Japan. Bill Whitaker visits Ishinomaki, where a bad decision cost the lives of dozens of school students.

fields.title: Japan earthquake survivor: Situation remains unclear
fields.description: Russ Mitchell spoke with Matthew Alt, a survivor of the 8.9 magnitude earthquake in Japan, on what life was like before, during, and after the quake struck.

fields.title: UN Efforts Aid to Pakistan
fields.description: Monsoon-driven flood waters in Pakistan have killed more than 1600 people and left millions homeless. The United Nations is coordination the massive international relief effort that far exceeds the demand placed on it during the Haiti earthquake. Frank Ucciardo, Up to the Minute Contributor, sat down with the UN's Humanitarian Aid Chief, John Holmes, who just returned from Pakistan.

fields.title: The Face of Haitian Tragedy
fields.description: "CBS News RAW": Katie Couric grips the hand of 13-year-old earthquake victim, Pierre Larousse, whose family was killed in the devastating Haitian Earthquake.

fields.title: Tsunami blankets Japan coast
fields.description: CBS News RAW: An 8.9 magnitude earthquake triggered a tsunami that rolled into the Japanese port of Sendai, engulfing farmlands and carrying vehicles and buildings.

fields.title: Earthquake survivor: Panic created "a human stampede"
fields.description: Russ Mitchell talks to Japan quake survivor Ines Kljakovic who was in a busy Tokyo subway station where thousands of people were scrambling to reach the street level for safety.

fields.title: Somalia famine reaches historic proportions
fields.description: Scott Pelley reports from inside the Dadaab refugee camp where 400000 Somalis have taken refuge. They are fleeing famine in their country which has reached historic proportions, putting 3.7 million people at risk of starvation.

fields.title: American Couple Escaped Haiti
fields.description: Frank and Jillian Thorpe spoke about arriving in the US after experiencing the Haitian earthquake. Jillian Thorpe was trapped in building rubble when her husband Frank came to her rescue.

fields.title: Sanger: Japan earthquake may lead to economic stimulus
fields.description: Bob Schieffer, joined by David Sanger of the New York Times and CBS News' David Martin, analyze the latest in Japan from the effects of a possible nuclear meltdown, the disaster relief the US is sending over, and how credible the facts are coming from the Japanese government.

fields.title: Caught on Tape: Tsunami hits Japan port town
fields.description: New video released shows the moment when the tsunami hit a small Japanese port town.

fields.title: Photos salvaged from tsunami ruins in Japan
fields.description: One year after the devastating tsunami in Japan, conservationists are collecting photographs left behind in the debris. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: Haitians Struggle To Find Hope One Year Later
fields.description: On the ground in Port-au-Prince, CBS News' Randall Pinkston gives Bill Plante a live look from the ground as relief is slow even one year after the devastating earthquake in Haiti.

fields.title: Energy from quake: if harnessed, could power LA for a year
fields.description: Dr. Marcia McNutt, the director of the US Geological Survey puts the power of earthquakes into perspective and talks to Rebecca Jarvis about what to expect in the aftermath of one of the most powerful earthquakes ever recorded.

fields.title: Erica Hill inside Kenyan refugee camp
fields.description: The worst drought in 60 years is sending more than a thousand people a day across the border from Somalia to Kenya. Erica Hill reports from Dadaab, Kenya with a first-hand look at the region's growing desperation.

fields.title: Fukushima plant fire stokes fear and confusion in public
fields.description: Harry Smith reports from Tokyo with the latest on the nuclear radiation threat stemming from the Fukushima nuclear power plant.

fields.title: Quake Zones Most at Risk
fields.description: Dr. Arthur Lerner-Lam, a seismologist at Columbia University, shows Chris Wragge some of the geographical zones most at risk of an earthquake.

fields.title: Chileans Cope, Awaiting Aid
fields.description: Chileans await aid while small towns wiped out by the tsunami struggle to bury their dead, reports Mark Strassman.

fields.title: Tsunami currents crash Calif. boats
fields.description: CBS News RAW: Boats in Santa Cruz, Calif. are pushed around and pulled out to sea by a strong current caused by tsunami waves that traveled from Japan. A magnitude 8.9 earthquake shook the country and triggered a tsunami.

fields.title: Japan's nuclear power plant: What went wrong?
fields.description: Professor Cham Dallas of the University of Georgia, an expert on nuclear energy, walked Chris Wragge through what exactly went wrong with the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power station in Japan which experienced a partial meltdown.

fields.title: AK Woman: Surviving Haiti's Disaster
fields.description: Christa Brelsford, a literacy volunteer from Alaska, spoke to Maggie Rodriguez about surviving the disaster in Haiti and her memory of being trapped under a collapsed building.

fields.title: The Plan For Haiti
fields.description: CBS News' David Martin reports on efforts by American military to combat the devastation following last week's earthquake in Haiti.

fields.title: Haiti Attempts Normalcy
fields.description: Twelve days after a catastrophic 7.0 earthquake ravaged Haiti, an odd sense of normalcy is settling in. Bill Whitaker has the story.

fields.title: 'Hard to be Any Age' in Haiti
fields.description: Dave Price toured the wreckage in Port-Au-Prince, Haiti with a 12-year-old girl living in the devastated area. Despite the tragic situation, the girl is hopeful and does not want to leave Haiti.

fields.title: Wife of Fukushima nuclear plant worker: Waiting and worried
fields.description: Rebecca Jarvis interviews Janie Eudy, the wife of an American worker at the Fukushima nuclear power plant, who is waiting for word from her husband that he is okay following today's explosion.

fields.title: Quake Victims Fight To Live
fields.description: After struggling with unsanitary conditions and a lack of food, water or shelter, survivors of the earthquake in Haiti are growing desperate. Katie Couric reports from Port-au-Prince.

fields.title: Survivor: Japan fears meltdown, residents moving south
fields.description: Erica Hill and Chris Wragge spoke with Aaron Lace, a survivor of the earthquake in Japan, who shared his experience escaping from a theater as its roof collapsed.

fields.title: Homeless Haitians Await Aid
fields.description: As tens of thousands of Haitians remain homeless in Port-au-Prince, Jeff Glor reports on desperate residents who wait for relief efforts to arrive with food, water and medical care.

fields.title: Haiti Aid: Life Changing Experience
fields.description: University of Miami School of Medicine's Dr. Barth Green spoke to Harry Smith about the relief effort to aid the Haiti earthquake victims and being part of the first medical teams in Port-au-Prince.

fields.title: Radiation leak fears rise
fields.description: Erica Hill speaks with the Carnegie Endowment Nuclear Policy Program's James Acton about the risk of radiation poisoning for Japanese residents living near fragile nuclear plants.

fields.title: Social Networking in Haiti
fields.description: Broadcasters, journalists and relief workers in Haiti are turning to social networking sites like Twitter and Facebook to get in contact with each other as normal means of communication are, at times, rendered useless. Daniel Sieberg reports.

fields.title: Pakistan Foreign Minister on Crisis
fields.description: Katie Couric interviews Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mehmood Qureshi about the humanitarian crisis in his country in the wake of the devastating floods.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Japan: one year after the quake and tsunami
fields.description: It's close to a year since the massive earthquake and tsunami rocked Japan, killing close to 800 people. Bill Whitaker takes a look back at the disaster and one man who lost everything.

fields.title: Second Quake Hits Indonesia
fields.description: Sumatra Island was stuck by a second earthquake in two days, Kelly Cobiella reports. The search for Tsunami victims continues in the Samoan Island after a Tsunami struck the area, Michael Moore reports.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Fukushima a no-man's land
fields.description: One year after the earthquake and tsunami, Japan is still dealing with the nuclear disaster after three reactors melted down and released dangerous levels of radiation. Bill Whitaker reports from the forbidden zone.

fields.title: Crucial power cable connected at Japan's nuclear plant
fields.description: One week after damaged nuclear reactors began leaking radiation, workers at Japan's Fukushima nuclear power plant have connected a power cable needed to restart the cooling systems. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: Japan earthquake eyewitness interview
fields.description: Erica Hill talks to Tokyo resident, Matt Alt about the 8.9 earthquake that struck Japan.

fields.title: Haiti Six Months After Quake
fields.description: Of the 1.5 million Haitians displaced by the earthquake, it's estimated that fewer than 30000 have moved into permanent housing. Seth Doane reports from Port-au-Prince.

fields.title: Starvation crisis in Somalia
fields.description: A drought in the horn of Africa has destroyed crops for more than a year, putting 12 million people at risk of starvation. Scott Pelley speaks with New York Times photojournalist Tyler Hicks about his remarkable pictures.

fields.title: Is the US prepared for an earthquake?
fields.description: The devastating events in Japan are raising questions about the safety of the US in the event of our own earthquake. Daniel Sieberg reports on how America's preparedness stacks up to Japan.

fields.title: Conflicting reports on Japan crisis
fields.description: Conflicting reports and mixed messages are coming out of Japan as workers race to cool its nuclear reactors ahead of a possible meltdown. Harry Smith has the latest developments from Tokyo.

fields.title: Haiti's Son Provides Hope
fields.description: People in Haiti know they'll be cleaning up a natural disaster for years if not decades. Pierre Garcon, a wide receiver for the Indianapolis Colts, has been one source of hope for the country following January's earthquake, CBS News Correspondent Jeff Glor reports.

fields.title: Earthquake scientist on Japan quake and tsunami
fields.description: Chris Wragge talks to earthquake scientist, Lucy Jones of the US Geological Survey about the earthquake in Japan, the risks of aftershocks and the dangers of tsunamis.

fields.title: Aftershocks Rock Haiti
fields.description: Millions may be affected by the strongest quake to hit Haiti, one of the world's poorest countries, in 200 years as aftershocks continue to hit, reports Kelly Cobiella.

fields.title: Haiti builds state-of-the-art teaching hospital
fields.description: Two years after an earthquake devastated Haiti, citizens there are laying the foundation of one of the largest, most sophisticated projects in the country - a state-of-the-art teaching hospital. Dr. Jon LaPook speaks with Dr. Paul Farmer about the change it will bring.

fields.title: How to help Japan quake survivors and not get scammed
fields.description: CBS News business and economics correspondent Rebecca Jarvis talks to Erica Hill about how make sure you're donating to reputable charities and not falling prey to scammers.

fields.title: Medical Efforts 'Chaotic'
fields.description: Dr. Jennifer Ashton reports from Port-au-Prince, Haiti on the difficult task of caring for the wounded survivors from the earthquake on this Early Show Health Watch.

fields.title: Somalia's growing humanitarian crisis
fields.description: The worst drought in half a century has millions across the Horn of Africa facing famine. Erica Hill talks to William Spindler, UNHCR's chief press officer for the latest on the dire situation.

fields.title: Nuke expert: "This is only the very beginning" of disaster
fields.description: Erica Hill talks to CBS News nuclear safety consultant Cham Dallas about the next steps to be taken in trying to contain the disaster at the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power plant.

fields.title: Dadaab refugee camp functions like town
fields.description: Every week, more than 5000 refugees cross the border from Somalia into Kenya's Dadaab refugee camp, the largest in the world. Erica Hill reports on what life is like in the 20-year-old camp.

fields.title: Explosion and smoke plumes at Japanese nuclear plant
fields.description: Nancy Cordes has the latest on the explosion at the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power station in Japan.

fields.title: Quake's economic impact
fields.description: Erica Hill talks to CBS News business and economics correspondent Rebecca Jarvis about the uncertainty over the economy due to the effects of the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear issues.

fields.title: Relief Services Face Challenges
fields.description: Head of Catholic Relief Services Karel Zalenka spoke to Harry Smith about the huge challenges faced by aid organizations in Haiti.

fields.title: The CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Secretary Clinton on Somalia famine
fields.description: Scott Pelley speaks with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton about the Somali famine emergency and the role of the US in the relief effort.

fields.title: Are America's nuclear power plants safe?
fields.description: John Blackstone examines the US nuclear power plants located along fault lines after safety concerns arose when a 9.0 magnitude earthquake ruptured the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power station in Japan, causing a partial meltdown.

fields.title: Critical Days for Haitian Victims
fields.description: Dr. Jennifer Ashton spoke to Harry Smith about the medical crisis in Haiti, the essential needs of earthquake victims and the critical days for trapped survivors.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Two years after quake, Haiti in dire straits
fields.description: Despite incredible generosity towards Haiti following the earthquake that hit the country two years ago, the lack of systems to channel the money in an effective way has held up the progress to rebuild the nation. Dr. Jon LaPook reports.

fields.title: CBS This Morning - Japan tsunami debris: How scientists track it
fields.description: Environmental advocate Philippe Cousteau, president of EarthEcho International, speaks to the "CBS This Morning" co-hosts about how scientists are tracking the Japan tsunami debris, as well as its potential impact on the environment.

fields.title: Japan's desperate measures to cool nuclear plant
fields.description: The reactors at Japan's Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant damaged by the earthquake and tsunami were bombarded with water from helicopters to try to cool them off and prevent a meltdown. Bill Whitaker reports that it is not clear these desperate measures will work.

fields.title: White House's Haiti Response
fields.description: CBS News' Lara Logan reports on US President Barack Obama and his administration's handling of the global disaster relief efforts which are now underway in the earthquake-ravaged Haiti.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Japanese tsunami-ravaged hospital still struggling
fields.description: Sunday marks the first anniversary of the powerful earthquake and tsunami in Japan. Bill Whitaker reports on one small hospital still barely getting by after being nearly washed away.

fields.title: Japan: Nuclear disaster overshadows earthquake and tsunami
fields.description: Bill Whitaker reports from Japan on the latest problems stemming from the nuclear disaster at the Fukushima Dai-ichi power plant, including the evacuation of workers from one of the reactors and the discovery of radiation in the food supply.

fields.title: Aftershocks Eerie and Surreal
fields.description: Harry Smith spoke to communications director of World Vision Magalie Boyer from Port-au-prince, Haiti with her account from the disaster stricken city.

fields.title: Large-scale relief effort underway in Japan
fields.description: Search and rescue teams from 13 countries are converging on Northeast Japan in an attempt to save any survivors after a 9.0 magnitude earthquake and subsequent tsunami hit the country. Lucy Craft reports.

fields.title: UN Copes with Haiti Earthquake
fields.description: Frank Ucciardo, Up to the Minute Contributor, examines how the United Nations is reacting to the Earthquake in Haiti.

fields.title: Progress in Haiti 1 Year Later
fields.description: One year after Haiti's devastating earthquake, many Haitians are still living in tent cities in the hills above Port-au-Prince. Bill Whitaker reports on the latest in the rebuild effort.

fields.title: Aerial shots show Japan earthquake destruction
fields.description: Days after the devastating earthquake in Japan, damage can be seen for miles at a stretch over Sendai, Japan. It is being estimated that nearly 10000 people may have died in the quake and subsequent tsunami. No Audio.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - A rare look inside Japan's evacuation zone
fields.description: The Japanese government has started an ambitious clean-up effort to make the area around the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant safe for humans to return. Lucy Craft got a rare look inside the project.

fields.title: Japan struggles with earthquake, tsunami cleanup
fields.description: Months after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, Japan is still struggling to clear the debris. Lucy Craft reports on the latest details in the country's cleanup effort.

fields.title: CBS Evening News - Radiation threats linger over Japan's food supply
fields.description: The damaged nuclear power plant in Japan came closer to a full meltdown than first thought. Lucy Craft reports that citizens continue to live with the threat of radioactive contamination in their food.

fields.title: Japan crisis raises concerns over California plant
fields.description: The continuing nuclear crisis at Fukushima's nuclear complex in Japan has raised concerns over the San Onofre plant in San Clemente, Calif. Terry McCarthy reports on San Onofre's history of problems.

fields.title: Japan's nuclear plant explosions explained
fields.description: As Japan fights to prevent mounting problems at Fukushima's power complex, Katie Couric reports on how nuclear reactors work and what went wrong when the quake struck the plant.

fields.title: Grief Unites Haitian-Americans
fields.description: Over 800000 Haitians living in the US are now bound by the tragedy which has hit their native land. As Randall Pinkston reports, many have been united in an effort to contact relatives.

fields.title: Sendai still without water, phone service
fields.description: In wake of the massive earthquake and resulting tsunami, Bill Whitaker reports on the conditions in Sendai, the big city in Japan located closest to the earthquake's epicenter.

fields.title: Earthquake's economic impact
fields.description: Chris Wragge talks to Jill Schlesinger, editor-at-large for CBS Moneywatch.com about how Japan's 8.9 earthquake could affect the world economy.

fields.title: Haiti: From Rescue to Recovery
fields.description: CBS News' Jeff Glor reports from the Haitian capital of Port-au-Prince, four days after a devastating earthquake left most of this area in rubble, as rescue operations turns to a recovery mission.

fields.title: Intel Leaks Plague Military
fields.description: A flood of documents released by the WikiLeaks web site show multitude problems in the war in Afghanistan. David Martin reports on one finding that suggests a link between Pakistan intelligence and the Taliban.

fields.title: Life-Saving Efforts Continue
fields.description: Throughout Haiti's ordeal, there have been remarkable life-saving efforts by medical teams from all over the world. But as Dr. Jennifer Ashton reports from Haiti, each day brings a new medical crisis.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Report: Tsunami put Japanese leadership in disarray
fields.description: A scathing report shows in the hours after the tsunami struck the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, authorities were helpless to address the situation, reports Lucy Craft.

fields.title: The Early Show - Lanterns fly in Japan to honor Tsunami victims
fields.description: Hundreds of lanterns were released in Japan's Fukushima Prefecture to mark the half-year anniversary of the massive earthquake and tsunami that devastated the country. The ceremony was held only 24 miles from the radiation-leaking Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.

fields.title: LAFD joins USAID rescue effort in Japan
fields.description: CBS News RAW: Los Angeles Fire Department search and rescue team joined the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) on the ground in Ofunato, Japan.

fields.title: Pras Michel Aids Relief Effort
fields.description: Award winning musician and Haitian-American Pras Michel along with cousin Wyclef Jean and family spearhead relief efforts for the earthquake in Haiti.

fields.title: Japan's Sendai near quake epicenter, hit hard
fields.description: In wake of the tsunami and earthquake that struck Japan, Bill Whitaker reports on conditions in hard-hit Sendai, located near the epicenter of the magnitude nine earthquake.

fields.title: Well Wishes for Clinton
fields.description: Maggie Rodriguez spoke with former DNC chairman Terry McAuliffe about former President Clinton's heart procedure and his continuing efforts in Haiti.

fields.title: Sendai in need of aid
fields.description: In the devastated city of Sendai, located closest to the earthquake's epicenter, residents are short of just about everything from food to gas. Bill Whitaker reports on international aid and how residents are helping each other.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Disabled Haitian helps others back on their feet
fields.description: Three days after the earthquake that struck Haiti, Shelove Julmiste was told her crushed leg would have to be amputated. She thought she would never walk again. Now two years later, Shelove is running Haiti's first rehab program and helping people get back on their feet. Whit Johnson reports.

fields.title: Tsunami surges across Pacific, batters Calif. coast
fields.description: The 8.9 magnitude earthquake off the coast of Japan triggered a tsunami which sent waves surging on all the way to California, destroying harbors and wrecking boats. John Blackstone reports.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Japan observes tsunami's one year anniversary
fields.description: One year ago a powerful earthquake and tsunami struck Japan leaving nearly 20000 dead or missing. Bill Whitaker visited some of the country's observances in some of the hardest hit cities of all.

fields.title: Thousands work to clean up Fukushima plant
fields.description: For the nearly two thousand workers trying to clean up Japan's crippled nuclear power plant in Fukushima, lending a helping hand is a highly personal mission. Lucy Craft reports.

fields.title: Record Donations from US
fields.description: Americans are donating now more than ever, as the recent crisis in Haiti has shown. Chris Wragge speaks with Manuel Gallegus about the texting craze and how this helps with the aid efforts.

fields.title: Japan's radiation exposure risks
fields.description: Dr. Jennifer Ashton spoke with Erica Hill on who is most at risk of radiation exposure after Japan's Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power station experienced a partial meltdown.

fields.title: Fukushima radiation levels fall, nuke crisis continues
fields.description: In Japan, people feel besieged from all directions and tensions over a nuclear emergency remain high. Harry Smith reports on the latest of the nuclear crisis in Japan.

fields.title: Japanese suspicious of government, TEOCO
fields.description: As officials cope with Japan's worst nuclear accident, Japanese people are growing more suspicious of the government and the Tokyo Electric Power Company's truthfulness. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: The Early Show - Japan's tsunami: Six months later
fields.description: Almost six months after the devastating earthquake and tsunami in Japan, Lucy Craft takes a look back at the sense of civic cooperation that helped Japanese victims survive.

fields.title: Possible meltdown fuels Japan's nuclear power debate
fields.description: Russ Mitchell spoke with CBS News correspondent Lucy Craft who has been in Japan since the 8.9 magnitude earthquake struck Japan and details the latest on reports of large amounts of radiation spewing out of the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power station.

fields.title: From Disaster to Donations
fields.description: From coast to coast, Americans nationwide are opening their wallets for survivors in Haiti who face the harrowing aftermath of an earthquake. Randall Pinkston reports on these charitable efforts.

fields.title: Rare Earthquake Hits Haiti
fields.description: About 90 percent of the world's earthquakes strike inside the "ring of fire," which is a 25000 mile stretch of ocean trenches and volcanoes. Haiti's earthquake was rare, but expected. Ben Tracy reports.

fields.title: New setbacks for Japan's damaged nuclear power plant
fields.description: A mysterious and serious setback prompted workers to evacuate Japan's Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear plant and once again stopped efforts to stabilize the plant. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: Japan's nuclear crisis on par with Chernobyl
fields.description: One day after Japan expanded the evacuation zone around the Fukushima Dai-ichi power plant, the severity of the crisis was raised to the highest level - the same as the Chernobyl crisis.

fields.title: Horn of Africa region close to famine, UN says
fields.description: Tony Guida takes a look at the humanitarian crisis in the Horn of Africa, where people are facing the worst drought in 60 years, massacres by Islamic militants and skyrocketing food prices.

fields.title: The danger of old US nuclear plants
fields.description: The nuclear emergency in Japan is raising questions about the safety older nuclear reactors in the US with same design as at Fukushima. John Blackstone reports on the dangers of the 23 reactors still operational in America.

fields.title: Fukushima came close to complete meltdown
fields.description: A new report shows that the meltdown at Japan's Fukushima Dai-ichi power plant, triggered by the earthquake and tsunami, was much worse than originally thought. Lucy Craft details how close Fukushima came to a total catastrophe.

fields.title: CBS This Morning - Japan tsunami debris nearing US shores
fields.description: The floating debris from Japan's devastating tsunami is now halfway across the Pacific Ocean, and scientists expect some of it to reach Hawaii in the next couple of weeks. John Blackstone reports on the impact of the debris on US shores.

fields.title: Japan's survival staples in short supply
fields.description: Japanese citizens rush to the stores to stock up on survival supplies fearing a possible nuclear meltdown and radiation stemming from the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. Lucy Craft reports.

fields.title: Japan gov't expands Fukushima evacuation zone
fields.description: As radiation levels continue to rise near Fukushima's nuclear plant, Japan's government has acknowledged that more towns need to be evacuated outside the 20-mile evacuation zone. Lucy Craft reports.

fields.title: Video from inside Fukushima Daiichi reactor
fields.description: CBS News Raw: TEPCO (Tokyo Electric Power Company) released video of Fukushima Daiichi's reactor one captured by US-made robot, "packbot." The video reveals no water leaks, however radiation levels are higher than were anticipated.

fields.title: Haiti Quake Predicted?
fields.description: US scientists warned in 2008 that Port-au-Prince was ripe for an earthquake, but they didn't know it would strike less than two years later. Ben Tracy reports on this code of earthquake predictions.

fields.title: 100 days since Japan quake
fields.description: It was 100 days ago that the deadly earthquake and tsunami struck Japan. More than 100000 citizens there are still without a permanent home. Lucy Craft reports on what life is like for those living in a homeless shelter in Kazo, Japan.

fields.title: Hope Fades for Trapped Survivors
fields.description: Hope is starting to fade for trapped survivors of the massive earthquake in Haiti. Many rescue teams say that the first 72 hours are the most crucial in aiding victims. Kelly Cobiella reports.

fields.title: Rescuing Haiti's Orphans
fields.description: The most painful pictures of all from Haiti are those of suffering children. As Manuel Gallegus reports, Americans who've been trying to adopt Haitian orphans want to speed up the process.

fields.title: Japan's post-quake humanitarian efforts
fields.description: Workers at the stricken nuclear power plant in Japan continue to pump radioactive water into the sea which is just one small step on the long road to getting the plant under control. Lucy Craft reports on how Japan is dealing with the humanitarian aftermath from the disaster.

fields.title: Haiti's Day of Prayer
fields.description: It has been another day of struggle for the survivors of the Haitian earthquake, but many are still living due to acts of mercy by relief workers. It has also been a day of prayer. Jeff Glor has the story.

fields.title: Haiti Man Rescued Month After Quake
fields.description: One month after the devastating earthquake in Haiti, survivors are still picking up the pieces. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: Haitian orphans thrive in American household
fields.description: After the earthquake in Haiti, Americans adopted more than a thousand young victims. Cynthia Bowers profiles a family in Washington State who took in three more children.

fields.title: Practice drills saved lives in Japan
fields.description: The town of Koizumi, Japan was wiped off the map by the tsunami, but, thanks to practice drills, only 42 people are missing or dead. As Lucy Craft reports, the neighboring town of Minamisanriku was not so lucky.

fields.title: Potential nuclear reactor breach expands evacuation zone
fields.description: The voluntary evacuation zone around the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan was expanded from 12 to 19 miles amidst fears of a possible breach at one of the reactors. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: Pandang Hospitals Overflowing
fields.description: Hospitals in the city of Pandang, Indonesia are overflowing with victims injured in last week's earthquake. As Celia Hatton reports, some patients were even forced to sleep outside.

fields.title: Millions could starve in Somalia famine
fields.description: A famine is putting millions of Somalis at risk for starving. Hundreds of thousands have fled across the border to Kenya. Scott Pelley speaks about the desperate situation with William Spindler , the UN High Commissioner for refugees in Kenya.

fields.title: Radioactive water leak slowed at Fukushima plant
fields.description: Workers at Japan's damaged Fukushima nuclear complex have managed to slow down the leak of radioactive water into the Pacific Ocean. Celia Hatton reports.

fields.title: Harry Smith on Japan town: "There is only ruin"
fields.description: More than half of the 20000 residents of Minamisanriku, Japan, are listed as missing or unaccounted for. Harry Smith reports from the hard-hit seaside resort town.

fields.title: Japan earthquake aftermath
fields.description: Ben Tracy reports from Tokyo on the aftermath of a magnitude nine earthquake and resulting tsunami that hit Japan and the massive trail of destruction left behind.

fields.title: 7.0 Quake Rocks Haiti
fields.description: The island nation of Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere with one of the weakest infrastructures, now faces near-catastrophic damage from an earthquake. Seth Doane reports.

fields.title: Haitians Turn to Looting
fields.description: CBS News RAW: In Port-au-Prince, Haiti, citizens are turning to looting in a desperate attempt to obtain supplies, security officials are working to prevent the illegal activity.

fields.title: More Aid Needed for Haiti
fields.description: While over two and a half billion dollars in contributions have already been raised in Haiti, Byron Pitts reports that the UN has brought world leaders together to raise additional funds.

fields.title: Is the US at risk from Japan's nuclear radiation?
fields.description: Radioactive plumes from Japan's Fukushima plant are expected to reach the West Coast of the US Health officials insist there's no danger to the US or Pacific territories. Dr. Sanjay Gupta reports.

fields.title: Survivors struggle in Japan
fields.description: Almost two weeks after disaster struck Japan, thousands of displaced survivors are still struggling to find adequate food, water and shelter in the face of disease and radiation scares. Lucy Craft reports from Tokyo.

fields.title: Could US nuclear plants survive earthquake?
fields.description: CBS News chief White House correspondent Chip Reid asked Nuclear Regulatory Commission Chairman Gregory Jaczko Monday if nuclear plants in the US could withstand earthquakes of the same magnitude that recently hit Japan. Jaczko and Dan Poneman, a deputy secretary of energy, took questions at the White House daily press briefing with Jay Carney.

fields.title: Inside Nature's Fury
fields.description: Given recurrent media coverage of catastrophic earthquakes, floods and other global natural disasters, Ben Tracy investigates the science and myths behind the ferocity of Mother Nature.

fields.title: Donor Fatigue in Pakistan Relief Effort
fields.description: Over the last few weeks, 20 million people in Pakistan have been affected by the worst flooding in that nation's history. But unlike previous disasters, relief for Pakistan may not be in sight. Richard Roth reports.

fields.title: Aid Arrives, Search Continues
fields.description: Thousands of US military personnel are now in Haiti helping those in need. As Jeff Glor reports, tons of relief supplies have arrived and the search continues for victims under the rubble.

fields.title: Japan's resilient survivors
fields.description: The Japanese city of Rikuzen Takata was almost wiped off the map by last month's tsunami, leaving nearly half of its 23000 residents homeless. Lucy Craft reports on the resilience of the city's survivors.

fields.title: Samoa Death Toll May Rise
fields.description: At least 150 people were killed in the tsunami that hit the Samoas two days ago. But, the death toll may rise as the search for bodies continues. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: Pakistan Flood Waters Reaching South
fields.description: As the flood waters in Pakistan reach the south, most villagers fled, joining an estimated 4 million other people who are desperate for food, water and shelter. Mandy Clark reports.

fields.title: Japanese Nuke Plant Scare
fields.description: Radiation levels outside a nuclear plant in Japan surged to eight times the normal level. Eleven of Japan's nuclear reactors were in the earthquake zone. Nancy Cordes reports.

fields.title: CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Japan's tsunami debris to hit US shores
fields.description: Oceanographers met in Hawaii to discuss when and where the millions of tons of debris from Japan's tsunami will wash ashore in North America. John Blackstone reports.

fields.title: Haitians Line Streets En Masse
fields.description: Many survivors of the recent earthquake in Haiti, which left the nation in a state of disaster and chaos, are now homeless and living in the streets without food or adequate shelter. Jeff Glor reports.

fields.title: Aid Efforts Bringing in Millions
fields.description: Rapidly organized efforts to help Haiti have brought in millions of dollars in cash, food, water and medicine. From corporations to celebrities, people giving what they can. Randall Pinkston reports.

fields.title: Harry Smith on Japan: Looks like it had been bombed
fields.description: Harry Smith reports from the ground in Minamisanriku, Japan, which was one of the hardest hit towns by the 9.0 magnitude earthquake.

fields.title: Extra: Child Trafficking
fields.description: Marie De La Soudiere is coordinating UNICEF's efforts to protect Haiti's vulnerable children.

fields.title: Samoan Tsunami Aftermath
fields.description: President Obama has declared American Samoa a disaster area, after a powerful earthquake in the region trigged a tsunami which destroyed many homes and businesses. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: CBS This Morning - Inside tsunami-proof "Noah's Ark"
fields.description: While in Japan, covering the one-year anniversary of the devastating earthquake and tsunami, Bill Whitaker took a trip inside a water-proof pod invented to protect a family from an incoming tsunami.

fields.title: Seismologist: Japan earthquake magnitude 'unusual'
fields.description: Katie Couric spoke with Dr. Lucy Jones, a seismologist with the US Geological Survey, on Japan's 8.9 magnitude earthquake and tsunami.

fields.title: Miracle rescue 9 days after Japan earthquake
fields.description: As Japan's nuclear safety agency says pressure is again rising in one of the reactors at the country's tsunami damaged nuclear complex at Fukushima, Lucy Craft reports of a dramatic rescue and stories of refuge.

fields.title: Japan's nuclear meltdown worries
fields.description: Workers at the Fukushima nuclear complex are trying to restore power and prevent the worst case -- a meltdown. Celia Hatton reports on what some Japanese are calling "Japan's Chernobyl."

fields.title: Earthquake Cripples Indonesia
fields.description: Rescue workers in Indonesia are desperately attempting to save thousands of residents who may be trapped under rubble after a 7.6 quake left behind mass devastation. Celia Hatton reports.

fields.title: Help On the Way
fields.description: The US military has begun a massive relief effort for Haiti and up to 5500 US troops are expected within days. CBS News' David Martin reports.

fields.title: Desperation Throughout Haiti
fields.description: Residents in Haitian cities are desperate for food and water as confusion and chaos spreads. Even in this disaster, Haitian people say they must be strong and move on. Kelly Cobiella reports.

fields.title: Wyclef Jean Gives Aid in Haiti
fields.description: Hip-hop artist Wyclef Jean visited his native Haiti to pass out hot meals in one of the poorest sections in Port-au-Prince. Bill Whitaker reports on the relief and recovery from the earthquake.

fields.title: 82nd Airborne's Mission in Haiti
fields.description: The mission of the 82nd Airborne in Haiti is a round-the-clock operation that includes food distribution, aiding the injured and sick and providing much-needed security. Bill Whitaker reports.

fields.title: Earthquake Zones Most At Risk
fields.description: In the wake of a devastating earthquake in Chile, CBS News' Bill Whitaker reports that there are some locations even in the US which are at risk due to potentially-disastrous seismic activity.

fields.title: The CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - What's behind the rare East Coast quake?
fields.description: Scott Pelley speaks with US Geological Survey seismologist Lucy Jones about the 5.8-magnitude earthquake that shook up millions from Georgia to New England.

fields.title: US, World Bank Rush to Aid Pakistan
fields.description: The World Bank released $900 million dollars in flood relief for Pakistan. The US is also rushing to help, both for humanitarian as well as strategic reasons. Richard Roth reports.

fields.title: Radiation threatens future of Fukushima farms
fields.description: The threat of radiation contamination is causing skepticism about the safety of food produced in Japan. And, as Lucy Craft reports, Fukushima farmers are concerned for their future.

fields.title: US Leading Aid Effort for Pakistan
fields.description: Floodwaters the size of Italy have killed more than 1500 people in Pakistan. As Richard Roth reports, the UN secretary general said the damage was the worst disaster he had ever seen.

fields.title: Radioactive water, plutonium found near Fukushima
fields.description: As the humanitarian crisis continues in Japan, more highly radioactive water was found near Fukushima's nuclear plant and soil samples reveal trace amounts of plutonium. Lucy Craft reports on the latest details.

fields.title: Small town residents in floodwaters' path
fields.description: CBS News national correspondent Dean Reynolds reports on the intentional flooding caused by the opening of the Morganza spillway and the people about to be affected by it.

fields.title: Quake survivors' desperate search for loved ones
fields.description: Thousands of survivors of the 8.9 magnitude earthquake in Japan are now on a desperate search for relatives and friends. Ben Tracy reports.

fields.title: Search for Indonesia Quake Survivors
fields.description: After back-to-back earthquakes shook Indonesia, rescue efforts are underway for survivors. Celia Hatton reports.

fields.title: Obstacles to Haiti Relief Effort
fields.description: As many as 10000 American military personnel are expected to be on the ground in Haiti or nearby offshore. David Martin reports on the logistical challenges that are hampering the relief effort.

fields.title: Japan tsunami heads toward US
fields.description: A Tsunami warning has been issued for the west coast of the US and Hawaii after a 8.9 magnitude quake devastated Japan. As Jeff Glor reports, the quake is the largest recorded in Japanese history.

fields.title: Japan: The staggering numbers
fields.description: Erica Hill takes a look at the numbers to offer some perspective on the images of destruction from the earthquake and tsunami in Japan.

fields.title: Sake sales boosting Japanese economy
fields.description: Shop owners in Japan have seen a boost in sales of sake after the disastrous tsunami devastated the economy one-year-ago. Monica Villamizar reports.

fields.title: Financial impact of Japan earthquake, tsunami
fields.description: Just days after the earthquake and tsunami struck Japan, the financial repercussions are starting to surface. Lucy Craft reports on the financial impact of the catastrophe in Japan.

fields.title: Obama personally "heartbroken" over Japan quake
fields.description: President Obama, during his news conference Friday, opened up about his personal feelings toward the earthquake in Japan and noted that he is heartbroken, especially as someone who grew up in Hawaii, which has strong ties to Japanese culture.

fields.title: China, Pakistan Desperate for Aid
fields.description: The US military ordered a dozen more helicopters to help Pakistan with the worst floods they've seen in 80 years. As Celia Hatton reports, aid is also needed in China where a separate disaster is unfolding.

fields.title: Japan town nearly wiped off map by tsunami
fields.description: Three days after the massive earthquake and tsunami, Ben Tracy reports on conditions on the small deserted town of Natori near the quake's epicenter, once home to 74000 people.

fields.title: Japan officials: Nuclear complex nearing meltdown
fields.description: Officials in Japan have admitted that seven damaged reactors at Fukushima's nuclear complex are on the edge of a possible meltdown. Celia Hatton reports on the latest details.

fields.title: Haiti quake amputee soccer team meets military vets
fields.description: Team Zaryean from Haiti is mostly made up of victims of the 2010 earthquake and they traveled to Washington, DC to play a friendly game with amputee military vets. WUSA-TV's Lindsey Mastis reports.

fields.title: Search for missing American teacher in Japan
fields.description: The family of 24-year-old American English teacher Taylor Anderson continues to search for her after she went missing in the Japan earthquake. Nancy Cordes reports.

fields.title: The CBS Evening News with Scott Pelley - Minor damage found at quake epicenter
fields.description: Sharyl Attkisson reports on the damage caused by the 5.8 earthquake that rattled the east coast, from the epicenter in Mineral, Va.

fields.title: Haiti Earthquake Aftermath
fields.description: "CBS News RAW": daytime pictures of the aftermath of the Tuesday's earthquake in Haiti. There were crying victims among the downed buildings.

fields.title: Caught On Tape: Wave Crashes Into Cruise Ship
fields.description: An Italian passenger of the Louis Majesty, Ervino Curtis shot the wave hitting and breaking the glass of portholes, killing two people and wounding many others.

fields.title: Japanese workers remain in nuclear plant
fields.description: After three explosions at Fukushima's nuclear complex, Jim Axelrod reports on the condition of the estimated 50 workers inside the plant and the dangers they face amid high levels of radiation.

fields.title: Moments after Haiti Quake
fields.description: "Caught on Tape": A Brazilian soldier reveals amazing footage he captured on his cell phone moments after Haiti's main cathedral collapsed during a devastating earthquake.

fields.title: The challenges of the Japan rescue effort
fields.description: The damage left behind by the massive earthquake and tsunami which ravaged Japan is posing many challenges to the international rescue effort. Bill Whitaker reports from Japan.

fields.title: Haiti's "Baby Doc" Charged with Corruption
fields.description: Haiti's former dictator Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier, who returned to Haiti after 25 years in exile, was charged with corruption, theft and misappropriation of funds. Kelly Cobiella reports.

fields.title: Feed: Lindsay Lohan Out of Jail
fields.description: Massive flooding in Pakistan, Obama has a blunt message for embattled Rep. Charles Rangel and Lindsay Lohan is freed from jail. For the news you missed over the weekend watch "The Feed" with Erica Hill.

fields.title: World Watch 10.30.09
fields.description: Secretary of State Hilary Clinton in Pakistan and another typhoon threatens the Philippines.

fields.title: Nuclear radiation threatens Japan's food, economy
fields.description: The US, China, South Korea and India have all stepped their inspections of Japanese food imports and Italy has banned them altogether. As Lucy Craft reports, this could threaten Japan's $5 billion export market.

fields.title: Floods Continue to Torment Pakistan
fields.description: With floodwaters moving South and more rain on the way, a UN official says the enormous crisis in Pakistan is still unfolding. Richard Roth reports.

fields.title: The Feed: Deadly Off-Road Crash
fields.description: Eight people were killed and 12 wounded when a truck careened off course in the California desert. Also, Pakistan flooding still causing damage, dramatic plane crash rescue, and zebras break loose in Sacramento.

fields.title: Pakistan Flood Victims Desperate
fields.description: Children were torn from their mothers' arms in flood-ravaged areas in Pakistan as desperation for food and water grows.

fields.title: Haiti Orphans Seek Parents
fields.description: Haitian orphans brought to the US after their orphanage was destroyed in the 7.0 earthquake are hoping to be adopted by American parents. Jeff Glor reports.

fields.title: "60 Minutes Presents: Honoring Our Soldiers"
fields.description: The first living soldier to win the Medal of Honor since Vietnam tells Lara Logan what he did to earn the nation's highest combat honor; plus Logan takes viewers to the border area between Afghanistan and Pakistan. Sunday, May 29 at 7 pm ET/PT.

fields.title: Images of Haitian Ruins
fields.description: Jeff Glor shows us the destruction and subsequent desperation throughout Haiti after the devastating earthquake.

fields.title: Preview: Haiti and Cholera
fields.description: Dr. David Walton has been working with "Partners in Health" in Haiti for over a decade and talks to Byron Pitts about the cholera outbreak in the earthquake-stricken country. Pitts reports Haiti this Sunday, Nov. 14, at 7 pm ET/PT.

fields.title: Port-au-Prince Before and After
fields.description: Satellite pictures of Haiti before and after the quake show the alarming devastation its capital, Port-au-Prince, is in. Google Earth has the images on its crisis response webpage. Sandra Hughes reports.

fields.title: Japan earthquake sparks huge oil refinery fire
fields.description: The 8.9 magnitude earthquake in Japan caused massive damage. A large fire erupted at the Cosmo oil refinery in Ichihara city and burned out of control with 100-foot high flames whipping into the sky.

fields.title: Deadly Flooding in Pakistan
fields.description: Monsoons caused devastating floods in Pakistan's Swat Valley. Richard Roth reports.

fields.title: Sendai temple nearly destroyed by tsunami
fields.description: In wake of a 9.9 magnitude earthquake and tsunami, Harry Smith reports on the near-destruction of a Buddhist temple in the hard-hit city of Sendai and the surviving spirit of the Japanese people.

fields.title: Destruction in Haiti
fields.description: CBS News Raw: The latest video from Port-au-Prince, Haiti, showing the destruction from the 7.0 earthquake. The majority of the city's residents are homeless and in need of aid.

fields.title: Tsunami aftermath in Crescent Bay, Calif.
fields.description: Five people have been swept out to sea after tsunami-created waves of up to eight-foot high crashed onto the shore of Crescent City, California.

fields.title: Drought leads to famine in Somalia
fields.description: The United Nations declared famine in parts of southern Somalia, signalling to donors the need for more aid. International aid agencies will not travel into Somalia due to the influence of Islamic insurgents affiliated with al Qaeda, leading many to flee the country. Felipe Maya reports.

fields.title: CBS News Update: Japan earthquake a 9.0, casualties at 1400
fields.description: Russ Mitchell updates the latest information coming from Japan reporting the magnitude of the initial earthquake has been increased to 9.0, the death toll is up to 1400 casualties with fears the number could exceed 10000.

fields.title: US aid for Japan turning hazardous for military
fields.description: The US humanitarian relief operation for Japan is quickly turning into a hazardous duty for the military after helicopter crews return contaminated with radioactivity. David Martin reports.

fields.title: Update: Latest on Japan earthquake and tsunami
fields.description: Russ Mitchell provides an update on the latest news regarding the earthquake and tsunami that ravaged Japan, including the explosion at a nuclear power plant, the rescue effort to find the missing and the US military aid to the country.

fields.title: World's largest refugee camp
fields.description: Thousands of Somalis fleeing famine and conflict pour into Dedaab, Kenya, making it one of the country's biggest population centers where the United Nations High Commission for Refugees is struggling to feed and house over 400000 refugees.

fields.title: Obama statement on Japan quake
fields.description: President Obama expressed his condolences to the victims of the 8.9 magnitude earthquake that struck Japan and triggered a powerful tsunami. Bill Plante reports.

fields.title: US to Increase Pakistan Aid
fields.description: The US is increasing emergency aid to Pakistan to $150 million to assist the 20 million people affected by flooding.

fields.title: Notebook: Aid to Haiti
fields.description: With Katie Couric on assignment in Haiti, CBS News' Kelly Wallace discusses the relief efforts in that disaster area, as the donations to this island nation cannot arrive fast enough for survivors.

fields.title: Preview: Rescue Mission in Haiti
fields.description: Katie Couric will anchor special coverage of the "CBS Evening News" from Haiti, were disaster relief teams are desperately searching for survivors of the recent earthquake. Friday, Jan. 15th, 6:30 pm, ET/PT

fields.title: Japanese city almost wiped off the map
fields.description: CBS News correspondent Ben Tracy reports from Natori City, Japan - which was once home to about 74000 people - mostly farmers. Now, it's deserted. Most evacuated to shelters or with family. Some are missing, some dead, and some are still there.

fields.title: Notebook: Haiti
fields.description: It is impossible to hear about the Haiti earthquake victims without feeling the immense emotion of this tragedy. As Katie Couric is on assignment in Haiti, Kelly Wallace comments.

fields.title: Haiti Rescue from Toppled Building
fields.description: CBS News RAW: Search and rescue teams worked to rescue a woman from a crumbled cement building after a 7.0 earthquake struck Haiti.

fields.title: Japan evacuees scanned for radiation
fields.description: CBS News RAW: Evacuees are scanned to check for possible exposure to radiation resulting from an explosion at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan, after an 8.9 magnitude earthquake shook the region.

fields.title: Sister city to the Rescue
fields.description: When the residents of Fort Bragg, CA, saw their sister city in Japan devastated by the tsunami, they started fundraising. Former Mayor Lindy Peters says 6000 people raised over $160000.

fields.title: Models take turns falling on the runway
fields.description: Several models fell on the runway at a fashion show organized by supermodel Naomi Campbell. The charity event, held in Cannes, France, was put on to benefit victims of the Japanese earthquake and tsunami.

fields.title: Japan earthquake triggers tsunami
fields.description: CBS News RAW: A massive 8.9 magnitude earthquake shook Japan and triggered a tsunami that caused further devastation. The quake is the largest in Japanese history.

fields.title: Sean Penn Arrives in Haiti
fields.description: CBS News RAW: Academy-Award winning Hollywood actor and activist Sean Penn arrived in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, in order to help with rescue efforts in the wake of a disaster.

fields.title: Buildings crumble during Japan's quake
fields.description: NO AUDIO: Amateur video captures buildings shaking and chunks of debris hurtling down onto roads in the city of Sendai, Japan.

fields.title: The Early Show - Lonely pine tree survived quake, tsunami
fields.description: A lonely pine tree in Japan has become a symbol of survival for the entire nation. Debbye Turner Bell reports.

fields.title: Haiti Earthquake Caught on Tape
fields.description: The CBS News Investigative Unit has acquired video of buildings collapsing in Port-au-Prince, Haiti during the country's worst earthquake since 1770. The earthquake had a magnitude of 7.0 and dozens of aftershocks. (CBSNews.com)

fields.title: Preview: Disaster in Haiti
fields.description: "CBS Evening News" anchor Katie Couric previews extensive coverage from Haiti, as US military forces attempt to assess the heavy damage in this area for rescue relief efforts.

fields.title: Goldfish survive 4 months after New Zealand quake
fields.description: Two goldfish were found alive in their tank in a building that was badly damaged by the earthquake that struck New Zealand four months ago. Jeff Glor reports.

fields.title: Rescuers follow tapping sounds to quake survivor
fields.description: CBS News RAW: Ann Bodkin, after being trapped for over 25 hours in the ruins of the Pyne Gould corporate building, is freed after tapping to communicate with rescue workers.

fields.title: Dog in Sendai refused to leave injured friend
fields.description: In the aftermath of the 9.0 earthquake and tsunami, a dog stood loyally next to another dog that was injured or sick in Sendai, Japan. Katie Couric reports.

fields.title: 7.8 Earthquake in Indonesia
fields.description: Sparking fears of another tsunami similar to 2006, the US Geological Survey says a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck the island of Sumatra in Indonesia. Maggie Rodriguez reports.

fields.title: Lucy Craft reunites with son in Japan
fields.description: CBS News correspondent Lucy Craft reunited with her son in Tokyo for the first time since the earthquake and tsunami struck Japan.

fields.title: UN: Famine crisis in east Africa, thousands dead
fields.description: The United Nations says there is a famine crisis in east Africa that has killed tens of thousands of people. Betty Nguyen reports on the worst drought in fifty years.

fields.title: The Early Show - Japan tsunami debris hits US coast
fields.description: It is estimated a debris field the size of Calif. is headed toward the US West Coast. Terrell Brown reports.

fields.title: Boy, Girl Rescued Week After Quake
fields.description: An 8 year-old boy and his 10 year-old sister were rescued from the rubble of a two-story building 7 days after the deadly earthquake struck Haiti.

fields.title: The Early Show - Turkey quake's tiniest survivor
fields.description: Jeff Glor reports on the youngest survivor from the 7.2 earthquake that rocked Turkey and killed 523 people.

fields.title: US questions Haitian earthquake death toll
fields.description: The US government reports the death toll from last year's devastating earthquake in Haiti is far less than what the Haitian government claims. Jeff Glor reports.

fields.title: Floodwaters rising in northeast Japan
fields.description: Heavy rain and high tides caused floodwaters to rise in northeast Japan, an area that was hit hard by the large earthquake and tsunami. Jeff Glor reports.

fields.title: The Early Show - Colorado shaken by strongest quake in 40 years
fields.description: Colorado has been shaken by the state's strongest earthquake in almost 40 years. Jeff Glor reports there are no reports of injuries.

fields.title: Shilling Expects Weakened Yen, Opportunity for Shorting
