As rain reached the camp in Mogadishu on July 31, old women and children struggled to repair their shelters which could not withhold the downpour. Internally displaced people described their situation as a desperate one, and had nothing to shield them from the harsh weather conditions. Thousands of IDPs, who were previously living in destroyed buildings in the Somali capital, have now been moved to camps outside the city. The UN has declared famine in two cities of southern Somalia, and has said that 3.7 million people are at risk of starvation. An ongoing scarcity in East Africa is the worst to strike the region in six decades. Humanitarian crisis continues in Somalia caused by military conflict and years of famine. More than 11 million people in the Horn of Africa now need assistance to survive the crisis caused by the floods. By: Ikram Al Yacoub Al Arabiya With Agencies

fields.title: Haitians struggle six months after killer quake
fields.description: It's almost six months since the January 12 earthquake that devastated large swathes of Haiti and left countless people homeless. But the NGO Doctors Without Borders (Médecins Sans Frontières) says many of those affected are still living in dire conditions. Duration: 03:08

fields.title: Japan marks a month since earthquake and tsunami
fields.description: Japan marks a month on Monday since a 9.0 magnitude undersea quake sent a powerful tsunami crashing into its coast, devastating entire towns and sparking the worst nuclear emergency in 25 years. Duration: 02:56

fields.title: A Haitian 'looter' puts himself in harms way
fields.description: In the streets of Haiti's earthquake-ravaged capital, the rubble is regularly scavenged by people desperate for food or goods to sell. When they clash with police forces, the country's devastated medical facilities can scarsley cope with the consequences. Duration: 02:43

fields.title: Islamic charities helping Pakistan flood victims
fields.description: When torrential monsoon rains flooded Pakistan, sparking the country's worst-ever humanitarian crisis, hardline Islamic charities moved fast. Faster than the government. Duration: 02:43

fields.title: What future for the UN in Haiti?
fields.description: The United Nations mission in Haiti, with its nearly 15000 uniformed and civilian staff, has been a fixture in Haiti since 2004, aiding with peacekeeping, stabilization and -- recently -- earthquake relief. But its presence is not without controversy: locals blame its soldiers for starting a cholera epidemic last year, and a group of troops are now accused of the rape of a Haitian youth. MINUSTAH, as it is called, has a new leader, and is looking to redefine its presence as Haiti rebuilds.Duration: 02:40

fields.title: Pakistani children suffer as floods bring death and disease
fields.description: Conditions remain perilous for people affected by Pakistan's worst floods in eighty years. At least two million people are in urgent need of help after being forced to leave their homes. Children have been particularly hard hit by the crisis, many of them falling ill after drinking contaminated water. Duration: 02:30.

fields.title: Mothers fight earthquake trauma to care for babies
fields.description: POst-quake stress and trauma means that many mothers in Haiti can't produce milk to feed their children, and malnutrition is a major concern. At a makeshift childcare unit in the capital's devastated general hospital, Swiss doctors help care for Haiti's youngest victims.Duration: 02:26

fields.title: Tough Haitians still clinging to life under rubble
fields.description: More than five days after an avalanche of rubble plunged her into a painful solitary black hell and 12 hours after international teams heard her faltering cries, Marie-France was rescued. French and US firefighters and medics drilled away the concrete slabs that buried her, then ground their way through the steel door that protected but also imprisoned her when Haiti was hit by a catastrophic earthquake. Duration: 02:26

fields.title: Japan disaster recalls dark days for Three Mile Islanders
fields.description: Until the Japan earthquake, the Three Mile Island accident in Pennsylvania in 1979 was the world's second most serious nuclear meltdown after Chernobyl. As Japan grapples with the accident at the stricken Fukushima plant , the residents of Three Mile Island remember the evacuation and nuclear fall-out.Duration:02:23

fields.title: Somali famers begin road to recovery
fields.description: The drought that swept the Horn of Africa turned several southern Somali regions into famine zones, but a small farming region near the Ethiopian border was spared. A FAO-sponsored project last year helped clear nine hectares of land, and now farmers are able to sell their produce in the local market. The UN says if more projects like this were in existence, thousands of lives would have been saved, as well as millions of dollars. Duration: 02:22

fields.title: Haiti struggles to rebuild after quake
fields.description: As aid organisations work to rehouse more than a million people left homeless and rebuild Haiti's capital, frustration is growing with the speed at which the desperately poor country is getting back on its feet. An international conference being held Wednesday in the neighbouring Dominican Republic is trying to refocus efforts to drive reconstruction.Duration: 02:23

fields.title: Rebuilding Haiti, one home at a time
fields.description: One in seven Haitians was left homeless after the earthquake that flattened much of the capital Port-au-Prince two years ago. Finding them permanent shelter is still one of the biggest challenges -- but the country may finally be ready to get the job done. Duration: 02:21

fields.title: Robots to the rescue in Japan
fields.description: Japan may be at the forefront of robotics and its children raised on cartoons of robot heroes and villains, but the country has so far had to rely on US-made machines for help tackling its nuclear crisis.Duration: 02:20

fields.title: Japan tsunami debris starts to hit US coast
fields.description: As much as 20 million tons of debris is estimated to have washed out to sea when the tsunami struck Japan in March. Now the first traces are appearing on the other side of Pacific ocean, on US and Canadian shores. Duration: 02:18

fields.title: Thousands flee Somali drought
fields.description: Tens of thousands of people have fled Somalia as the worst drought to hit the horn of Africa since the 1960s brings starvation to the region. Duration: 02:17.

fields.title: Haitian child survivor finds new life
fields.description: A year ago, some 300 abandoned children were leaving their home in Haiti for a new life in France. Mickenson, now three, should have been one of them. But the massive earthquake which shook the country in January 2010 meant he never left. For his adoptive parents in France, it was the start of a nightmare wait to find out what had happened to their new son. Duration: 02:16.

fields.title: Disaster-hit Japan faces a challenge processing refuse
fields.description: Almost a year after the tsunami, Japan is still cleaning up and processing the thousands of tons of garbage remains one of the country's biggest challenges. Duration: 02:16

fields.title: Japan fishermen vow to rebuild tsunami-hit lives
fields.description: VIDEO: Fishermen whose livelihoods were devastated when the enormous tsunami hit Japan say they are determined to rebuild their industry on the sea that so cruelly turned against them. Duration: 02:16

fields.title: Lady Gaga appeals to Japanese to 'keep dream alive'
fields.description: Participating in an MTV charity event in Tokyo on Saturday, Lady Gaga urged Japanese people to be strong and never give up on their dreams despite the huge challenges caused by the recent earthquake and tsunami. Duration: 02:15

fields.title: Rebuilding Haiti, one year on
fields.description: A year after its devastating earthquake, Haiti is still lagging in rebuilding. At Camp Corail, about 20 kilometers from Port-au-Prince, non-profit groups have been building shelters since April 2010. The site is far from ideal -- with food hard to come by, and work nowhere to be found -- but it offers what thousands still need -- a roof over their heads. Duration: 02:15.

fields.title: Pakistan flood overshadows Eid
fields.description: Muslims all over the world are preparing to mark the Eid al-Fitr holiday. But for Pakistan's flood victims, the situation remains bleak. Twenty-one million people have been affected, and 10 million remain without shelters.Duration: 02:14

fields.title: Cleaning up Fukushima is still dangerous work
fields.description: One year after the Fukushima plant was hit by a tsunami, the Japanese government and the plant operator announced a "cold shutdown" of the reactors implying that there is only cleaning up left to do. But, for those cleaning up, the task continues to be a dangerous, complicated and lengthy one. Duration: 02:13

fields.title: Haiti women vulnerable with rape on the rise
fields.description: More than 250 cases of rape were reported in Haiti's 1150 camps in the first 150 days after the earthquake. Gangs of armed men roam the camps after dark, but many women have no option but to stay in the same camps where they were raped -- and live with the fear of further attacks.Duration: 02:13

fields.title: Hopes dim for tsunami victims' family
fields.description: Yoshie Kikuchi is still desperately looking for her parents who she hasn't heard from since the earthquake and tsunami swept Japan's north-east eleven days ago. Duration: 02:13

fields.title: German nun dedicates life to help Pakistan's poor
fields.description: Some compare her to Mother Teresa. For the past 50 years, 81 year-old sister Ruth Pfau has looked after Pakistan's poorest with seemingly endless amounts of energy. Duration: 02:12

fields.title: Theatrical therapy for quake-hit Haitians
fields.description: In a time of uncertainty and rumor, one Haitian theatre troupe is encouraging people to take hold of their destiny rather than succumb to inaction. Their 'participatory theatre' calls on the audience - inhabitants of refugee camps in quake-hit Port-au-Prince - to step up and speak out during performances, and thereby change the course of events.Duration: 02:12

fields.title: Damaged Haiti port vital to quake aid supplies
fields.description: Port authorities are working hard to repair maritime installations in Haiti's ruined capital. The port was severely damaged during last week's earthquake but once it's up and running again, it can provide a secure route for the supply of lifesaving aid. Duration: 02:12

fields.title: UN: more coordination needed for aid to Haiti
fields.description: The UN's deputy chief in Haiti has been seeing first-hand some of the challenges facing aid workers in the country, as he took a whistlestop tour of Jacmel on the southern coast, where half the town's population are homeless. With two billion dollars pledged in international aid, and new NGOs arriving to help almost daily, coordinating efforts effectively in Haiti is now a mammoth task. Duration: 02:11

fields.title: Japan's tsunami orphans face uncertain future
fields.description: Naho and Takashi are just two of an unknown number of children orphaned by the huge waves that crushed towns along Japan's northeast coast on March 11. Duration: 02:11

fields.title: Tsunami 'Pine of hope' dying but not its legacy
fields.description: The sole survivor of a rich forest of 70000 pine trees that once lined Rikuzentakata's shore became a symbol of hope for Japan as the country struggled to make sense of the enormity of the disaster, but a year on the tree is dying. Duration: 02:11

fields.title: Japan wave pummels Japan's tsunami defences
fields.description: People in the fishing village of Taro thought they were safe behind one of Japan's largest tsunami-resistant barriers. But they stood little chance when the giant wave hit following the March 11 quake. Duration: 02:11

fields.title: MSF: Children's health getting worse in Dadaab camps
fields.description: The medical charity Médecins Sans Frontières says children in the Dadaab refugee camps that have arrived in recent months are more malnourished than children who have just arrived.Duration:02:11

fields.title: Wave pummels Japan's tsunami defences
fields.description: Protected by one of Japan's largest tsunami-resistant barriers, people in the small fishing village of Taro never doubted their safety behind its gigantic sea wall. But faced with the giant 10-metre wave triggered by the March 11 quake, even the most well-prepared communities quickly discovered they were not prepared enough.Duration: 02:11

fields.title: Tsunami aftermath hits Japan's tourism industry
fields.description: The beach resort of Okumatsushima was a thriving stop on Japan's north-east coast tourist trail until two weeks ago, when the huge tsunami virtually wiped it from the map. Duration: 02:11

fields.title: Floods 'great catch' for Pakistan fishermen
fields.description: Fishermen who work the seas off Sindh province in southern Pakistan are among the only people to have benefited from the devastating floods that ravaged a fifth of the country. Duration: 02:09

fields.title: Haiti looters threaten new strife
fields.description: One week after an earthquake devastated the country, Haitian security forces are struggling to control looters in the capital Port-au-Prince. Thousands of homeless Haitians are prey to bands of looters swarming through the ruins, and the handful of Haitian police on patrol are helpless to stop them. Duration: 02:10

fields.title: Haitian voters brace for stark choice
fields.description: Disillusioned Haitians are preparing to vote for new leaders who will inherit a country on its knees after January's earthquake, and a cholera epidemic threatening over a million refugees. Duration: 02:29.

fields.title: Concern grows for Fukushima-style reactor in US
fields.description: In what's been seen as a small victory for the American anti-nuclear lobby -- just ten days after the Fukushima nuclear disaster, a federal judge has decided to focus on the operating license of America's most dilapidated reactor: Oyster Creek on the east coast. The reactor has the same design as its Japanese counterpart but is four years older and has recently suffered a series of leaks. Duration: 02:09

fields.title: Somali men left behind as women trek alone
fields.description: Eighty percent of the new arrivals at the Dadaab refugee camp in Kenya are women and children. They say that Islamic militants are stopping able-bodied men from making the journey and are sending them back home.Duration: 02:08

fields.title: Students back to school after the tsunami hit
fields.description: Students in Japan's tsunami-hit region are having to return to their studies. Many of them face hard times without homes and some are still missing relatives and friends, and they are having to study in makeshift facilities.Duration: 02:08

fields.title: Rebuilding work underway in devastated Japan
fields.description: VIDEO: Construction is underway in Rikuzentakata, one of the towns worst hit by Japan's earthquake and tsunami. Temporary homes are being built for those in evacuation centres, many who have lost everything. Duration: 02:07

fields.title: Huge Dadaab vaccination programme in bid to save lives
fields.description: Children under the age of five are being immunised against measles and polio in the world biggest refugee camp in Kenya. But doctors warn that unless more is done to help the children on their journey from Somalia to Dadaab, many will continue to arrive at death's door and maybe even die on the way.Duration: 02:07

fields.title: A year after the tsunami
fields.description: Japan is preparing to mark the first anniversary of the huge earthquake and tsunami that devastated the northeast coast on March 11, sparking a nuclear crisis at Fukushimaand leaving around 23000 dead or missing. A look at the situation in Japan now and over the last year.

fields.title: Desperation in Haiti amid pleas for more aid
fields.description: Relief workers in Haiti have been struggling for the fifth day to assist desperate earthquake survivors amid anger over the chaotic aid effort, as two former US presidents admitted the country's recovery will be long. Duration: 02:08

fields.title: Haiti's homeless camp on perilous ground
fields.description: January's quake left more than 1.3 million people homeless and claimed as many as 300000 lives. Five months later, several hundred thousand people remain camped out in precarious tent cities and on the streets in the capital Port-au-Prince. Duration: 02:08

fields.title: Woman in iconic tsunami photo looks to future
fields.description: The photo of Yuko Sugimoto wrapped in a blanket and staring out among the destruction of her town went around the world and was used to illustrate the devastation of the March 11 tsunami. Yuko and her husband had lost their young son and thought he had been carried away by the wave, but after three days they found him. Now Yuko's family are rebuilding their life. Duration: 02:06

fields.title: Pakistan flood victims return home to devastation
fields.description: Four months after unprecedented floods left a fifth of Pakistan under water, millions of people are still in a desperate situation. Residents fed up with living in makeshift shelters are returning to the ruins of their homes. Duration: 02:06

fields.title: Conflict, drought continue to uproot Somalis
fields.description: As Somalia's civil war drags on along with a punishing drought, more and more people are having to move into temporary camps where there are little or no facilities. Aid however is slowly getting through. Duration: 02:06.

fields.title: Four million Somalis still need urgent help
fields.description: Somalia Six months after a famine was declared in Somalia, four million people are still in urgent need of humanitarian support. But the UN says the situation in Mogadishu has improved significantly over the past few months. Duration: 02:04

fields.title: Nuclear disaster at Fukushima
fields.description: Japan is preparing to mark the first anniversary of the huge earthquake and tsunami that devastated the northeast coast on March 11, sparking a nuclear crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi plant.

fields.title: Japan's tsunami survivors brace for harsh winter
fields.description: As the mercury plunges in Japan's disaster-hit northeast, thousands of people in temporary homes are digging in for what could be a long, hard and very cold winter. Duration: 02:03

fields.title: Foreign tourists avoid disaster-hit Japan
fields.description: More than a month after Japan suffered the most powerful earthquake in its history, foreign tourists remain a rare sight as the country grapples with power cuts and radiation leaks from a nuclear power plant. Duration: 02:03.

fields.title: Drought threatens traditional Kenyan way of life
fields.description: The drought that is afflicting the horn of Africa is forcing the traditional pastoralists of Northern Kenya to give up their way of life. The Turkana people are having to settle in villages where aid sometimes arrives, and the children are losing the skills that have served the people for generations. Duration: 02:02.

fields.title: Japan disaster builds international bridges
fields.description: Many of Japan's tsunami victims are encountering foreign faces armed with drills and hammers as aid groups arrive to help rebuild homes. Duration: 02:02

fields.title: Global food scare widens from Japan nuclear crisis
fields.description: Fears of radiation are rising as more countries ban some food imports from areas near the nuclear power plant in Japan, damaged by a powerful quake and tsunami. Duration: 02:02

fields.title: Mogadishu's cathedral gives shelter
fields.description: The cathedral in Mogadishu is now home to hundreds of Somalis who have fled drought afflicted regions across the country in search of aid. Duration: 02:01

fields.title: Life and death a matter of metres in Japanese town
fields.description: VIDEO: Japan is battling a nuclear and humanitarian crisis after its huge earthquake and tsunami. In some towns, the line between survival and ruin was very fine indeed. Duration: 02:01

fields.title: Mogadishu hospital overwhelmed with malnourished children
fields.description: Tens of thousands of Somalis have poured into Mogadishu, fleeing the drought that has wiped out livestock and crops. At the city's only dedicated paediatrics ward, doctors say they are overwhelmed by the huge numbers of malnourished children. ATTENTION: VIEWERS MIGHT FIND THESE SOME OF THESE IMAGES DISTRESSING.Duration: 02:02

fields.title: Fire-ravaged Russian villages start to rebuild
fields.description: Reconstruction has begun in Russia in villages affected by this Summer's forest fires. Duration: 02:01.

fields.title: Earthquakes: devastating natural disasters
fields.description: An 8.7-magnitude earthquake off the coast of Indonesia has triggered a tsunami warning across the Indian Ocean, particularly affecting Sri Lanka, where some 30000 people were killed in the 2004 tsunami, also following an undersea earthquake off Indonesia.

fields.title: Haitians throng to UN looking for jobs
fields.description: Haiti's earthquake destroyed lives, homes but also thousands of businesses leaving many unemployed with no means to support themselves or their families. They are now thronging to the United Nations base where aid groups are hiring hundreds of drivers, guides and interpreters. But the job application process is chaotic and for most, fruitless. Duration: 02:01.

fields.title: Haitians risk their lives in post-quake looting
fields.description: Looting is on the increase in the Haitian capital of Port-au-Prince as chaos reigns in the wake of Tuesday's killer earthquake. With aid agencies struggling to get supplies to the population, desperate survivors are risking their lives by entering collapsed buildings to pillage what they can. In the city's Marche en Fer, or Iron Market district, the city's barely-functioning police force is struggling to control the situation. Duration: 02:01

fields.title: UNICEF's Mia Farrow visits Dadaab refugees
fields.description: UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Mia Farrow vists the world's largest refugee camp in Dadaab, north-eastern Kenya. Duration: 01:59

fields.title: Haiti quake worst disaster ever confronted by UN: UN
fields.description: The earthquake in Haiti is the worst disaster ever confronted by the United Nations, a spokeswoman said Saturday, pointing out that the catastrophe has left affected regions with little infrastructure. UN images from Port-au-Prince. Duration: 02:00

fields.title: Japan's pet survivors face post-tsunami struggle
fields.description: When the tsunami hit Japan's northeast coast, many people turned up at evacuation centres with their beloved pets in-tow. But most centres are animal-free zones -- so a team of veterinary volunteers are doing what they can to help.Duration: 01:59

fields.title: Summer of extreme weather fuels debate over warming
fields.description: As Russia battles wildfires triggered by an unprecedented heatwave, flood waters surge across a drenched Pakistan leaving millions of people homeless, questions are being asked about global warming.Duration: 01:59

fields.title: Tsunami fears surge on US coast, after Japan
fields.description: Seismic tremors along the Cascadia fault are causing jitters for those in charge of earthquake and tsunami preparations on America's Pacific Northwest coast. Duration: 01:58.

fields.title: Asian tsunami warnings test post-2004 systems
fields.description: Since the 2004 tsunami, which devastated the Aceh province, Indonesia has invested heavily in an early warning system. It has proven a success so far. The area was hit by a giant quake again on April 11 but there was little damage. Duration: 01:58.

fields.title: Japan's communities rebuild after tsunami and earthquake
fields.description: Fishing communities in Onagawa, northeast Japan, were devastated by the March 11 earthquake and tsunami. But the fishermen have returned to work and plans are under way for their villages to be rebuilt. Duration: 01:57

fields.title: One year on from disaster, Japan is still hurting
fields.description: As Japan commemorates the March 11 disaster with a minute of silence, thousands of Tokyo residents take to the streets to let the Japanese government -- and the world -- know that Japan's nuclear crisis is far from over. Duration: 01:56

fields.title: Feeding the starving in Somalia
fields.description: Aid is slowly trickling into Somalia to help the hundreds of thousands of people affected by drought and famine. In Doolow, the last town before the border with Ethiopia, hundreds have gathered to get their first hot meal in days at an NGO feeding point. Duration: 01:55

fields.title: Race is on to save Haiti quake victims
fields.description: Rescuers are racing against the clock to find survivors among thousands of corpses in Haiti, two days after the deadly earthquake struck the island nation. AFPTV reports.Duration: 01:56

fields.title: Aid efforts stepped up ahead of Haiti's rainy season
fields.description: With more than a million Haitians homeless, the rainy season on its way and many thousands more still in desperate need of food and medical care, the quake-ravaged country currently depends on foreign aid more than ever. Coordination efforts have improved, making distribution quicker and more widespread, but impatience is stilll growing in the capital, Port-au-Prince. A natural sound version of an AFPTV report.Duration: 01:56

fields.title: Somalis in Nairobi help drought victims
fields.description: The Somali community in Nairobi has raised thousands of dollars in the past few weeks to help their fellow country men who are suffering from the worst drought to afflict the region in 60 years. Two truck loads of aid are driving to northern Kenya, where they'll cross the border to bring relief to thousands of starving people.Duration: 01:54

fields.title: First aid is small mercy at Haiti quake epicentre
fields.description: A first shipment of UN food aid has arrived in the ruined Haitian town of Leogane, west of the capital Port-au-Prince, where street after street of homes and businesses have been torn apart by this week's devastating earthquake. The UN says up to 90 percent of buildings were badly damaged or destroyed. Duration: 01:53

fields.title: 'Air-conditioned clothes' help Japan beat summer heat
fields.description: Japan is braced for a sweltering summer with little air conditioning due to post-earthquake measures to save electricity. One clothing company has created special air conditioned outfits to help people through the hot working season. Duration: 01:53

fields.title: Paris ballet dancers teach young tsunami victims
fields.description: Members of the famed Paris Opera Ballet performing in Japan travel north to teach budding dancers who survived the March tsunami. Duration: 01:52

fields.title: Pakistan suffers as key cotton crop hit
fields.description: VIDEO: Pakistan is the world's fourth largest producer of cotton. But following last year's floods and ongoing power cuts, this year's harvest is down 20 percent and could affect the cost of textiles around the world. Duration: 01:52

fields.title: Japan quake survivors cling onto hope
fields.description: Orderly queues for food, fuel and transport in Sendai downtown are in stark contrast with the devastation only a few kilometres away. Relief operations are underway, but there are frequent aftershocks and ongoing fears of nuclear fallout and new tsunamis.Duration: 01:52

fields.title: Everyday things lift spirit of tsunami victims
fields.description: Getting a haircut, watching the football or playing a musical instrument are some of the small acts that are helping lift spirits in Japan's disaster-sticken north-east.Duration: 01:51

fields.title: Exodus-seeking quake survivors face long wait
fields.description: Thousands of Haitians sit by the sea on earthquake-cracked mud, surrounded by bags and babies. They're waiting for ferries to travel to countryside, spared in the recent devastating earthquake. But damage to the port and a lack of fuel means the wait could be long.Duration: 01:51

fields.title: Tsunami wipes out half of Japanese town
fields.description: The tsunami triggered by last week's earthquake off the coast of Japan has devastated one small town. More than half of the population of 17000 are missing, presumed dead.Duration: 01:52

fields.title: Rescue workers free trapped Haitian woman
fields.description: Belgian rescue workers worked throughout the night and into much of Friday to free a 28-year-old woman called Marie-Jeanne trapped when her house collapsed in Haiti's devastating earthquake. They had to amputate her right leg under the rubble to free her. More than four days after the disaster, it's a race against time to free any remaining survivors. Duration: 01:50

fields.title: Haiti's quake survivors brace for deadly wet season floods
fields.description: Haitians huddling together in the open after their killer earthquake are bracing for a new natural menace: the Caribbean's notoriously heavy rainy season, which is already causing deadly flooding in their country.Duration: 01:51

fields.title: Scale of Japan quake-tsunami destruction revealed
fields.description: As Japan begins the process of recovering from Friday's catastrophic earthquake and tsunami, the enormity of the task facing the country has become clear.Duration: 01:48

fields.title: Japan tsunami damage on Chile's shellfish beds
fields.description: The tsunami that has caused so much damage in Japan carried its wave of destruction all the way across the Pacific. Though it was barely visible when it hit Chile's shores a day later, under the water it destroyed a year's worth of the shellfish harvest. Duration: 01:48

fields.title: Doctors fear outbreaks of disease in Pakistan
fields.description: On the ground, authorities and aid organisations are struggling to meet the needs of Pakistan's flood victims, with worries growing about outbreaks of disease. Duration: 01:48

fields.title: Drought hits Somalia's internal refugees
fields.description: Faced with what locals say is the worst drought in a decade, Somali herders who lost their flocks to starvation are moving to the Somaliland town of Berbera. There they are joined by another kind of refugee -- people fleeing fighting in the south. But the port's ageing infrastructure delivers barely enough water for its ever-expanding population, and the United Nations says it urgently needs 10 million dollars to provide relief aid. Duration: 01:46

fields.title: Somali refugees flee as famine declared
fields.description: The Dolo Ado refugee camp in southern Ethiopia has been overwhelmed in recent weeks by Somalis fleeing a devastating drought. As famine is declared in two regions of Somalia, AFPTV hears first-hand about the region thousands have left behind. Duration: 01:46

fields.title: Mayor fights to rebuild tsunami-hit hometown
fields.description: The city of Rikuzentakata was virtually wiped from the map on March 11. Thousands of its citizens died and a third of its civil servants were killed. The city's mayor, who lost his wife in the disaster, came to symbolise the tragedy and has led efforts to rebuild his hometown, battling the central government's often slipshod approach to recovery and trying to reunite a community left in tatters by the disaster. Duration: 01:45

fields.title: Haiti's cultural community looks to uncertain future
fields.description: Last month's Haitian earthquake didn't just destroy buildings and lives -- it also curtailed the country's burgeoning cultural life. But in the midst of the suffering, the country's artistic community is still determined to make its voice heard. Duration: 01:45.

fields.title: In Haiti, the beat goes on
fields.description: Music courses through Haitian culture in good times as in bad, continuing to reflect the lives of millions as they piece together what shattered in the earthquake. Local musicians have written a song collectively to commemorate the first anniversary of the quake, relating through the rhythms the hardship and hope that remain.Duration: 01:44

fields.title: New Zealand community pulls together following quake
fields.description: While the search continues for the hundreds of people feared to be buried in the wreckage of New Zealand's 6.3 magnitude earthquake, many survivors in the small town at the epicenter of the quake are wondering if they are safe in their own homes.Duration: 01:43

fields.title: Haiti mourns one month after devastating quake
fields.description: Haiti observes a national day of mourning Friday to mark one month after a devastating quake killed at least 217000 people. This comes as the rainy season starts earlier than usual and is making life even more miserable for the hundreds of thousands made homeless by the quake.Duration: 01:42

fields.title: Olympics: Fukushima refugees cheer for native son
fields.description: A Japanese track cyclist from the no-go zone around the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant is helping unite a community scattered by last year's quake-tsunami disaster as they cheer him on in the London Olympics. Duration: 01:38

fields.title: Ten days ahead of elections, tempers frayed in Haiti
fields.description: Tempers are frayed in Haiti less than ten days ahead of crucial general elections that will see Preval's successor chosen in the first polls since January's earthquake. Political forces are being blamed for whipping up tensions in the northern city of Cap-Haitien and in the capital on Thursday.Duration: 01:38

fields.title: Pakistan: Millions still at risk from floods, illness
fields.description: A month after monsoons triggered catastrophic flooding throughout Pakistan, submerging an area the size of England, eight million people remain dependent on handouts for their survival, which they say are too slow coming. NGO 'Doctors Without Borders' is helping to bring urgent medical treatment to people in the areas around Sukkur.Duration: 01:39

fields.title: Haitian earthquake survivor arrives in New York
fields.description: Six-year-old Adaurdo Pierre survived the earthquake in Port-au-Prince and was reunited with his mother in New York City yesterday. His American citizenship allowed him to leave the devastated island. Other Haitian New Yorkers crowded into a local community center to find out if immigration laws might help them their family members to New York. Duration: 01:37

fields.title: Families stranded on embankments by rising flood waters
fields.description: Pakistan ordered the evacuation of 300000 people from Thatta city after waters breached its defences. But many families remain stranded on embankments, surrounded on all sides by rising flood waters. Duration: 01:36.

fields.title: Lack of access to petrol fuels Haiti chaos
fields.description: A week on from Haiti's killer earthquake, it's not just food, water and medicines in short supply. A lack of available petrol is also fuelling the post-quake chaos. Survivors have been scrambling to get their share of dwindling reserves from the service stations still standing, while others have been forced to buy from the black market at inflated prices. Duration: 01:36.

fields.title: Prayers among the rubble for Haiti's faithful
fields.description: Church bells were eerily silent Sunday over the ruined Haitian capital, but the faithful still came in droves praying for solace in the darkest hour of this deeply-religious nation. Only the facade of the once proud building now stands over the ruins felled by the powerful 7.0-magnitude quake which struck on Tuesday.Duration: 01:36

fields.title: 'Years' for Japan communities to rebuild: Red Cross
fields.description: Communities in Japan destroyed by the tsunami are years away from being righted, the Red Cross warned Friday, with many of the displaced stuck in temporary housing for a long time to come. Duration: 01:35

fields.title: Haitians feel helpless in New York
fields.description: Despite days of frantic phone calls, many Haitian New Yorkers still haven't heard from their relatives after this week's earthquake. Haitian radio stations and community centers in Brooklyn, one of the largest Haitian immigrant communities in the US, are serving as remote command centers, directing rescuers on the ground to find missing loved ones. Duration: 01:34

fields.title: Red Cross seeks funds to feed 1.1 mn in Shebab areas
fields.description: The international Red Cross calls upon donor nations to double its Somalia budget so it can feed more than a million people hit by famine in areas controlled by Al-Qaeda-linked rebels.Duration: 01:34

fields.title: Haitian radio key link for survivors
fields.description: Ever since the massive earthquake devastated Haiti, local radio stations have been providing a key link for people desperate for news of their families and friends.Duration: 01:34

fields.title: Haitians turn to God at quake anniversary
fields.description: In Port-au-Prince, hundreds of Roman Catholics attended Mass on Sunday under tents erected next to the cavernous ruins of the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Assumption. The event took place a year after an earthquake destroyed much of the Haitian capital. Duration: 01:33

fields.title: Smartphone Geiger counters allay fears in Japan
fields.description: Smartphones with state-of-the-art radiation counters are in high demand in Japan after the March 11 earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disasters sparked fears over radioactive contamination. Duration: 01:32

fields.title: Haiti quake victims search the debris for precious objects
fields.description: One month after the devastating earthquake, Port-au-Prince residents are trying to piece their lives back together. As bulldozers clear rubble, quake victims move in to scavenge for wood, bricks and metal -- anything that can be used to build new homes. Duration: 01:31.

fields.title: Survival struggle against Somalia's drought
fields.description: Dying children, hunger and overcrowded camps -- Somalis describe the extreme drought threatening famine and death on a massive scale in the Horn of Africa. Interview with the Country Director of Action against Hunger and images from Somalia. Duration: 01:30

fields.title: Rebuilding Haiti, one year on
fields.description: A year after its devastating earthquake, Haiti is still lagging at rebuilding. Non-profit groups and local construction companies alike are labouring to get projects off the ground, but work is slow-going in a country without a functioning government or even the most basic infrastructure, and cursed by a cholera epidemic which continues to worsen. Duration: 01:30.

fields.title: Horn of Africa drought to worsen, warns UNICEF
fields.description: The worst drought in decades has hit the Horn of Africa and the UN children's fund warns that children are suffering the most. AFPTV visits rural communities in northern Kenya, where livestock have been practically wiped out in recent months, and rates of malnutrition amongst children have risen dramatically. Duration: 01:29

fields.title: Drought compounds Somalia's woes
fields.description: The drought ravaging central Somalia has compounded the problems of a people already caught in the crossfire between the country's warring factions.

fields.title: Flood spares Pakistan city as waters recede
fields.description: A torrent of water threatening to deluge a major town in flood-hit Pakistan has begun to recede, officials said on Monday, as emergency workers plugged a breach in defences against the swollen Indus river. The Pakistani government has been overwhelmed by the magnitude of the disaster, the worst in the country's history.Duration: 01:28

fields.title: Amnesty urges 'strong financial response' to famine
fields.description: Children in drought-struck Somalia are suffering from a range of war crimes including systematic recruitment by Islamist insurgents, Amnesty International said on Wednesday. The London-based rights group urged international action to protect the rights of children in war-torn Somalia, where tens of thousands are fleeing extreme drought. Duration: 01:26

fields.title: UNICEF distributes emergency aid to refugees in Mogadishu
fields.description: Emergency supplies are being delivered to thousands of displaced families who have arrived in Mogadishu, fleeing the drought in the Horn of Africa. Plastic sheets, mosquito nets, jerrycans and high-energy biscuits are being distributed by UNICEF's NGO partner HINNA.Duration: 01:26

fields.title: Persistent rains thwart Pakistan relief efforts
fields.description: The UN says the huge scale of devastation wrought by monsoon rains in Pakistan is testing aid agencies to their limits. The French NGO Médecins sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders) says its efforts to distribute aid to thousands of needy families have been thwarted in recent days by persistent rain and flooding. Duration: 01:27

fields.title: The struggle to get by after Japan's tsunami
fields.description: Nearly half a million people in northeast Japan are still living in shelters. But daily life is hard for those whose houses remain intact. There's still no electricity or running water in many districts and some people are thinking of moving away from the coast altogether. Duration: 01:25.

fields.title: UN declares famine in sixth Somali region
fields.description: Famine has spread to a sixth southern Somali region and will likely extend further in the coming four months, the United Nations said on Monday. Images from the internally displaced persons (IDP) camp at Sayidka in Mogadishu. Duration: 01:24

fields.title: Millions lack shelter after Pakistan floods
fields.description: With entire towns and villages swallowed up by Pakistan's devastating floods, experts say it could take years to solve a shelter crisis now facing up to six million people camped out under open skies.Duration: 01:24

fields.title: Desperate Haitians contemplate mass exodus
fields.description: Relief workers in Haiti have been struggling for the fifth day to assist desperate earthquake survivors amid anger over the chaotic aid effort, as aftershocks continued to shake the island. With fears growing of epidemics and other heath problems, many inhabitants have now decided to try to flee the disaster altogether. Duration: 01:23

fields.title: UNHCR urges more aid to drought-hit Somalia
fields.description: UN refugee agency chief Antonio Guterres said Tuesday that relief groups should increase aid to war-battered and drought-hit Somalis to reduce the exodus to neighbouring countries. Duration: 01:22

fields.title: Shakira visits quake-hit Haiti
fields.description: Colombian pop star Shakira was welcomed by students at an all-girls school in Haiti on Thursday. Shakira, who visited Haiti following the January 2010 earthquake, is donating USD 800000 to the Elie Dubois School which is run by nuns.Duration: 01:22

fields.title: Muslim states pledge $350 mn to Somalia at Turkey summit
fields.description: Members of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation promised to donate 350 million dollars as a relief for famine that has hit Somalia, in an emergency meeting here on Wednesday.Duration: 01:20

fields.title: Evacuated Pakistanis settle on streets
fields.description: Many of the tens of thousands of Pakistanis who have left southern coastal towns after a flood warning have set up temporary accommodation on the streets of Thatta city's Makli neighbourhood, and down the highway running across the fringes of the country's financial capital Karachi. They say they can get by on shelter for a while but food scarcity is threatening their survival.Duration: 01:21

fields.title: Health crisis looming from Pakistan floods
fields.description: Almost 14 million people have been affected by Pakistan's worst ever floods. Children are among the most vulnerable with diarrhoea the biggest health threat and measles a serious concern. Images and soundbites from a mobile medical clinic near Charsadda. Duration: 01:19

fields.title: Aerials of the moment the tsunami hit Japan
fields.description: Aerial footage shot by Iwate Prefecture police shows the moment when the tsunami hit the cities of Ofuna and Rikuzentaka on March 11, 2011. Duration: 01:19

fields.title: AU Summit agrees aid for famine in Horn of Africa
fields.description: African donors meeting at an African Union Summit in Ethiopia have raised $365million for drought hit Horn of Africa. Duration: 01:19

fields.title: Anti-nuclear protests in Japan
fields.description: Hundreds of people joined anti-nuclear protests in Japan on Sunday following the country's worst ever atomic accident at the tsunami-stricken Fukushima plant.Duration: 01:19

fields.title: The fight to help flooded Pakistan
fields.description: Authorities in flooded areas of souther Pakistan are struggling to help hundreds of thousands of people evacuated from their homes. While many are living in roadside shelters or making their way to camps in Karachi, still others remain cut off by the flood waters. Duration: 01:20

fields.title: Somalia security improving but aid still urgent: UN
fields.description: The UN special representative in Somalia tells AFPTV that security is improving every day in Mogadishu now that the Islamist Shebab has withdrawn from the city. But Dr Augustine Mahiga warns that money and aid is desperately needed for the war-wracked country. Duration: 01:18

fields.title: Spirits are high for Haiti's rum producers
fields.description: The earthquake that ravaged much of Haiti in January stopped production of a prized product and the country's national drink: rum. Reserves ran low at home and abroad, and bottles were selling on the black market for double their normal price, according to producers. But Haitians can look forward to a plentiful flow of the "brown gold" once again. Barbancourt, the blenders that make the majority of the country's rum, are back up and running. Duration: 01:18

fields.title: Haiti survivors seek solace in faith
fields.description: Quake-scarred Haiti was rocked by a powerful aftershock Wednesday, causing little damage but jolting the frayed nerves of survivors and fanning a new wave of religious fever among the nation's deeply-religious people.Duration: 01:18

fields.title: Biggest earthquake on Japanese record
fields.description: VIDEO: The strongest earthquake ever to hit Japan unleashed a terrifying 10-metre tsunami that washed away homes and tossed ships inland, with a nuclear plant among multiple sites set ablaze. Interview of a seismologist in Paris. Duration: 01:17

fields.title: US, Pakistan ask world to prevent flood unrest
fields.description: US Senator John Kerry and Pakistan President Asif Ali Zardari urge the world to act swiftly to stop militants exploiting the country's devastating floods and to prevent social unrest. Duration: 01:18.

fields.title: Hope and defiance among Japan's tsunami homeless
fields.description: VIDEO: Japanese rescuers search through debris for bodies from the March 11 tsunami and earthquake in the city of Kesennuma in Miyagi prefecture. Japan is battling a nuclear and humanitarian crisis as engineers work to prevent meltdown at a stricken atomic plant, while the toll of dead and missing from the quake and tsunami has topped 16000. Duration: 01:16

fields.title: The fight to help flooded Pakistan
fields.description: For nearly a month, torrential monsoon rains have triggered massive floods, moving steadily from north to south in Pakistan, affecting a fifth of the volatile country and 17 million of its 167 million people. Hundreds of thousands of people are fleeing areas of southern Pakistan, in the province of Sindh, as rising floodwaters breach more defenses and inundate towns. Duration:01:16

fields.title: Emergency services brave radiation to spray water on reactor
fields.description: Emergency services spray water at Fukushima No. 1 nuclear plant using specially equipped fire trucks to try and prevent a full-blown meltdown. Duration: 01:15.

fields.title: Angelina Jolie visits quake-stricken Haiti
fields.description: Hollywood starlet and UNHCR Goodwill Ambassador Angelina Jolie visited UN staff in Haiti on Tuesday and toured a children's refuge, nearly four weeks after the country was devastated by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake. ImagesDuration: 01:15

fields.title: Former Haiti president Aristide ready to return
fields.description: Former Haitian president Jean Bertrand Aristide, exiled in South Africa since 2004, said Friday he was ready to return to help rebuild the country in the wake of the devastating earthquake.Duration: 01:15

fields.title: UN chief urges world to speed up Pakistan aid
fields.description: UN chief Ban Ki-moon flew into Pakistan on Sunday to visit areas ravaged by floods and urged the world to speed up aid for up to 20 million people hit by the country's worst humanitarian disaster.Duration: 01:13

fields.title: 'France sees Pakistan as partner': President Zardari
fields.description: France sees Pakistan as a reliable friend, President Ali Asif Zardari said Monday after meeting his French counterpart Nicolas Sarkozy in Paris.Duration 01:14

fields.title: Americans celebrate start of cherry blossom season
fields.description: Washington's kicks off cherry blossom season with performances from pop songstress Sara Bareilles, Japanese R&B singer MISIA, and a variety of other tributes to the nation of Japan, hit hard by last year's tsunami. This year marks the centenary of Japan's gift of the trees to the United States. Duration: 01:12

fields.title: UN declares famine in southern Somalia
fields.description: The United Nations has declared famine in two regions of southern Somalia and is considering whether to send its food agency back into the region after Islamist rebels appealed for help to face a drought threatening millions. Duration: 01:13

fields.title: Somali refugees make way to Ethiopian camps
fields.description: Almost half have arrived in the last two months as they flee famine, drought and a war that has raged for two decades. A massive influx of Somali refugees has overstretched refugee camps in Liben, Ethiopia, which were initially built to shelter 45000 people. Duration: 01:11

fields.title: Tokyo residents speak of nuclear fears
fields.description: Japan's nuclear crisis deepened on Wednesday with another fire at a quake-hit atomic power plant and a radiation spike there that forced the temporary evacuation of workers. Tokyo residents share their worries about the nuclear emergency.Duration: 01:11

fields.title: Haiti girl saved from rubble after 15 days
fields.description: Rescuers on Wednesday dragged a Haitian girl alive from the rubble 15 days after a devastating quake, in a rare moment of joy for a country where victims still face a desperate shortage of aid. A French search team saved the 16-year-old after neighbors heard a voice in the debris of a house in Port-au-Prince, ending what appeared to be the longest ordeal of any survivor so far following the January 12 disaster.Duration: 01:11

fields.title: Kenyan minister: we failed to plan for drought
fields.description: The deputy speaker of the Kenyan parliament admits his country failed to plan for the drought, which has seen hundreds of thousands of people facing starvation across the horn of Africa. Farah Maalim also admits that some aid money is being lost to corruption. Duration: 01:10

fields.title: EU aid commissioner visits Somalian relief camp
fields.description: Relief efforts continue to support 12 million people facing drought in the Horn of Africa, as the UN prepares to host emergency talks on the crisis in the region. EU aid commissioner Kristalina Georgieva visits the Dolo relief camp in Somalia. Duration: 01:09.

fields.title: France sends aid planes to Haiti
fields.description: As the death toll of the devastating quake in Haiti was feared to top 100000, French fire fighters, rescue workers and relief agencies flew to Port-au-Prince on Wednesday afternoon, with tons of rescue equipment and medical supplies.Duration: 01:09

fields.title: 40000 famine-hit Somalis flee to Mogadishu: UNHCR
fields.description: Some 40000 famine-hit people have fled to the Somali capital Mogadishu over the past month in search of food and water, the UN refugees agency said Tuesday. Meanwhile the UN's World Programme Programme was preparing to airlift food aid into the Somali capital Mogadishu, but efforts were hampered by last minute paperwork in Kenya. Duration: 01:07.

fields.title: Red Cross dispatches food aid to Somalia
fields.description: The International Committee of the Red Cross is shipping food aid to Somalia, as conditions deteriorate amid the region's worst drought in over half a century. Duration: 01:07

fields.title: Pakistan waters recede as tent cities spring up
fields.description: Water levels receded in Pakistan on Thursday but survivors of record floods are enduring grim conditions in makeshift tent cities, as the UN appealed for 460 million dollars in urgent foreign aid. An estimated 14 million people have been affected by the floods -- many have lost their homes and livelihoods including those in Sukkur, in the southern Sindh province, where 500 people have found temporary shelter.Duration: 01:07

fields.title: FAO calls for emergency aid for 12 mn people in E. Africa
fields.description: Ahead of emergency talks at FAO in Rome on Monday aimed at coordinating emergency aid for 12 million people on the brink of starvation in the Horn of Africa, UN emergency official Cristina Amaral says the fact children are dying of hunger is "immoral". Duration: 01:06.

fields.title: Foreign aid for Indonesia quake victims
fields.description: Foreign and local aid for Indonesia earthquake victims is being moblized. At least 1100 people died in Wednesday's 7.6 magnitude earthquake which has devastated Padang city. Duration: 01:06

fields.title: Obama unveils 100 million dollars of Haiti aid
fields.description: President Barack Obama promised Haitians Thursday they would not be foresaken or forgotten, offering 100 million dollars in immediate earthquake aid and every element of US power to help them. Duration: 01:06

fields.title: California coast hit by tsunami waves from Japanese earthquake
fields.description: California ordered hundreds of people to evacuate from coastal areas Friday as tsunami waves from a Japanese earthquake swept in, a spokeswoman said, warning there could be "significant" impacts. Duration: 01:05.

fields.title: UN urges end to crisis cycle in Horn of Africa
fields.description: The United Nations food agency called on Thursday for long-term aid for farmers in the Horn of Africa to "break the cycle" of hunger, saying constant crises in the drought-hit region should shame the world. Duration: 01:04.

fields.title: Tsunami survivor struggles to rebuild her life
fields.description: One year ofter a huge earthquake and tsunami, a survivor in Ishinomaki is slowly rebuilding her life. 62-year old Mitsuko Tamura spent a month in hospital and is recovering from a severe nervous breakdown. Duration: 01:03

fields.title: Angelina Jolie in Pakistan to meet flood victims
fields.description: Hollywood star Angelina Jolie visited Pakistan's northwest to draw world attention to the plight of 21 million people affected by the country's worst-ever floods. Duration: 01:03.

fields.title: Pakistan floods bring untold suffering for children
fields.description: Families living in makeshift camps all over southern Pakistan are particularly hard-hit by the disaster -- and the situation is especially hard for children. Duration: 01:02

fields.title: Pakistan floods, 1year on: thousands still affected
fields.description: Thousands of people displaced by the 2010 Pakistan floods find themselves unable to return to their homes, even though water has receded from towns and villages. Duration: 01:02

fields.title: Mothers and children receive medical relief in Pakistan
fields.description: The United Nations estimates that up to 3.5 million children are at high risk from deadly water-borne diseases in Pakistan as a result of the country's devastating floods. In Charsadda in northwestern Pakistan, health workers are vaccinating children against polio, measles and tetanus. Duration: 01:02.

fields.title: US military choppers deliver Pakistan flood aid
fields.description: US soldiers are helping to deliver aid by helicopter in Pakistan where massive flooding and subsequent landslides have cut off roads and put thousands of people out of reach of most food and emergency supplies. The UN estimates at least 1600 people have been killed in nearly a fortnight of floods in the largely impoverished, insurgency-hit country.Duration: 01:02

fields.title: Japan emperor recalls 2011 as 'truly distressing year'
fields.description: Japan's Emperor Akihito marked his 78th birthday on Friday by recalling a "truly distressing year" but praising the unity of the Japanese people in overcoming March's earthquake-tsunami-nuclear disasters. Duration: 01:01

fields.title: Disaster-ravaged Haiti begins voting in key elections
fields.description: Haitians early Sunday began voting for a new president and lawmakers in an election marred by violence and concerns about fraud, while a cholera epidemic eats away at the earthquake-ravaged country. Balloting began in most of the country shortly before 6:00 am, as scheduled. However, some polling stations opened late.Duration: 01:01

fields.title: Japanese mothers worried about children's health
fields.description: Residents of Tokyo are getting increasingly worried by radiation from Fukushima plant and reports of contaminated food and water. Some have decided to move their families further south to Osaka.Duration:01:02

fields.title: Japan's crisis-hit Fukushima nuclear plant
fields.description: The huge earthquake and tsunami that hit northeast Japan on March 11 sparked a crisis at the Fukushima nuclear power plant after huge waves knocked out vital cooling systems, leading to partial meltdowns and the world's worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl. Duration: 01:01

fields.title: WFP airlifts emergency food to Somalia
fields.description: The World Food Programme airlifts 10 tonnes of emergency supplies to Mogadishu to feed thousands of malnourished children in drought-hit Somalia. The peanut-based paste flown to Mogadishu Wednesday was the first in a series of deliveries which aims to supply 100 tonnes of the nutritional supplement to 35000 children every month, a spokesman said. Duration: 01:01

fields.title: Patience runs thin for Japan evacuees
fields.description: Three months after Japan's March 11 quake and tsunami disaster, frustration is growing as the nuclear crisis shows no sign of abating and nearly 100000 evacuees remain holed up in crowded shelters. Duration: 01:00

fields.title: US troops secure Haiti presidential palace, hospital
fields.description: US troops descended by helicopter to take control of Haiti's ruined presidential palace on Tuesday, as the military earthquake relief operation gathered pace.Duration: 01:00

fields.title: Japan marks tsunami anniversary
fields.description: Thousands have attended a silent vigil and march through downtown Tokyo to mark three months since an earthquake and tsunami hit Japan's northeast coast, crippling the Fukushima nuclear plant. Duration: 01:00

fields.title: Drought in Horn of Africa: UN concern
fields.description: UN says famine in the Horn of Africa is now a "food and agricultural emergency." Interview with Chief Economist at the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation.Duration: 01:00

fields.title: UN special envoy talks about Pakistan flood relief efforts
fields.description: UN special envoy Jean-Maurice Ripert talks about Pakistan flood relief efforts following his visit to affected areas. Ripert hopes to reach an agreement with the national and provincial governments in Pakistan on priorities in delivering much-needed aid to the flood-hit nation. Duration: 01:00.

fields.title: UNHCR urges more aid to drought-hit Somalia to stem exodus
fields.description: UN refugee agency chief Antonio Guterres says that relief groups should increase aid to war-battered and drought-hit Somalis to reduce the exodus to neighbouring countries.Duration: 00:59

fields.title: Japan earthquake rattles Tokyo buildings
fields.description: VIDEO: One of the strongest earthquakes ever recorded hit Japan Friday, unleashing a 10-metre high tsunami that tossed ships inland and sparked fears that destructive waves could hit across the Pacific Ocean. Duration: 00:59

fields.title: Japan in first national quake drill since tsunami
fields.description: Japan on Thursday conducted its first national earthquake drill since the March 11 disasters that left 20000 dead or missing and triggered a nuclear crisis. Duration: 00:59

fields.title: Pakistani president holds British rally
fields.description: Hundreds of protestors gathered to criticise Pakistani President Asif Ali Zardari as he continued his official visit to Britain on Saturday with a trip to Birmingham to address a group of British Pakistanis at a rally while millions back home struggled in the aftermath of severe floods.Duration: 01:00

fields.title: US Navy helps Japan relief effort
fields.description: VIDEO: A US aircraft carrier deployed off tsunami-hit Japan conducts a vertical replenishment while under way on Saturday. Duration: 00:59

fields.title: Aftershocks slow Christchurch quake rescue efforts
fields.description: As exhausted emergency crews comb through the wreckage of New Zealand's second city Christchurch, powerful aftershocks slow down rescue efforts for more than 50 people still missing after last week's 6.3-magnitude tremor. Duration: 00:58

fields.title: UN launches vaccination campaign in east Africa
fields.description: Thousands of children in drought-affected parts of east Africa are at risk from killer diseases like measles and polio, according to UNICEF, who have launched a major vaccination campaign in Southern Somalia and Kenya. Duration: 00:58

fields.title: Bodies line Port-au-Prince streets as dusk falls
fields.description: Piles of bloodied, twisted bodies lay abandoned in the Haitian capital Wednesday as the moans of thousands believed trapped after a massive quake rang out plaintively from the city's ruins. Aerial images shot by the US Coast Guard.Duration: 00:58

fields.title: Actor Sean Penn calls for action in Haiti
fields.description: Hollywood star and humanitarian Sean Penn appeared at the Brookings Institution in Washington, DC today, making an urgent call 'for action' in Haiti, America's impoverished neighbor.Duration: 00:58

fields.title: Scientists survey seabed fractured by Japan quake
fields.description: Scientists are launching a mission to the undersea epicentre of Japan's huge tsunami-causing quake to get their first look at the fractured ocean bed. Duration: 00:57

fields.title: Lady Gaga says Japan safe for tourists
fields.description: An emotional Lady Gaga pledged on Thursday to use her star power to "remind the world that Japan is safe" following the March 11 earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disasters. Duration: 00:57

fields.title: Tsunami-stranded dog reunited with owner in Japan
fields.description: VIDEO: A dog rescued from a floating roof off Japan's tsunami-battered northeast coast has reunited with its owner. Japan Coast Guard rescuers picked up the dog after spotting it on a floating house roof. Duration: 00:57

fields.title: Tokyo protesters call for end to nuclear power
fields.description: Protesters rallied in Tokyo on Sunday to demand an end to nuclear power as Japan marked the first anniversary of a disastrous earthquake and subsequent tsunami. Monster waves triggered a meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi plant, sparking the world's worst atomic disaster in a generation. Duration: 00:57

fields.title: Dadaab refugees say there are more people, less food
fields.description: Refugees who have been living in the Dadaab refugee camps for many years, say the recent influx of people fleeing the drought from Somalia has meant they are getting less food. Duration: 00:56.

fields.title: East African Drought: new camp opens in Dadaab
fields.description: It has taken weeks of wrangling between aid agencies and the Kenyan government but finally part of the extension at the Dadaab refugee camp has opened. Five thousand refugees are already calling it home, but the area where most of the facilities are located remains closed. Duration: 00:56.

fields.title: 65 dead in New Zealand quake disaster
fields.description: A powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake Tuesday killed 65 people and trapped dozens more under flattened buildings in New Zealand's most devastating tremor in 80 years. Duration: 00:56

fields.title: Haiti's disabled still play ball
fields.description: Almost one year ago, a devastating earthquake in Haiti killed more than 220000 people and injured hundreds of thousands of others. Many victims had to have limbs amputated just to survive. They are now determined to move on with their lives and are playing in an exhibition soccer game in Port-au-Prince to commemorate the tragic events of last year. Duration: 00:56.

fields.title: Japanese rescuers search through rubble at airport
fields.description: A new explosion at a stricken nuclear power plant hit Japan Monday as it raced to avert a reactor meltdown after a quake-tsunami disaster that is feared to have killed more than 10000 people. Searchers found 2000 bodies just in the northeastern region of Miyagi, while millions were left without water, electricity, fuel or enough food.Duration: 00:56

fields.title: US troops secure Haiti airport, aid begins to flow
fields.description: Troopers from the US Army's 82nd Airborne division fanned out to secure quake-hit Haiti's main airport Friday, as a massive international got into gear and aid started to flow in. Duration: 00:56

fields.title: Haiti receives first commercial flight since quake
fields.description: The first passenger plane to arrive in Haiti since the January 12 earthquake touched down in Port-au-Prince to a warm welcome Friday, but with many passengers carrying a heavy emotional load.Duration: 00:56

fields.title: Asbestos, dioxin threats in Japan tsunami rubble
fields.description: Japanese workers tackling the Herculean task of clearing millions of tonnes of debris from last month's earthquake and tsunami also face health risks from asbestos and dioxins.Duration:00:55

fields.title: Pakistani navy uses hovercraft to rescue flood victims
fields.description: The Pakistani navy has been using a small hovercraft to rescue families stranded by flood waters in Rohri in Sindh province and to deliver relief supplies. Duration: 00:55.

fields.title: Japan marks the one-month anniversary of quake
fields.description: Japanese Self-Defence Forces prepare for and mark one minute of silence to honour victims of the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, before they continue searching for bodies beneath the rubble in Kesennuma town, Miyagi prefecture. Duration: 00:54.

fields.title: Chinese teams join New Zealand quake rescue effort
fields.description: Chinese rescue teams join an international effort to search for at least 200 people missing in New Zealand's earthquake.Duration:00:53

fields.title: Pakistan floods hit 2.5 million, 1500 killed
fields.description: Fears are growing about outbreaks of disease among 2.5 million people affected by Pakistan's worst floods in 80 years after monsoon rains killed up to 1500 people across the northwest.\Duration: 00:53

fields.title: Millions affected in Pakistan's disastrous flooding
fields.description: About 1.5 million people have been evacuated in southern Pakistan as flood waters paralyse vast swathes of the countryside. An estimated 13.8 million people have been affected by one of the world's worst humanitarian disasters.Duration: 00:53

fields.title: Magnitude of Japan nuclear emergency unclear: Greenpeace
fields.description: Japan battled a nuclear emergency Sunday in which the government said twin meltdowns may have taken place and that radiation had escaped from reactors at a quake-damaged atomic power plant. Duration: 00:53

fields.title: Fukushima worker says the situation is 'catastrophic'
fields.description: A worker at the Fukushima nuclear plant says the situation is "catastrophic" and calls on authorities to tell the truth. Japan has upgraded the Fukushima nuclear emergency to a maximum seven on an international scale. Duration: 00:53

fields.title: Ban says Haiti worst disaster in decades
fields.description: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said Sunday that Haiti was the worst humanitarian crisis in decades as he surveyed the devastated quake-hit capital for himself.Duration: 00:53

fields.title: Jackie Chan, Asian stars raise funds for Japan
fields.description: Action hero Jackie Chan and other Asian celebrities have held a charity concert in Hong Kong, raising funds for disaster-stricken Japan, where about 28000 are dead or missing.Duration: 00:52

fields.title: Pakistan in fresh warning as floods hit 3.2 million
fields.description: Pakistan is battling to cope with the worst floods in living memory, which have affected 3.2 million people and killed up to 1500. A week into the crisis and as more monsoon rains lashed the country, anger was reaching boiling point among impoverished survivors complaining that they have been abandoned by the government after their livelihoods were swept away.Duration: 00:52

fields.title: Emotional gatherings mark one month since Haiti quake
fields.description: Haitians gathered at tearful ceremonies in sprawling homeless camps, churches and alleyways Friday to mark one month since a huge quake shattered their country and killed more than 200000 people.Duration: 00:53

fields.title: Aid anger mounts as Haiti death toll tops 200000
fields.description: The death toll in the Haiti quake has swelled to 200000, Prime Minister Jean-Max Bellerive said Wednesday as angry protests over the slow arrival of aid flared on the rubble-strewn streets.Duration: 00:53

fields.title: Indonesia battles to aid tsunami survivors as toll tops 400
fields.description: Indonesia is battling to deliver aid to remote islands where a tsunami has killed over 400 people, as almost 13000 people are living in makeshift camps on the islands after their homes were wiped out in the killer wave. Duration: 00:52.

fields.title: Stocking up on food and petrol in Fukushima
fields.description: VIDEO: As Japan battled a nuclear emergency Sunday, in the city of Fukushima, set amid mountains some 80 kilometres northwest of the seaside plants, there were struggles of a different kind as people rushed to stock up on supplies. Duration: 00:51

fields.title: Nuclear power and the generation of electricity
fields.description: Thousands demonstrated in Tokyo at the weekend against nuclear power generation, 11 months after a massive earthquake and tsunami sparked reactor meltdowns at the Fukushima plant. The role of nuclear power in global generation of electricity.

fields.title: Clearing Japan tsunami homes, one shovel at a time
fields.description: It oozes and reeks and sometimes it shimmers in oily rainbow colours. Millions of tonnes of putrid mud now fill every nook and cranny of Japan's tsunami disaster zone. Duration: 00:50.

fields.title: Robot seals heal hearts of Japan's tsunami survivors
fields.description: High-tech fluffy seals that respond to human touch are the latest weapon in the battle against depression for survivors of Japan's tsunami disaster. Duration: 00:50

fields.title: Tokyo residents discuss concerns after quake
fields.description: VIDEO: As millions of Japanese people were without food, water or power on Monday, Tokyo residents discuss their concerns in the aftermath of a massive quake and tsunami that has left the economic superpower battling third-world conditions. Duration: 00:50

fields.title: Post-disaster kick off for Japan's football league
fields.description: VIDEO: Sendai, a city at the heart of Japan's disaster zone, is holding its first football match on home turf since the March 11 earthquake and tsunami. Duration: 00:50

fields.title: Japan's finance minister to become latest PM (2)
fields.description: Japan's premier-designate Yoshihiko Noda vows a safe pair of hands in rebuilding the country from its tsunami-nuclear disasters after he has been elected the ruling party chief. Duration: 00:49.

fields.title: Emergency work continues at Fukushima nuclear plant
fields.description: Japanese emergency workers spray water to try to cool reactor units at the damaged Fukushima nuclear power plant. Duration: 00:49

fields.title: Aftershocks frighten Japan quake evacuees
fields.description: VIDEO: Evacuated residents in Sendai, one of the regions worst hit by the earthquake and tsunami, are living in constant fear as strong aftershocks continue. Duration: 00:49

fields.title: A hungry start for Pakistan's newest flood victims
fields.description: Jannan Soorjo summoned the energy to give birth in the filthy Pakistan graveyard that has become her refuge from the floods -- but she cannot produce the milk to feed her sickly newborn.Duration: 00:50

fields.title: Massive Indonesia quake triggers tsunami alert
fields.description: A huge earthquake and strong aftershocks struck off Indonesia's Sumatra island early on Wednesday, triggering an Indian Ocean-wide tsunami alert that sends terrified people fleeing from the coast. Duration: 00:49

fields.title: UN to launch appeal as Pakistan disaster deepens
fields.description: A Pakistani army helicopter flies relief supplies for villagers in the devastated city of Sukkur in southern Pakistan. The UN is launching an appeal to help some 14 million people affected by flooding. Duration: 00:49

fields.title: Tokyo stocks hammered, BoJ unleashes record funds
fields.description: Japanese stocks tumbled Monday and the central bank poured a record amount of cash in a bid to soothe money markets shaken by Japan's biggest ever earthquake, a devastating tsunami and a nuclear emergency. Duration: 00:48

fields.title: Nuclear threat worries Japanese rescue workers
fields.description: VIDEO: In Miyako, a port town ravaged by the tsunami that followed the huge earthquake in Japan on March 11, Japanese rescue workers rested on Wednesday evening after another long day searching for survivors. Duration: 00:48

fields.title: One of Japan's 'last geishas' defies tsunami
fields.description: Tsuyako Ito, the last working geisha in the Japanese steel city of Kamaishi, is no stranger to disaster -- having survived devastating US air raids in World War II and three major tsunamis.Duration: 00:48

fields.title: US helicopters survey flood damage in Swat
fields.description: US helicopters survey flood damage in Pakistan's northwestern Swat Valley and evacuate victims of the disaster. Duration: 00:47

fields.title: Japan's TEPCO faces angry shareholder protest
fields.description: Angry shareholders in Japan's Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO) on Tuesday slammed the company for its handling of the nation's worst ever atomic accident after the March quake-tsunami, amid calls for the firm to abandon nuclear power. Duration: 00:47

fields.title: Oxfam ships supply to Somalia to fight cholera
fields.description: Cases of cholera and acute diarrhoea are on the rise in southern Somalia and require a rapid response, the World Health Organisation and the UN children's agency said Thursday. Duration: 00:46.

fields.title: Deadly tsunami hits Otsuchi on March 11, 2011
fields.description: Images of the moment the tsunami hit Otsuchi in northern Japan on March 11, 2011 , killing 802 people and leaving 479 missing. Duration: 00:46

fields.title: Kidnappers free two women aid workers in Haiti
fields.description: Two European women aid workers were kidnapped in Haiti last week but freed on Thursday, their organization, Medecins Sans Frontieres (Doctors Without Borders) told AFP.Duration: 00:46

fields.title: US to boost Pakistan flood aid to $150 mln
fields.description: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said Thursday that US aid is swelling to 150 million dollars for Pakistan and called for a halt to extremist attacks during the flood crisis as an "expression of common humanity." Duration: 00:47.

fields.title: Hundreds feared dead in Haiti quake: UN chief
fields.description: UN chief Ban Ki-moon said a major relief effort would be required to help Haiti after the western hemisphere's poorest country was struck by a devastating earthquake. US President Barack Obama also promised swift aid.Duration: 00:47

fields.title: Thousands flee as Indus threatens to burst banks
fields.description: Thousands throng routes out of Shikarpur, a city of half a million people in Pakistan's Sindh province, as fears increase that the Indus river banks could burst as rains continue to lash down. Duration: 00:46

fields.title: Three Jordan peacekeepers killed in Haiti quake
fields.description: The Jordanian army said on Wednesday that three Jordanian peacekeepers were killed and 21 injured in the massive earthquake that rocked Haiti earlier this week.Duration: 00:46

fields.title: Haiti risks 'uncontrollable AIDS epidemic'
fields.description: As a UN donors conference for quake-hit Haiti gets under way in New York, AFPTV interviews UNAIDS Executive Director Michel Sidibe on the risks facing the devastated country, which has the highest HIV-AIDS rate in the Caribbean.Duration: 00:45

fields.title: Flood-displaced people receive food and shelter in Sukkur
fields.description: At least six million Pakistani flood survivors in desperate need of food, shelter and clean drinking water require humanitarian assistance to survive, as concerns grow over potential cholera, typhoid and hepatitis outbreaks. Duration: 00:45.

fields.title: An aerial view of Fukushima's damaged reactors
fields.description: VIDEO: As Japan desperately tries to avoid a nuclear meltdown, aerial footage of damaged reactors at Fukushima No. 1 plant has been released by its operator, Tokyo Electric Power Co(TEPCO). Duration: 00:43

fields.title: Duvalier visits quake victims
fields.description: Former Haitian president Jean-Claude Duvalier and his partner Veronique Roy arrived in Leogane, 33 km from Port-au-Prince to visit victims of the January 2010 earthquake. Duration: 00:43.

fields.title: Japan tsunami town bound to Chile by Moai
fields.description: The small Japanese fishing town of Minami Sanriku is half a world away from Chile, but the two places share a bond that crosses a vast ocean: Moai statues. Duration: 00:43

fields.title: Relief efforts in the tsunami-hit town of Minamisoma
fields.description: Over two months after the quake, tsunami, and nuclear accident, relief efforts and the clean up are continuing in Minamisoma, a devastated town near the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant. Duration: 00:43.

fields.title: More than 6000 pulled alive from quake rubble
fields.description: VIDEO: President Hu Jintao travelled to remote quake-hit northwestern China Sunday to inspect relief efforts as rescuers struggled to cope with a disaster that has killed more than 1400 people. Rescue efforts continue in Jiegu, in Qinghai country after a 6.9 magnitude earthquake devastated the area on April 14. Duration: 00:43

fields.title: IAEA says Japan underestimated tsunami threat
