fields.description: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) says Japan underestimated the hazard posed by tsunamis to nuclear plants while praising Tokyo's response to the March 11 disaster as "exemplary". Duration: 00:42

fields.title: Military helps in Japan relief effort
fields.description: VIDEO: Japan's military is helping with the relief effort after the earthquake and tsunami which devastated the country's northeast, killing more than 6500 people. Duration: 00:41

fields.title: Famine threatens Horn of Africa
fields.description: Ten million people in the Horn of Africa have been hit by the worst drought in 60 years, with some areas on the verge of famine and thousands on the march in seach of food and water. Imagesfrom Dadaab refugee camp in northern Kenya. Duration: 00:41.

fields.title: Eid brings little joy to Pakistan's flood refugees
fields.description: Bringing an end to the fasting month of Ramadan, Eid al-Fitr (Eid) should be an occasion for family celebration and gift-giving, but for poor and hungry flood survivors in Pakistan, this year's holiday offers more rain and little joy. Duration: 00:41

fields.title: France sending aid to quake-struck Haiti: Kouchner
fields.description: France is preparing to urgently dispatch aid to quake-struck Haiti, Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner said, adding that the government had no news from UN staff and French nationals in the Caribbean-island nation.Duration: 00:39

fields.title: Indonesia tsunami death toll tops 400
fields.description: Disaster response officials believe the final death toll from the huge wave that hit the Mentawai island chain off the west coast of Sumatra on October 25 could pass 500, with many of the victims sucked out to sea as the tsunami receeded. Duration: 00:39.

fields.title: Radiation, legal fears slow Japan quake clean-up
fields.description: Nearly four weeks after a massive tsunami slammed into northeastern Japan, the devastation it left in its wake has barely been touched as radiation and legal issues hamper the clean-up. Duration: 00:38

fields.title: Somalia facing 'fresh humanitarian crisis'
fields.description: War-torn Somalia faces a fresh humanitarian crisis due to conflict, poor rains and a likely late harvest, aid group Save the Children warned Thursday, nearly a year on since famine was declared. Tens of thousands of people are believed to have died last year after extreme drought and war pushed several areas of southern Somalia into famine last July. Although the famine was declared over in February, severe emergency conditions remain in many areas. Duration: 00:38

fields.title: NGO warns says crisis worsening in Somalia
fields.description: The charity Action against Hunger is one of only a handful of international NGO's currently working in Somalia. They say there's been a huge rise in the number of Somalis fleeing rural areas to Mogadishu, arguably the most dangerous city on earth. The internally displaced people there are struggling to survive with little access to aid.Duration: 00:38

fields.title: Haiti quake just beneath surface on notorious fault: expert
fields.description: The quake that struck Haiti erupted just below the surface on a notorious fault where two plates of the Earth's crust jostle and grind, scientists say. Seismologist Yann Kinger of the Institute of the Physics of the Globe (IPG) in Paris gives an insight.Duration: 00:39

fields.title: Army calls for help as Pakistan floods move south
fields.description: A spokesman for the Pakistan army called for the help of the international community as floods spread to southern Pakistan on Friday. Major General Athar Abbas said army engineers and local authorities were trying to cope with the water flow, but that it was a 'real crisis all over the country'. The UN estimates 4.5 million people have been affected by the floods, and at least 1600 killed. Duration: 00:38.

fields.title: Japan's nuclear plant neighbours face tsunami cleanup
fields.description: The nightmare of Japan's unfolding nuclear emergency is sending fear through the community of Onagawa that lives in the shadow of another coastal reactor. The town was also devastated by the tsunami, and residents are trying to pick up the pieces. Duration: 00:38

fields.title: US, British rescuers search for missing from Japan's disaster
fields.description: In the coastal town of Ofunato, where 300 homes were destroyed by the devastating 9.0 earthquake and tsunami that hit Japan, British and US rescue teams are still searching for the missing. 112 countries and regions, along with 23 international organisations, have offered aid to Japan.Duration: 00:37

fields.title: UN urges 'massive' action on Horn of Africa drought
fields.description: The United Nations is urging "massive" action to save millions of people in the drought-stricken Horn of Africa region, as France announced donor countries would meet in Nairobi this week.Duration: 00:37

fields.title: Lone pine tree symbol of hope in Japan tsunami city
fields.description: A lone pine tree stands on the shore of a tsunami-wrecked Japanese city, a symbol of hope and defiance for people who have lost everything.Duration:00:37

fields.title: US pledges $17 million more in Somalia aid
fields.description: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on Thursday announced $17 million in new US aid to famine and drought-hit East Africa, what she called the world's "most severe humanitarian emergency."Duration: 00:36.

fields.title: Japan buries tsunami victims in mass graves
fields.description: With makeshift morgues close to overflowing and crematoriums unable to keep pace with the number of bodies, Japanese authorities have taken the drastic step of using mass burial sites. Duration:00:36

fields.title: Bill Clinton 'frustrated' by Haiti rebuild
fields.description: Bill Clinton said Tuesday in Haiti that he was "frustrated" by the slow pace of reconstruction on the eve of the first anniversary of the catastrophic earthquake.Duration: 00:36

fields.title: Pakistan floods affect 12 million people: disaster agency
fields.description: Floods in Pakistan's southern Sindh province have begun to affect the people living in and around the riverbed as a minister said the rescue agencies have evacuated 200000 people already -- less than half of the people estimated to be affected in this part of the country.Duration: 00:36

fields.title: Survivors of Japan's tsunami fear nuclear threat
fields.description: Alarm over Japan's nuclear disaster grew on Thursday with more foreign governments advising citizens to flee Tokyo as army helicopters dumped water on the overheating plant at the centre of the crisis. Survivors of Japan's devastating tsunami speak of facing a new looming threat of nuclear catastrophe.Duration: 00:36

fields.title: Tsunami surge from Japan reaches Hawaii
fields.description: VIDEO: Tsunami waves rolled thousands of miles across the Pacific Ocean after a massive earthquake off Japan and washed ashore in Hawaii early Friday, without causing major damage. Duration: 00:36

fields.title: Flood-hit China braces for typhoon Chanthu
fields.description: The worst flooding to hit China in 10 years has killed more than 700 people and forced three million people from their homes so far this year. In Chongqing, local residents have to wade through mud left after the high waters receded. Duration: 00:37

fields.title: Desperate Pakistan flood survivors clamour for aid
fields.description: Pakistan risks a public health disaster with 3.2 million people hit by the worst floods in generations as anger growing among survivors complaining they have been abandoned by the government. Residents try to clean up the flood damage in the village of Majuky near the city of Charsadda. Duration: 00:36.

fields.title: Footage shows tsunami hitting northern Japanese town
fields.description: As Japan battles to recover from Friday's devastating earthquake and tsunami, footage emerges of the waves hitting the northeastern coastal town of Otsuchi on March 11.Duration:00:35

fields.title: WFP begins emergency airlifts to hunger-stricken Somalia
fields.description: The World Food Programme airlifts 10 tonnes of emergency supplies to Mogadishu to feed thousands of malnourished children in drought-hit Somalia.Duration: 00:35

fields.title: Mexico rallies to help Haiti
fields.description: Mexico, with experience of devastating earthquakes, scrambled to send aid to Haiti. Search and rescue teams prepared to leave on Thursday night, as the Red Cross coordinated donations.Duration: 00:35

fields.title: Japanese spirits unbowed by wind of change
fields.description: Nearly six weeks after the tsunami, many of those whose homes stood up to the raging torrents have only just been able get back into them to search for the remnants of their old lives. Duration: 00:34.

fields.title: Families seek news of Haiti-bound travellers
fields.description: Anxious Haitians gathered at France's Orly international airport seeking news of family and friends who had boarded a Haiti-bound plane but were diverted to Guadeloupe following the deadly quake of 7.0-magnitude.Duration: 00:35

fields.title: Haiti quake toll could reach 300000: Preval
fields.description: The death toll from Haiti's January 12 earthquake could reach 300000, Haitian President Rene Preval said in an appeal for international aid at a summit of Caribbean leaders. Haitian officials had previously put the death toll at 217000, but Preval advanced the higher 300000 estimate Sunday in a speech to leaders of Mexico and the 15-member Caribbean Community (Caricom).Duration: 00:35

fields.title: Japan quake could alter Tokyo risk: expert
fields.description: Scientists are looking into the likelihood that Japan's devastating earthquake could increase the chances of a mega-quake hitting the Tokyo metropolis, home to 30 million people, but it's unlikely to have any effect on seismic activity on the US west coast, a National Science Foundation geophysicist, Jim Withcomb, told AFPTV.Duration:00:33

fields.title: Children most at risk in Pakistani floods
fields.description: Pakistan's Prime Minister Yousuf Raza Gilani said Saturday 20 million people had been affected by the worst floods in the country's history as the UN confirmed the first cholera case. Children are most at risk from waterborne diseases. Images of a refugee tent camp.Duration: 00:32

fields.title: Business as usual despite new Fukushima earthquake
fields.description: A powerful earthquake struck near Japan's crippled Fukushima nuclear plant on Tuesday, shaking buildings in Tokyo. For office workers, it was business as usual.Duration: 00:32

fields.title: Flood survivors in Sindh wait for food
fields.description: The UN World Food Programme said on Wednesday it was trying to get help to up to six million survivors of Pakistan's devastating floods at a cost of 150 million dollars. The country's worst floods in 80 years have affected millions and ravaged swathes of the country, killing an estimated 1600 people. The UN agency is now trying to get food to about 525000 people in Punjab province to the south and another 300000 in Sindh.Duration: 00:32

fields.title: Japanese coast guard rides the tsunami
fields.description: VIDEO: A video shows a Japanese coast guard boat riding over the tsunami wave after the earthquake hit. Duration: 00:32

fields.title: Japan Self-Defense Forces look for tsunami dead
fields.description: Members of the Japan Self-Defense Forces search for bodies in the waters around Sendai two weeks after a massive 9.0 earthquake and subsequent tsunami hit the northeastern coast of Japan.Duration: 00:31

fields.title: Rain spell might bring further woes to Japan
fields.description: VIDEO: Radioactive materials might seep into the soil through rain waters forecast in the next few days over quake-hit Japan, a nuclear engineering expert has warned. Duration: 00:31

fields.title: After year of woe, Haiti chooses a new president
fields.description: Haiti went to the polls Sunday to choose if a popular singer or a former first lady will be the new president of a shattered country struggling to rebuild from a devastating 2010 earthquake.Duration: 00:30

fields.title: Thousands trapped in Pakistan's flood-hit south
fields.description: A year after Pakistan's worst ever floods, the lush southern lands of Sindh are inundated once more, and angry villagers are desperate for help for their families who escaped the rising floodwaters by sitting on their roofs. Duration: 00:31

fields.title: More than 100000 people were feared dead in Haiti
fields.description: More than 100000 people were feared dead in Haiti after an earthquake decimated the capital Port-au-Prince, where survivors faced a second night on streets still littered with the dead. Schools, hotels, hospitals and the presidential palace lay in ruins. Raw images of the damaged presidential palace, bodies in the streets, survivors preparing to spend the night out in the streets, US Coast Guard aerials of Port-au-Prince.Duration: 00:29

fields.title: Video of tsunami hitting Fukushima nuclear plant
fields.description: Tokyo Electric Power (TEPCO) releases footage of the tsunami hitting Fukushima No.1 nuclear plant in north-east Japan on March 11. Workers at the nuclear plant are still battling to cool overheating reactors and plug radioactive leaks to halt the spread of radiation at the tsunami-hit plant. Duration: 00:28

fields.title: UN says Pakistan floods worse than 2004 tsunami
fields.description: The United Nations said Monday that massive floods in Pakistan had affected 13.8 million people and eclipsed the scale of the devastating 2004 tsunami, as anger mounted among survivors. Duration: 00:28.

fields.title: Carnival seeks to rid Haiti of its ills
fields.description: Haitians danced in memory of quake victims to mark the return of carnival. Last year's celebrations were canceled after the massive January 12 earthquake that killed more than 220000 people. Duration: 00:28

fields.title: Grim search for dead three weeks after Japan quake
fields.description: Three weeks after the tsunami, Japanese soldiers and residents continued the grim task of recovering bodies in the devastated port of Rikuzentakata on the northeast coast of Japan's main Honshu island. Duration: 00:28

fields.title: Huge Japan tsunami dock washes up on US beach
fields.description: A huge floating dock cast adrift by Japan's killer tsunami has washed up on an Oregon beach, believed to be the biggest pieces of flotsam to make landfall on the US West Coast so far. Duration: 00:27.

fields.title: Horn of Africa faces 'famine': UN
fields.description: Parts of the Horn of Africa have been hit by the worst drought in 60 years, according to the UN. An unusually dry rainy season combined with rising food prices have led to severe food shortages in countries including Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia and Uganda. Images of refugees at Kenya's Dadaab refugee camp. Duration: 00:27.

fields.title: Rescuers battle to find survivors of Indonesia quake
fields.description: The Indonesian city of Padang, home to nearly a million people has become ground-zero of the disaster after the massive quake on the island of Sumatra. Indonesian government calls for foreign aid.Duration: 00:26

fields.title: Cholera outbreak among Somali refugees
fields.description: Cases of cholera and acute diarrhoea are on the rise in southern Somalia and require a rapid response, say the World Health Organisation and the UN children's agency. Some 4272 cases of cholera or acute watery diarrhoea have been reported in Banadir hospital in the capital Mogadishu alone since January, the agencies said in a statement. Restriction: NO RESALE. Duration: 00:24.

fields.title: Earthquake shaped work of Japanese Cannes contender
fields.description: Japan's devastating earthquake and tsunami in March had a powerful impact on Naomi Kawase's haunting new film in competition at Cannes, the Japanese director said on Wednesday. "Hanezu" -- one of 20 contenders for the coveted Palme d'Or to be awarded by jury president Robert De Niro on Sunday -- tells the story of a love triangle in the mountainous Asuka region, seen as the birthplace of the Japanese nation. Red carpet images of the film's director and her team. Duration: 00:23.

fields.title: Food fears for Pakistan flood survivors
fields.description: Desperate survivors clamoured for urgent relief after Pakistan's worst floods in living memory as officials feared a food crisis could compound the humanitarian disaster. With over three million people affected by the flooding, Prime Minister Yousuf Raza Gilani ordered government officials to speed up relief work and total up damages likely to present a headache for the cash-strapped government. Duration: 00:23.
